title: Dimension Templates Page
text: This is where you can create and maintain all the Dimension Templates, Dimension Values and Dimension Names [or Sets]. Sometimes collectively referred to as Size Patterns. A Dimension Template is where you have one or several Dimension Names or sets. You can set up a variation of Dimension types such as Colour, Size, weight or an alternative. Dimension Template Group - This is the Dimension Group title where the Dimension Values sit within. Dimension Value - Is the value information of size, age, weight or any other value of which an item is distinguished. Below are some examples of Templates, Names and Values setup for easier selection when creating items. JNR CLOTHING SIZES NAME NAME VALUES Jnr XS to L JSX - JS - JM - JL Jnr Age 8yr - 10yr - 12yr - 14yr Jnr Age Combi 4/6yr - 8/10yr - 12/14yr ADULT CLOTHING SIZES NAME VALUES S - XL S - M - L - XL XS - XL XS - S - M - L - XL - 2XL 10-16 10 - 12 - 14 - 16 FOOTWEAR SIZES NAME VALUES Jnr Whole 4 - 5 - 6 - 8 - 9 Jnr Half Sizes 4 - 4x - 5 - 5x - 6 - 6x - 7 - 7x - 8 - 8x - 9 Adl Euro Whole 38 - 39 - 40 - 41 - 42 - 43 - 44

title: Creating a Dimension Template
text: When you first begin, if you have no templates set up you will see the below page. Click on the add template button, and type the name of the Dimension Group you require. Click next this will then take you to add a Dimension Value. Type in the Value and choose which Dimension Type the value is to be assigned to. Eg, NAME: Jnr XS to L / VALUE: Size Click Add Dimension, you will be taken to the Dimension Template Groups page. From here you can add, edit or delete more Dimension Values using the buttons to the right of the table. To Add Values click the + icon this will make the Value Box available. Type in the Value E.g. XS and click the save icon. The Name (Jnr XS to L) will now become the parent name and become a drop-down style menu to display the values. NOTE: The order of values can be rearranged by dragging them up and down the list using the situated to the left. To create another template click name the Dimension Template and press save. The Dimension Template will now be available for selection as one of the pre-defined Templates within the Dimensions section when in Item Creation.

title: Editing an Existing Dimension Template
text: Using the Template drop-down, select the template and click the edit button. Change the Dimension Template name and click the Save button. The name will update and be displayed in the drop-down and above the value tables. From here you can add, edit or delete more Dimension Values using the buttons to the right of the table. To Add Values click the + this will make the Value Box available. Type in the Value and click the save icon to save.

title: Dimension Types
text: Dimension types are a way of setting the heading for your Dimensions that then work in hand with Dimension Templates. These headings will then be shown in the Item properties and for reporting. A maximum of 10 dimension types can be created. Commonly used dimension types are Colour, Size, Fit and Weight. If required these can be broken down further in the Dimension Template page as Clothing Colours, Footwear Colours or Supplier ABC Colours. For Sizes and Weights, it might be Clothing Sizes, Footwear Sizes, Imperial Weights or Metric Weights. Add a Dimension Type Click on Let's add your first type. Enter the description of your dimension type e.g. SIZE. Clicking next will then take you to the main page for adding, editing and deleting types. You will see the Size set as Sequence 1. NOTE: Dimension Sequence is the order in which you wish the dimension type to appear in a drop-down list, starting at 1. You can add more types by pressing the + this will add another line for a dimension type, you can add up to a maximum of 10. NOTE: You cannot have the same Dimension Type twice. If this occurs you will be shown the warning seen below. Once you have entered a unique Dimension Type click this will save the name and be added as sequence 2. You can change the sequence number to suit your requirements. To delete a Dimension Type click the bin icon. NOTE: A dimension type should not be deleted whilst there are active dimension templates and dimensions assigned. To edit any Dimension Types click the pencil icon once edited click the save icon.

title: Step 1 - Create a New Stocktake (Blank)
text: Step 1: Select Create New to start the process. Step 2: Type in a meaningful description for the stocktake. Step 3: From the stocktake type drop-down, select Partial. Step 4: Select the desired shop from the shop drop-down. Step 5: In the "Add partial Stocktake Selection" section, choose Blank from the drop-down. Step 6: Since it's a Blank stocktake, there are no filter selections required. Step 7: Click SAVE to save the Partial Blank stocktake. Step 8: Wait a few moments and you will be taken to the newly created Stocktake form. Step 9: From the drop-down menu, select the created stocktake to proceed.

title: Step 2 - Count Add Items to Stocktake
text: Certainly! Here are the steps to add items to the stocktake: Step 1. Find the stocktake you want to work with from the drop-down menu. Step 2. Once you have selected the stocktake, click on the "Count" button to begin the counting process. Step 3. Ensure that you have selected the correct partial blank stocktake by checking the message displayed on the screen. This will open a counting page where you can add items manually or import counts from a file. If you choose to import from a file, refer to the separate section on File Import for instructions. Step 4. Enter the physical section you are currently counting. You have the option to add counts in individual sections that reflect how you break down the count within the shop. For example, stockroom, gondolas/stands, display windows, cupboards, etc. If you are importing, the sections may be based on the import file. You can select and modify these individual count lists later before completing the stocktake. - If you leave this field blank, all counts will be shown under the header of "Default" in the Count drop-down list. Step 5. Enter the barcode of the item you want to add. You can either scan the barcode or manually enter it into the barcode box. Once selected, a default quantity of 1 will be added. - Alternatively, you can manually search for an item using the "Find Item Manually" option. You can search by text, vendor, or item groups. Once selected, a default quantity of 1 will be added. Step 6. The "Total Number of Unique Barcodes" field displays the number of entries in the stocktake. Step 7. The "Total Counted Quantities" field shows the total number of counted quantities. Step 8. If you want to deduct the quantity when an item is added via the barcode entry, set the "Negate Quantity" option to "Yes". Step 9. For a Partial Blank stocktake, set the "Add Items Not Currently in Stocktake" option to "Yes" if you want to add items that are not already included in the stocktake. If set to "No," no items can be added. Step 10. To manually search for an item, follow these steps: - Enter the search text, which can be a whole word or use an asterisk (*) before or after the word to search for all possibilities. For example, "can*" for candles or "*proof" for waterproof. - Use the drop-down menu to select one or more vendors from the list. - Use the drop-down menu to select one or more item groups from the list. - Click the "Search" button to start the search process. The results will be displayed in the list below. These steps will guide you through the process of adding items to the stocktake and manually searching for items within the stocktake.

title: Step 3 - Manual Count
text: Here are the steps for manual counting: Step 1. If you are counting by sections, enter a description in the physical section box to specify the section you are counting. Step 2. Scan or manually enter a barcode to count items, or use the "Find Item Manually" option to search for items and adjust their count quantities. Each time you scan a barcode, the quantity is increased by 1, and the most recently scanned item is displayed in the "Last Scanned item" box. You can manually adjust the quantity in the "Last Scanned item" box instead of the Manual Count list before moving to the next item. Alternatively, if you are adding items directly from the item list, you can use the "+" and "-" buttons or directly choose the quantity field to adjust the count quantities. the quantity is limited to a maximum value of 10 digits (e.g., 9999999999) and up to a maximum of 2 decimals (e.g., 99999999.99). The minimum value is 0. Step 3. You can use the "Items by page [5 10 20 50]" and the "Page number [7 of 11 (54 items)]" to scroll through and find more items in the list. Step 4. Once you have added all the counts, choose the "Back" button to close the count page. All counts are automatically saved. Step 5. If you entered a description into the Physical section box, it will appear in the Count list. Step 6. Use the drop-down menu to see all counts and select a specific count. Step 7. To add more individual counts with different physical descriptions, choose "Count" again from the top right-hand side (Step 3) and add a different physical description. Note: To amend a specific location (e.g., Location 55G), choose "Count" again from the top right-hand side (Step 3) and type in the same description again. It must be the same to update the existing count location; otherwise, it will create a new count location. These steps will guide you through the process of manual counting, adjusting quantities, and navigating the count page.

title: Step 5 - Commit
text: Step 1: If all the discrepancies in the report are correct, choose Commit to accept the discrepancy report and update the stock figures. Step 2: Confirm the commitment by selecting Yes to proceed or No to cancel the Commit request. Step 3: The stocktake list will show "Committing" while making the final adjustments and then display "Closed" when completed. Step 4: You can view the closed stocktake again by clicking on it in the stocktake list.

title: PoS
text: The Imagine PoS system is a Point of Sale (PoS) solution that operates directly within modern HTML5-compatible browsers. It is specifically designed to function seamlessly both online and offline, leveraging the advanced capabilities of contemporary browsers and a distinctive hardware platform. This eliminates any worries a retailer may have about potential connection issues. While the system provides a reliable offline functionality, retailers should consider investing in a dependable LAN (local area network) and Wi-Fi infrastructure, which may include backup connections such as mobile network cut-over, if there is a desire to maintain an uninterrupted and continuously accessible service. The Point of Sale system operates on a supported browser and device, requiring an Internet connection. This connection can be established through either Wi-Fi or a wired LAN connection. However, if you are using a fixed PoS system rather than a mobile device, it is recommended to utilize a wired connection for enhanced stability. The PoS system interacts with a web-based database in real-time, allowing it to read and write data seamlessly. Coupled with the database, all business logic acting on this data is also held and processed in cloud based computing. To mitigate outages the PoS system has incorporated an offline failover function, enabling you to continue trading even in the absence of an Internet connection. To facilitate the connection between the hardware components (such as PoS printer, cash drawer, PIN entry device) and the system, a device called a "Connector" is employed. The Connector must always remain connected to the local network via a wired connection. Online mode requires the Connector to be connected to the Internet too. In the event of offline working, where the shop has no access to the Internet, then the browser and Connector work in tandem on the LAN to allow continuous transactions recording and printing. Offline working is jointly handed by features of the browser and Connector and is reliant on the LAN being active. The configuration of the Connector is managed through the POS Admin, which operates within the Imagine Portal. When initially running the device, the Connector needs to be online to establish a connection with the server and download its configuration and offline data. However, once this initial setup is completed, the Connector can operate either online or offline. It is strongly recommended that the Connector is keep online where possible as offline data can become out of date where item details are altered in Inventory. It is important to note that if there is no local connection between the browser device and the Connector (due to a router or local network being down), you will be unable to communicate with the hardware or conduct offline transactions. This also applies to PIN Entry Devices (PED's) that must be on the local connection in order to function.

title: Offline Mode
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Functions that don't work when offline. Offline whilst the POS screen is open. Opening the browser while offline. Using a desktop shortcut while offline. POS is designed to "work" offline, however it will only operate offline if you already have POS open in a browser and will be limited to certain functions. Functions that don't work when offline. Item Shortcuts. Redeeming Gift Certificates. Items are limited to 1000 latest sold and 2000 most sold items. Parked Transactions. Recall Parked Transactions. Find & Email Receipts. Use of Widgets. Extensions. End of Day procedure. Master Item lookup with variant grid view. Gift Aid (UK Only). Item information messages will not be presented. Item Images. These normally display in widgets which also have no functionality when offline. The POS uses HTML5 Local Storage to hold all the critical information that it needs to operate. This includes product data and clerk data. When working offline, a will appear in the top bar of the POS to alert you, do not refresh or backstep out of the POS as you will be unable to log back in. ⚠ CAUTION! You should avoid using Clear History, Deleting cookies or similar functions which clear your browser cache. Doing this will wipe the local storage and any settings which are held there. Browsers can be configured to automatically clear these on browser exit, and other third-party applications can also "clean" your browser These types of tasks should not be performed. ⚠CAUTION: If you clear the local storage (Through clearing browser cache, running clean-up tools, deleting cookies etc) whilst you are offline, then you will not be able to start the POS. You may however be asked to clear the cache by a member of the K3 support team. NOTE: Any sales completed using the 'default' connector will not show on the Z read. The 'default' connector is available whilst offline to enable sales to be completed. NOTE: The POS can go into offline mode if there is an issue with the K3 Servers, this can happen even if the POS is still connected to the internet. If you suspect this is an issue you can check status.k3imagine.com Some transaction data will be stored on the connector and will remain even if the connector is rebooted. The Connector will continuously try and send receipts to imagine every 60mins, once back online it will take up to a minute for these to sync. Offline whilst the POS screen is open. If you are using the POS and you go into offline mode you will see a disconnect symbol. If you have widgets enabled for your shop these will only be available when you are back online. An offline symbol will replace in the side menu. Opening the browser while offline. If you have the POS browser saved in a tab and use this while offline you will be unable to access the POS and will see the below page. You will be unable to access the POS until you re-connect. Using a desktop shortcut while offline. If you have the POS saved as a shortcut on your desktop and you are offline using the shortcut you will be shown the below page. You will be unable to access the POS until you re-connect.

title: POS Home Page
text: The first you time access the POS you must the portal via http://portal.k3imagine.com NOTE: You must also do the same if you have cleared your local storage. Once you have access to the POS via the portal, you can then save http://pos.k3imagine.com as a bookmark or set it as a home page within your browser settings. The top bar lets you access a few different functions. Allows you to set the default connector that this POS uses. Toggles full-screen mode (on supported browsers) Alerts you of any notifications or messages from the head office. Allows you to access other functions and brings up a side menu. The only option on the home page is Portal Logout. The second section shows some basic statistics from the last transaction. The sales value and the change issued. This can be disabled in the Admin module. In the middle section, the date and the POS number that is assigned to this device are displayed. This number is held in local storage and is not fixed to the device. That means if the cache is cleared from the browser, a new POS number will be generated and assigned. This is because the POS is fully portable and not device-specific. When the POS number reaches 99, it will look for the lowest unused POS number. It also displays the login box. This is where you enter your Clerk number and password. After you have completed a sale, you can quickly log back in using the below button which replaces the login panel if you tap it before the timer runs down. You can also quickly expire the timeout by pressing the Sign Out button. There is also a panel which shows some basic sales metrics. This panel can be disabled in the Admin module. NOTE: The panel excludes any Expenses transactions from its totals.

title: Logging into POS
text: NOTE: The POS will automatically update. You will receive an update notification prompt when logging in. Updates are automatically applied and you may continue to use the POS as normal during this process. To log into the POS you will need a Clerk number and password, these are configured within the Portal Module. Use the number pad to enter your clerk number, press the green tick, and then enter your password. After you have completed a sale, you can quickly log back in using the button below which replaces the login panel if you tap it before the timer runs down. You can also quickly expire the timeout by pressing the Sign Out button. If successful, you will see the POS screen. Note: depending on the browser you are using and its settings, the PoS may automatically refresh the page and you could be retuned to the log on screen. This is a browser control outside the capabilities of Imagine.

title: POS User Interface
text: The User Interface is laid out below. This is shown on a desktop-style device and the panels may be in different locations or minimized away depending on the device and its screen size. The top bar lets you access a few different functions. Allows you to set the default connector that this POS uses. Toggles full-screen mode (on supported browsers) Alerts you of any notifications or messages from the head office. Allows you to access other functions and brings up a side menu. This side menu also shows you your shop ID, POS Number and Version Number The left panel is the Widget panel. Widgets are an extension to the basic POS and will vary in use from customer to customer. This panel also displays the reason codes when you perform a function that requires a reason, such as discounting and returns. The centre section is the transaction or basket panel. This is where you perform most of the POS transaction functionality. Scan a barcode, search for a product list items in the basket and adjust quantities and apply discounts. The right panel is the Menu which allows you to access other POS functions. These buttons can be nested and have links to other functions. The soft keyboard is used when you need to enter text or numeric data into the user interface. You can alternate between Alpha and Numeric using the corresponding button or The keyboard is context-sensitive, so it will display the Alpha or Numeric keyboard depending on the input type of the field you are entering data into.

title: Using Scan / Search
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Scanning a barcode Searching for an item Browsing and searching for an item Matrix Lookup Scanning a barcode You can manually scan an item with the physical barcode using the scanner and it will appear on the POS. You can also manually input the barcode using either an external keyboard or the Soft Keyboard, Click the enter barcode section This will bring up the soft keyboard. Enter the barcode and press enter key on the keyboard or the green tick on the soft keyboard. The item will be displayed on the POS Searching an item The Enter Barcode box allows you to scan a product barcode, or search for an item to add to the transaction if you know its barcode. You can also directly enter a receipts barcode here, or the Matrix code for a range of variant items (see Matrix Lookup below) The POS will automatically detect input from an external source, such as a keyboard or a barcode scanner. However, if you want to use the soft keyboard, tap the Enter barcode box and you will be able to tap a barcode number. Browsing and searching for an item Click the browse button to perform a search. This will take you to a list of products where you can directly scroll through the items and select using the Cart button. NOTE: This list will only show active items, however, inactive items can still be scanned and added to the transaction. Items can be made active in the Matrix Tab. Cancel will return you to the Transaction screen. Reset will reset your search parameters. Use Filter to narrow down your search to a particular word(s) More will take you to the next page of results. The Filter button shows a panel where you can search for active items. When you tap the search box the soft keyboard will appear. Enter a description and it will perform a smart search, looking for the values you type. It will separate words by a blank space and search for combinations of these words. When you have found the item and you want to add it to the transaction, you press the Cart button If you want to print an item details label instead of adding it to the transaction, press the Print button This will open the left side tray where you can enter the quantity of labels required and choose which label design to print. Matrix Lookup When an item has multiple variations i.e. Colour or size you can use the Matrix Look Up. Input the Matrix Number into the barcode section on the POS. In the example below the Matrix Number is 000301 Press enter and this will bring up a list of available Variations of this item. Make the selections on the screen by tapping the options. NOTE: To deselect an option tap it again. NOTE: You cannot select multiple options of one variation i.e. you cannot have two colours selected at the same time. In the example below the selection is Colour-Pink and Size-M. Once you have made the selection tap OK to confirm and you will return to the transaction screen and the item line will be listed. NOTE: Tapping Cancel will return you to the transaction screen. You can now finalise the transaction.

title: Custom Email Receipts
text: NOTE: This functionality is no longer supported. Custom Email Receipts are supported when a retailer has their own SendGrid account. Within SendGrid they must create an API Key through settings > API Keys and record/copy the key to be used. Within SendGrid a Dynamic Template can then be created.This is done using Templates > Transactional You can then create and format a template but it must be a Dynamic Template. It can be formatted and structured however you like, but you should use the following variables in triplicate {{{curlybraces}}} and Imagine will replace these with the content from the transaction. {{{HEADER}}} {{{ITEMS}}} {{{TOTAL}}} {{{VATS}}} {{{PAYMENTS}}} {{{CUSTOMERNUMBER}}} {{{FOOTER}}} {{{BARCODE}}} {{{CARDRECEIPT}}} The Template ID is then required to configure Imagine to use your custom template. The custom receipt template can then be implemented by K3 as a Shop Feature through the support platform. Please contact your local support team for more details. Feature Name: ReceiptEmail Feature Values: Name: SendGridReceiptEmailTemplateId, Type: String, Value: TemplateId taken from SendGrid Name: SendGridReceiptEmailApiKey, Type: String, Value: ApiKey taken from SendGrid A sample/getting started template is shown below. - CUSTOM!!!!!! CUSTOM!!!!!! Thanks for your purchase! Please find attached your receipt and below an overview of your purchased items. {{{HEADER}}} {{{ITEMS}}} {{{TOTAL}}} {{{VATS}}} {{{PAYMENTS}}} {{{CUSTOMERNUMBER}}} {{{FOOTER}}} {{{BARCODE}}} {{{CARDRECEIPT}}}

title: EFT Certifications
text: K3 Imagine provides several local and global EFT provider integrations. For details of the integration in your region please contact your K3 sales representative, account manager or by emailing your local support team.

title: Gift Aid
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Introduction Receipts Settings Selecting Gift Aid Items POS Customer Capture Transactions Introduction Gift Aid is a UK scheme from HMRC where eligible organisations such as charities can accept donations instead of payments and claim the equivalent of the donator's income tax relief. This works by capturing a customer’s details at the POS when they wish to purchase a qualifying item. This data is then exported and submitted to HMRC to claim tax relief for the donation. How it works When an item marked with a Gift Aid attribute is sold via the POS, a prompt is displayed to confirm if the customer would like to give Gift Aid to the organisation. If Yes is chosen then the required customer detail is captured and the value of the transaction will be recorded for HMRC. On a periodic schedule, these transactions are exported to a spreadsheet and submitted to HMRC, usually via a dedicated portal for Gift Aid. Your accountant will be able to further advise on the submission process. For full details of Gift Aid rules see HMRC Gift Aid Receipts Editing Customer Declaration for Gift Aid The customer declaration is printed on the POS during a Gift Aid transaction. The wording of the declaration can be edited in Gift Aid - Receipts. Click Save when editing is complete. Settings Creating a Custom Attribute for Gift Aid To identify items for Gift Aid a Customer Attribute is needed. In Inventory - Customer Attributes create a new custom attribute. The custom attribute should be created as type Yes / No, it should be left as optional. Give the Custom Attribute a code and name that identifies it as a Gift Aid custom attribute. Note the code for use on the Gift Aid Settings page. Identifying the Custom Attribute for Gift Aid Items are identified as Gift Aid items via a custom attribute. Under Gift Aid - Settings the custom attribute specifically designated for Gift Aid should be selected so this can be applied to items. From the drop-down select the Yes/No Custom Attribute made for Gift Aid use. Selecting Gift Aid Items In Inventory - Item List chose or create item(s) that are to be Gift Aid Items. Select the Gift Aid Custom Attribute as part of this process to identify the item as a Gift Aid item. In the matrix tab ensure the Gift Aid custom attribute is enabled (set to Yes) At least one item is required a the POS to perform Gift Aid transactions, but you can nominate more than this if desired. POS Customer Capture On transaction payment, when item(s) marked as Gift Aid have been included in the transaction, a prompt will be displayed, asking if the customer wishes to Gift Aid their eligible purchase. Choosing No will allow the transaction to continue without further processing or capturing of Gift Aid data. Choosing Yes will request the required customer details. These details are required by HMRC to satisfy the Gift Aid transaction export. On completion, the receipt and declaration will be printed. If during this process the customer changes their mind then the 'I have changed my mind' button should be pressed and any details will be discarded and the transaction will continue as if the No button had been selected initially. NOTE: there is no validation at this stage that the customer details are valid. The clerk should ensure reasonable details are entered and formatting of details like Postcode are correct. Transactions Exporting Gift Aid Transactions Transactions are exported via the Gift Aid - Transactions menu. The transaction list will be displayed and can be filtered to a specific date range. Transaction rows can be expanded to view detail. Export Data Clicking the export icon will download transactions for the date selected as a .xlsx sheet. If any dates have already been exported then a warning will be displayed but transactions can be downloaded multiple times. You should be careful not to declare a Gift Aid transaction to HMRC more than once.

title: Functionality
text: NOTE: SCOs are named Units within the Self Serve Companion. When accessing the Self Serve Companion, you will find a list of all the Units that are currently online for your shop. In the context of the Self Serve Companion, a Unit is considered online when the SCO app is running inside a browser. It is important to note that if a machine is powered off, the browser is closed, or the browser is not on the SCO web page, the Unit will not be reported as online in the Self Serve Companion. Colour Coding The Self Serve Companion utilizes a basic color coding system that works in conjunction with the NCR SCO Tri-Light color system. Here's an overview of the color codes and their meanings: Green: This color indicates that there are no obstacles or issues preventing the user from completing a transaction smoothly. Orange/Amber: When a Unit is displayed in this color, it signifies that a supervisory action will be required soon in order for the customer to proceed with the transaction. Typically, this occurs when there is a need for approval due to a restricted item. Red: The red color indicates a hard block, meaning the customer cannot continue with the transaction at all. Immediate action is necessary to resolve the issue. In addition to the color coding, each Unit will present a message that provides further information to complement the status color. These messages serve to provide more context or details about the current status of the Unit. Status Messages Ready The Unit is ready for the next customer. No action is required. Needs Arm Setup The Unit in the Self Serve Companion will provide information about the status of the SCO's connector. Each SCO is expected to have one associated connector. If no connector is selected for an SCO, the Unit will indicate that it "Needs ARM Setup." For further details regarding the connector setup, you can refer to the POS Admin - K3 Connector Manager, which provides more comprehensive information on managing connectors in the system. Help When the customer presses the Help button, the SCO will be blocked and the Unit will show in Red. Item Not Found When a barcode is scanned that cannot be recognised, it will block the customer from proceeding so they do not accidentally add the item into their bag without paying. Restricted Items In the Product Configurator, items can be restricted in two ways. Firstly, an item can be flagged as "Age Restricted," which requires the clerk to determine if the customer is legally allowed to purchase the item based on their age. Secondly, the quantity of items that can be purchased together in a single transaction can be restricted using the "Restricted Quantity" field. When a restricted item is scanned, both the Tri Light and SCO Companion will display an orange status. This indicates that although it doesn't block the customer from proceeding with the transaction, it presents an opportunity for the clerk to remotely approve the restriction. By approving the restriction promptly, the clerk can facilitate a faster checkout process for the customer. If the clerk does not catch the orange alert in time, the SCO will block the transaction when the customer press the pay button and the SCO will force an authorisation. The clerk needs to press the Authorize button to remotely authorise the transaction.

title: Vendors overview
text: To access a list of all Vendors select Back Office - Vendors You will be presented with a list of all Vendors created in Imagine. See the How to Add a New Vendor page for details of new Vendor creation Search for Vendors by entering a keyword(s). Any matching details in the overview page will be highlighted to help you narrow down the Vendor you are looking for. To edit an existing Vendor click the relevant Vendor in the list. See the How to Edit an Existing Vendor page.

title: How to Add a New Vendor
text: From the Vendors overview page click the Add Vendor button. This will bring up a form with multiple fields to fill in. To provide your Vendor details, such as Vendor Number, Company Number, VAT Number, and other relevant information, simply input the data into the designated fields. Once all the necessary fields have been filled in, the Save button will become active and allow you to save the information. Use Back to return to the Vendor overview page. Any changes made will be discarded. NOTE: Fields marked with an asterisk * are required. Vendor Details Vendor No. A code for the Vendor if required. Company Number The Company Number for the Vendor. Name * The name of the Vendor that will appear on lists, reports, PO's and other relevant documents. Website The website for the Vendor. VAT Number The Tax Number for the Vendor. Discount Percent The percent of discount the Vendor provides to you. Main Phone The main phone number for the Vendor Fax Number The fax number for the Vendor. Accepted Currency * Select a currency from the list. This currency cannot be altered once the Vendor details are Saved. Contact Information Salutation The greeting used for the main contact at the Vendor. First Name The first name of the main contact at the Vendor. Last Name The last name of the main contact at the Vendor. Email The email address of the main contact at the Vendor. Mobile Phone The mobile phone number of the main contact at the Vendor. Vendor Location Address1 The first line of the address for the Vendor. Address2 The second line of the address for the Vendor. Address3 The third line of the address for the Vendor. City The city line of the address for the Vendor. Postal Code The postal code of the address for the Vendor. State The state, region, county or area of the address for the Vendor. Country The country of the address for the Vendor.

title: How to Edit an Existing Vendor
text: To modify the details of a Vendor that has already been created, select the Vendor from the list to open the Vendors details. Complete any alterations to the fields as necessary. See the How to Add a New Vendor page for details of the fields for Vendors. Use to permanently remove a Vendor. Before the vendor is permanently removed, you will be prompted to confirm this action. Once a vendor has been deleted, it cannot be restored. Ideally you should ensure any items are not associated with a Vendor before deleting it. You should also complete any outstanding PO's, Receive Goods or Vendor Returns before deleting this Vendor. Once all the necessary fields have been filled in, the Save button will become active and allow you to save the information. Use Back to return to the Vendor overview page. Any changes made will be discarded.

title: Users / Adding New Users
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Add User User Details Assigning Modules You will see a roster of present users, with the option to sort each column alphabetically. Additionally, you may utilize the search feature to locate users by their Username, Email Address, First Name, or Last Name. Clicking on a user will allow their roles and access modules to be added or removed as well as the editing of user details. Add User This opens a new blank form allowing a new user to be added. User Details Username - The name the user will use to access the Imagine portal. This could be different from a user's POS log-on details. Email Address - Used to send password reset notifications. First Name - Complete as required. Last Name - Complete as required. Language/Region - Used to set the language in Imagine. Role - See Roles for role creation, assign a role to a user here. NOTE: Role is a mandatory field, you should set up at least one Role before making a new user. Any existing users not assigned a role will require this field to be updated on any change of detail. Active User - To activate a user, check the box. To deactivate a user, uncheck it. If a user is inactive, they won't be able to access the Imagine portal. However, the currently logged-in user is not able to use this option. Tenant Administrator - To grant Tenant Admin Permissions, check the box. To revoke these permissions, uncheck it. Without being a Tenant Administrator, a user cannot access the Portal module. It's important to note that this option is not available to the currently logged-in user. Reset Password - This allows a new temporary password to be assigned to a user. They will be expected to choose a new private password at first login. Assigning Modules Please note that the user who is currently logged in is not permitted to add or remove their modules. To add or remove a module from the user, click on its respective tile. Modules that have been assigned to the user will be highlighted in blue. If a module tile displays a 'cog' icon, the user must be assigned permitted shops to access it. To do so, click on the cog icon and select the shop(s) that this user should be granted access.

title: Role Management
text: User roles are collections of permissions that can be assigned easily to multiple users. With Roles, you can generate a role with restricted access for lower-level positions, such as Sales team members, and another role with broader access for higher-level positions, such as Managers. The current roster of roles will be presented initially. To create a new role or edit an existing one, click on either the "New Role" or the chosen role. If you want to establish a new role that incorporates the permissions from an existing role with slight modifications, utilize the "Copy" option. A roster of module permissions will be shown. Details Tab Name - The name of the role i.e. Manager or Sales Team, this cannot be edited after saving. Description - You can describe to clarify the role's purpose. To search for a specific module or description, click the search icon in the Module or Description column. To enable or disable permissions for each role, check or uncheck the appropriate boxes. After selecting the necessary boxes, click "Save". In the Enabled Permissions column, you can display all permissions, only the enabled ones (True), or only the disabled ones (False). Users tab Clicking on the Users tab displays a list of all Users already assigned to this Role. You can search for a user by name.

title: Modules
text: Modules provide an alternative to editing each user's module access individually. To modify a user's access to a module. Open the Modules section. Locate the Users column and select the user you want to modify access for. In the Modules column, the modules to which the selected user currently has access will be highlighted in blue. To grant or revoke access to a module, check or uncheck the appropriate box. If there is a Shop Access column, click on the module to access it and tick the box to allow access or mark with an 'x' to remove access. To modify access for multiple users, select them in the Users column. The Module Access list will aggregate to show which modules all selected users have access to. After selecting the necessary modules, click "Save" to save changes. Clicking "Reset" will return you to the first column, but does not reset the modules if the user is selected.

title: Configuration
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS POINT OF SALE CONFIGURATION ANALYSIS CONFIGURATION TENANT CONFIGURATION INVENTORY Global Configuration Management allows you to configure settings that will impact all of your shops, meaning that these options apply across the whole of your tenant. Once you have made the necessary changes, ensure to click the "Save" button to apply and retain the modifications. It's important to note that if you leave the page without saving, the changes will not be preserved. POINT OF SALE CONFIGURATION Please note that the default setting for this feature is disabled (unchecked). If it is not enabled, the Point of Sale (POS) will not execute these actions. However, if you enable (tick) this option, the POS will perform the following actions when a barcode is scanned. For barcodes that have exactly 18 characters, the last 6 digits represent the item's new price. The first and second numbers are swapped, as are the third and fourth, but the fifth and sixth numbers remain in the same position. For instance, if the barcode is "123456789012123456", the price of the item is "2143.56". If the 6th character in an 18-character barcode is "9", the POS will use the following 6 characters as a search query to match against the item numbers in the item list. For instance, if the barcode is "123459111111000000", the POS will initiate a search to find the item with an Item Number of "111111". ANALYSIS CONFIGURATION Global Configuration Management is linked to the output of rows for the Analysis module. The default amount of rows 10000 (Ten Thousand) The minimum number of rows is 1000 (One Thousand) The maximum number of rows is 10000000 (Ten Million) If you choose a value outside of these parameters, you will be shown a warning TENANT CONFIGURATION The Serial Number Mask specifies the serial number format. When a serial number or item barcode is scanned or entered manually, its format is checked against the Serial Number Mask to identify whether it is a serial number, item number, or none of these. If you wish to use this feature you should check the Enable Serial Number Tracking option. SERIAL NUMBER MASK EXAMPLES 1. If your serial numbers consistently have the same format (e.g., always 18 characters long and begin with the number combination 50361), you should set the Serial Number Mask to "50361?????????????". This ensures that all serial numbers will start with "50361" and be 18 characters in length. 2. If your serial numbers always start with the same number combination (e.g., 50361) but have varying lengths, you can represent this format using "50361*". This means that all serial numbers will start with "50361" and can be followed by any number of characters greater than zero. 3. If all your serial numbers have the same format and are always 12 characters long, you should set the Serial Number Mask to "????????????". This indicates that all serial numbers will have 12 characters with no specific prefix or suffix. 4. If your stock items are from different manufacturers who use different serial number formats, and your serial numbers do not have a consistent format in terms of characters or length, you should set the Serial Number Mask to "*". This indicates that serial numbers can have any combination of characters and lengths. INVENTORY Allow Placed purchased orders to be changed Please note that the default setting for this feature is disabled (unchecked). If it is not enabled, editing Quantity and Cost in Purchase Orders that have a status of 'Placed' will not be possible. However, if you enable (tick) this option, PO's with a status of 'Placed' will allow you to alter Quantity and Cost values.

title: User Shop Groups
text: User Shop Groups allow for multiple locations to be assigned to named groups. To create a new User Group click on "Create New". 1. A new window will open. Provide a name for the group. 2. From the "Shops" drop-down menu, select the required locations previously created in the "Shops" section. Note: A minimum of 2 shops must be selected. 3. Click Save. You will be returned to the main page, where the newly created group will be displayed. To delete a Group, follow these steps: 1. Click on the Bin icon. 2. A warning message will appear. 3. Click Yes to confirm the removal of the Group. Clicking No will cancel the deletion.

title: Summary Tab
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Summary details Copy Master Item Additional Information The Summary tab allows you to view and edit the Master Item Information. A Master Item identifies a range of items (or variants) that are linked by a common theme. Master Items are not physical items that can be sold, they logically link variants together. For example you sell T-shirts in a range of colours and sizes. The price, cost, vendor and other details are the same across these items. The Master Item shown on the Summary tab is the link between these variants. The Matrix tab will show specific details for the range of colours and sizes you physically stock and sell the T-shirt in. Summary Header This is made up of the Item Name and Master Item Number, as shown on the Item list. In the example here Hand Bag is the Item Name and 10003 is the Master Item Number. Images See the How to use the Image Media Library article for details about managing an item's images. Summary details Return to the Item List page. Ensure any changes are saved before returning to the Item List. This saves all information belonging to the Master Item Summary tab. Name This is the Master Item Name. Used by the Item List and by parts of Imagine where the items are listed at Master Item level instead of variant level. Manufacturer Item No This is the manufacturer item number at the Summary level. Note: This can be different at a variant level. Default Label Template This is the label format which will be used for label printing unless an alternative format is selected at the time of printing. Active This is where you can set an item to be Active or Inactive. At the summary level, this is for all variants that belong to the item. To make individual variants active or inactive, use the option on the matrix tab against the variant. An inactive item may be excluded from certain parts of the system. Inactive items can be made active again at a later date. Previous Vendors This field shows the previous Vendors that the item was assigned. For reference purposes. Type This is to distinguish if this item is stock or sample. Description This field is an extended description of the Name field and is commonly used to hold more descriptive information about a product, such as material type, weight, size, artist information, design notes, etc. The Description can be different at a variant level. Variants This shows how many Active and Inactive variants belong to the Master Item. Clicking on the Edit Pencil on the right will take you straight to the Matrix tab where you can view and edit the variants. Sales Price Range This shows the highest selling price and the lowest selling price of the variants within the item. If only one price is shown, then all items are the same selling price. Last Cost Range This shows the highest and lowest cost of the variants for the item across all shops. If only one cost is shown, then all items are that cost. Copy Master Item This is a quick way of creating an item based on an existing item, especially if most of the field information is the same. After choosing Copy Master Item you will be prompted for a new Master Item number. Fill in as required or if left blank, it will use the next available system item number. The green Copy Master Item button will create a copy of the item. When you copy an item, it is important to give it proper attention. Specifically, you need to make adjustments to the Item Name field on both the Summary and Matrix tabs. The original Item Name will have the prefix [Copy] added to it. Additionally, remember to modify any other fields as necessary. Helpful Tip: To easily locate the copied item, simply type the word "Copy" into the search bar. Additional Information After creating an item, any modifications made to the Summary tab will only apply to the Summary tab itself. If there is a corresponding field on the Matrix tab, it must be separately updated, as these variants can have distinct information based on colour, size, etc. The fields that should be amended separately on the Matrix tab include Manufacturer Item Number, Vendor Number, Image URL, Name, and Description.

title: Custom Attributes Tab
text: The Custom Attribute tab allows you to manage different attributes of an item. These attributes have been created beforehand in the Custom Attributes Module. To add an attribute to an item, simply click the "+" button on the page. From the list of available Custom Attributes, click on each to add. They now appear in the list showing the Name, Label Code, Data Type and Required Status. To delete a Custom Attribute from an item, please follow these steps: Check if the Required status of the attribute is set to "NO." Custom Attributes with a Required status of "YES" cannot be directly deleted. If the Required status is set to "NO," locate the attribute in the list and click on the delete icon (usually represented by a trash bin or a cross symbol) next to it. This action will remove the attribute from the item. In case the Custom Attribute has a Required status of "YES," you will need to modify the attribute's set up in the Custom Attribute section of Item Management. Change the Required setting to "NO" for that attribute. Once the Required status is updated to "NO," the attribute will appear in the list with the modified status, allowing you to remove it by clicking on the delete icon. Remember that deleting a Custom Attribute from an item will remove its associated data or values from that item.

title: Hierarchy Tab
text: In the Hierarchy tab of the Item Hierarchies Module, you can view the items you have previously set up. The tab initially displays the top-level hierarchies. If a hierarchy has sub levels or lower-level categories, a gray arrow is shown to the left of its name, indicating the availability of further options. It's important to note that each item can only be assigned to a single hierarchy at a time.

title: Miscellaneous Tab
text: The miscellaneous tab in Imagine encompasses essential functions and settings for efficiently managing the item across the platform. OptionDescription POS Block Discount When the box is checked, the item is blocked from being discounted at the POS. When unchecked, the item can be discounted. If an item is already in PPE Item Prices or PPE Item bundles and it is marked as "Block Discount," consider removing it from the PPE list. The item will still be discounted as this option does not automatically remove it from any PPE list. POS Prompt for Price When the box is checked, a prompt appears at the POS asking the user to enter a price. When unchecked, the item is not prompted for a price. POS Block Quantity Entry When the box is checked, the user cannot change the quantity of the item being sold. When unchecked, a quantity can be set against the item. Enable as Web Item When the box is checked, the item is flagged as web-enabled. Do not place on Purchase Order When the box is checked, the item can no longer be added to purchase orders. Save Saves the settings on the tab. Toggle the options To set them on for the item(s). These options can also be found and edited within the individual items themselves, accessed via the Matrix Tab.

title: Matrix Tab - Details section
text: The Matrix tab shows detailed information about specific Variant items. Every item in Imagine is a variant, with an associated master item, even if there is only one variant item. Variant items (often referred to as just 'variant') are the physical items you sell in your shop such as an XL blue T-shirt. Master items group similar variant items together such as all T-shirts irrespective of size or colour. Variant item details are shown here whilst master item details are shown on the Summary tab. Note: ensure you click the Save button after making any changes in the Details section. Changes will be lost if you navigate away without saving Images See the How to use the Image Media Library article for details about managing an item's images. Dimension See the Matrix Tab - How to Add and Edit Dimensions on an Item article for details about managing an item's dimensions. Name This is the variant item's name used to identify it within Imagine, such as where the items are listed or selected. This name can be the same across variant items, master items and other items so consideration should be given to ensure easy identification of individual items when viewing data across multiple items. Weighted Average Cost Range Shows the weighted average cost for the item in the tenant and given as a range across all shops where the first figure is the lowest weighted average cost across all shops and the last figure is the highest weighted average cost across all shops. Weighted average cost is the only method used in Imagine to calculate profits, cost sales and margins. Sales Price This is the default retail selling price of the variant item where a specific Local Price is not available. Note: the Sales Price remains unchanged across all shops irrespective of an individual shops currency. This should be taken in to consideration if Local Prices are not available. Last Cost Range The Last Cost is the most recent cost recorded for an item during a receive process, such as Goods Received, Transfers (including inter-company transfers), or any other receipt of stock. As costs can be shop and currency dependant, Last Cost Range is shown as a range from lowest to highest cost and shown in tenant currency. Barcodes This shows all barcodes assigned to a variant item. To add a barcode, key in the number and press the return key on the keyboard. To remove a barcode, click on the "X" to delete. Vendor Cost The vendor's own catalogue cost for an item. This is used as the default cost on POs when ordering the item. Shown in tenant currency. Manufacturer Item No This is the Manufacturer's Item number at the variant level. An example of a Manufacturer Item Number is ISBN number for books, or PLU's for fresh goods. This can be different from the Summary Manufacturer Item number and the other variants items. It can also be different from the Vendors Item Number. Tax Code This is the Tax Rate applied when the variant item is sold. Note: The tax rate can be different for each variant. If there are multiple Tax Groups, select a Tax Rate from each group as required. Only one tax rate can be chosen from each group. Tags A Tag is a piece of information that can be attached to an item, mainly for reference or reporting purposes. They are similar to the Custom Attributes on items but express a range of values rather than a single fixed attribute. Key in the value and press return to build up a list of Tags for the item. Previously entered Tags are shown to help avoid duplication or close alternative tags. Vendor Item No This is the Vendors own catalogue number, which can be different to your variant item number. Used by the vendor to identify the item required on a PO. This can be different between variants in the same Master Item. Editable via Vendor Management, see below. Sales UOM Code UOM is a Unit of Measure by which an item is sold, for example weight, length, pack size. UOM can be different for each variant. Note: this field is for reference purposes only. Description This field is an extended description of the Name field and is commonly used to hold more descriptive information about a product. Examples can be material type, weight, size, artist information, design notes, etc. Note: this field may appear as the item's variant description in some parts of Imagine. Description can be different at Summary level as well as across other variants. Restock Level This is the maximum amount of stock to hold for the variant item, and can be different for each variant. This is used to Auto Populate POs. See Purchase Order for more details. This detail is also shown on the Stock Lookup Summary tab. Reorder Point This shows the lowest amount of stock to be held for an item and at which point the item requires ordering. It is used to Auto Populate PO's, see Purchase Order for more details. Reorder Point detail is also shown on the Stock Lookup Summary tab. The Reorder Point value can be different for each variant item. Primary Vendor Each variant item in Imagine must be associated with one or more vendors. Where an item is only associated with one vendor this vendor is by default the Primary Vendor. This field displays the variant item's primary vendor. Where an item is associated with more than one vendor you must nominate one vendor to be the Primary Vendor. This Primary Vendor is the vendor used in selections such as Purchase Orders and reports. To manage vendor for a variant item use the Vendor Management function. See the Vendor Management section below. Active This is where you set a variant item to be Active or Inactive (known as its 'active state'). Other variants will not be affected by the change in active state here, but the Summary item will have its active state altered to ensure consistency, using the following rules: If the Summary item and all variants are inactive and one variant is made active, the Summary item is made active. If all variants are made inactive, the Summary item will be made inactive. To make all variants inactive or active, use the Summary tab option. An inactive variant may be excluded from certain parts of the system. Inactive variants can be made active again by using the Show Active option in Item List. Shortcut When set to ON, the variant item is shown as an Item Shortcut on the PoS. When set to OFF, the variant item is not shown as an Item Shortcut on the PoS. By default, Shortcut is set as Off. This value can be set per variant item. Vendor Management A variant item can be associated with one or more vendors. Each item must be associated with at least one vendor and where this is the case this vendor is classed as the Primary Vendor. Where an item is associated with two or more vendors then one vendor must be nominated as the Primary Vendor. Vendor Management gives you the ability to manage these associations as well as other key information that is relevant to an item and its vendor. The Primary Vendor is the default option within Imagine where vendor/item relationships are required. For example, when making a Purchase Order a vendor must be chosen. The range of items then displayed for this Purchase Order is taken as all items where this vendor is the primary vendor. By having more than one vendor you can switch to an alternative vendor where the current primary vendor may not be able to supplier you this item. Select a vendor from the drop down and click Add to add this new vendor to the list of Available Vendors. Search this list by typing in relevant letters of the vendors name, this will narrow the list of vendors shown. Vendor Item No This is the Vendors own catalogue number, which can be different to your item number. Used by the vendor to identify the item required on a PO. This can be different between variants in the same Master Item. Primary Vendor Toggle on or off as required. Only one vendor can be the primary vendor and there must be a primary vendor. To change the primary vendor to this vendor, edit the vendor line, check the Primary Vendor box and click Save. The Primary Vendor will move to this vendor. Min Order Information only field of the vendors minimum number of these items a vendor will accept on a purchase order. Pack Size Information only field of the number of items in a pack. For example the vendor supplies boxes of pencils that come as 50 in a box. You should order based on this pack size i.e. multiples of 50 such as 50, 100, 350, 5000 etc. Cost The cost at which the vendor will supply the item, expressed in the vendors accepted currency. Tax The tax rate attributable to this item Edit the related line Save changes made to this line Revert changes to this line Delete the vendors association with this item. Only applies to vendors that are not selected as the primary vendor. This does not delete the vendor, only the association. Rest all values to zero

title: Matrix Tab -Standard Attributes, Local Prices and Custom Attributes sections
text: Important! If you move to another tab without saving, you will lose all changes. Enable as Web Item Marking an item and its variants as 'web item' will allow integrations to e-commerce sites to be selective about which items to import. It will also be available for reporting and analysis. Do not place on Purchase Order When a PO is automatically created or is selected based on filtering by vendor or hierarchy, there may be some items you do not wish to include because they are poor sellers or you have more than already needed. This option gives the ability to preclude these items from future POs, allowing you to better manage inventory levels. Custom Attributes This is where you see the custom attributes that were added in the Custom Attributes tab. Local Prices This is where you see prices for shops with different currencies. Estimated Margins Displays each Tax Rate and Estimated Margin. Save This saves all information belonging to the Item.

title: Matrix Tab - How to Add and Edit Dimensions on an Item
text: To add a new dimension value to an item, select the Dimensions button. This will load a Dimensions window showing the item's current dimension details. Header name indicates the Dimension Type e.g. [Colour. Size, Weight]. Under each will be the Dimension Name and the set of Dimension Values currently used. [Patterns,Check, Plain and Diamond.] Vertical/Horizontal indicates which direction they appear in a grid view. Click the Add button on the Dimension you wish to create a new value for. Input the new dimension value. e.g. Stars Click OK to add to the dimension. NOTE: This will add a new pattern called Stars with 4 sizes, (XS, SM, MD LG) Click on the top right-hand X of the Dimensions panel to save and close. The Current Work Item Number list will now show the newly created item variants highlighted in Orange. For each new variant, check and amend each field as required. NOTE: Remember to Save after viewing and editing the newly added variants.

title: Matrix Tab - How to Copy Values from One Variant to Another
text: When editing an item, it is possible to copy the value of one variant to all other variants using the Multi Edit icon which appears to the right of the field. NOTE: Not all fields have this option. The value to be copied must be shown in the field to start with. e.g., £20.00 Click on the Multi Edit icon. This displays a list of all variants available for selection to copy the value to. It can be to all variants or just a few. All Variants - Click the top left box to select all variants. Click on Copy to update and close the screen. Selecting Specific Variants - Click the white box to the left of each variant to select, then click on Copy to update and close the screen. NOTE: Only those selected with a tick will be updated. Filtering Specific Variants - Click the white box of each variant to select, then click on Copy to update and close the screen. NOTE: Only those selected with a tick will be updated.

title: Matrix Tab - Current Work Item section
text: Where a Master Item has more than one variant you must choose which variant you wish to edit. In this section you can choose that variant item as well as edit the variant's images and make alterations to the Dimension set. Current work item number This shows the variant's item number. if you choose a different variant this number will be changes to match the current work item. Use the drop down to select the appropriate variant to work on. Images See the How to use the Image Media Library article for details about managing an item's images. Dimension See the How to add and edit Dimensions on an item article for details about managing dimensions for an item. Note: ensure you click the Save button after making any changes in the Details section. Changes will be lost if you navigate away without saving

title: Matrix Tab - How to Mange Item Images
text: See the How to use the Image Media Library page for details on how to add and update item images.

title: Movements Tab
text: The Movements tab shows the movement (or audit trail) of an item or variant throughout Imagine. Movements can be broken down by shop, movement type and by date. From* The start date of the item's movement (manually enter a date or click into the mini calendar to select) To* The end date of the item's movement (manually enter a date or click into the mini calendar to select) Movement Type Select a movement type from the drop-down list. If left blank, then all movement types will be shown. If selecting a type, only 1 can be selected at a time. Shop Select a shop from the drop-down list. NOTE: Only active shops are shown. To make a shop active, see Back Office - Shops. If left blank, then all shops will be shown. If selecting a shop, only 1 can be selected at a time. Item Select an item variant from the drop-down list. If left blank, then all variants will be shown. If selecting an item variant, only 1 can be selected at a time. Search Finds all movements based on the search criteria entered. Once the search completes the view will update to show a Grid with the movements. Column Chooser Located at the top right of the grid panel is a Column Chooser icon, which lets the user add and remove columns [fields] to/from the grid view. Add a Column From the Column Chooser box, drag the column to the grid view. Remove a Column From the grid view, drag the column to the Column Chooser box. Close Column Chooser To close the Column Chooser, use the X at the top right of the box. Alternative grid view with Name and Item Number added, but with Barcode and User removed. The data grid shows the following. (some options may be hidden within the Column Chooser) NOTE: The grid view is not saved and will revert to the default view upon exiting the item. Date Date of the movement. Barcode The item's primary barcode. Dimensions A concatenated field containing all dimensions applicable to the item. User The user that performed/recorded the item movement. Movement Type The type of movement. From Shop The shop that the movement originated from. To Shop The shop that received the movement of goods. Quantity The quantity of the movement adjustment. Item Number The item variant number. Name The item variant name. Reference This is the Receive Goods Number.

title: Figures Tab
text: The Figures tab allows you to see different types of Inventory data based on a date period. The figures are shown in grid format by shop and variant with some options to alter the grid view. See the How to Alter the Grid View in Figures page for more details on this. Movement Header This is made up of the Master Item Name field (e.g. I love Birmingham T-Shirt) followed by the Master Item Number (e.g. 010012). From* The start date of the item's activity (manually enter a date or click the date selector icon). The start date is included in results. To* The end date of the item's activity (manually enter a date or click the date selector icon). The end date is included in results. Company Use this filter to select a particular company(s). See Inter-Company Trading for more details. Search Finds all figures based on the search criteria entered. Back to List Return to the Item List. This will then display a data grid from the selected filters. In the example shops are shown as rows and sizes are shown as columns. Each row is broken down to data components that describe different figures for the items. Sold The number of units sold in the selected period. On Hand The current quantity of items in-store that are available to sell. This includes Reserved stock but excludes Offline. Reserved The number of units reserved for customer collections, such as web orders. In Transit The number of units in transit between shops, awaiting completion of the transfer. Specifically, this is the quantity of items that have been transferred out from the shop but have not been received at the 'transfer in' shop. Once the receiving shop has transferred this item in then the stock is no longer deemed as 'In Transit'. On Order The number of units requested from a vendor but not yet delivered. This figure is based on the number of items on all Placed PO's in-line with the given filters. Available Calculated as On Hand - (Offline + Reserved) = Available. It represents the number of units available for immediate sale. Cost Price The weighted average shop cost of items at the item/location level, required for accurate reporting of profit margins. Note: the Cost Price here is the weighted average shop cost rather than the weighted average tenant cost as shown in the Item report. Location The shop whose figures are being shown. Offline The number of units held as offline stock for the shop. Value On Hand The sum of On Hand multiplied by Cost Price, representing the total value of stock on hand for the shop. Note: this can differ from the Value On-hand as shown in the Item report due to the shop Cost Price value used.

title: Figures Tab - How to Alter the Grid View
text: The grid view can be changed to show the different types of figures, change the vertical and horizontal selections, or add a filter. All Section This is a list of the grid selections available to show in the grid view. Rows The vertical selection on the left-hand side of the grid. Columns The horizontal selection on the top panel of the grid. Data The type of figure that you wish to see, such as Sales, On Hand, On Order, Store, etc. Filters This is where you can choose to see only certain information from one of the Grid Selections. For example, you can filter to see only one of your two stores in the grid. Add/Remove Grid selections can be added and removed by ticking the grid selection On or Off in the ALL section. Tick Off Removes the grid selection from the Rows, Columns, Data, or Filter sections. Tick On Adds the grid selection back into one of the Rows, Columns, Data, or Filter sections. Alternatively, they can be dragged and dropped between each section. A Grid selection can only belong to 1 section at a time, Rows, Columns, Data or Filter Filter Selection This is where you can choose to see only certain information from one of the Grid Selections. For example, to see only one of your two stores in the grid, rather than both stores. Drag the Location field to Filters This action involves dragging the Location field to the Filters section. Click on the Filter icon [top right] Clicking on the Filter icon, located at the top right corner, opens the filter panel. Within the panel, select which store to view. Once the filter panel is open, you can select the specific store you want to view from the available options. OK to apply. After making the selection, click OK to apply the filter. Grid View Order If more than one grid selection is in a section, the order in which it is displayed is the order it appears in the grid. Change the order by dragging the selections into the correct order. The example below is On Hand, then Sales, then Reserved. Drag the Sale selection above the On Hand selection. Before View The order has now changed to Sale, On Hand, Reserved. After View

title: Print Label Tab
text: The Print Label tab is where barcode labels can be printed for the item. Header This is made up of the Master Item Name field followed by the Master Item Number - as shown on the Item list. Higgildy Tank Top - 000127 Quantity Key in the number of labels to print. Connector Select a connector from the drop-down list. If there is more than one connector, it should be the one that the barcode printer is connected to. Item Select a variant from the drop-down list. Label Templateiv This is the format that you wish to print a label for. If the Default Label Template was populated on the Summary Tab, then this format will be shown. If the Default Label Template is blank on the Summary Tab, then the system will try to use the Default Label Template set against the Hierarchy of the Item. Should this be blank, then the Label Template field will also be blank. If it is blank, use the drop-down to select a format. NOTE: Use the drop-down option to select a different format from the default one. The default will reset when you navigate away from the Print Label tab. NOTE: Always ensure the label printer is on and using the correct labels for the selected format. Print For All Items Choose this option to print a label for all variants of the item. Print For Single Item Choose this option to print a label for the variant shown in the Item field.

title: How to Use the Image Media Library
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Upload Image Image Library URL Image The Imagine Image Media Library serves as a platform for uploading, storing, organising, and assigning images to your items. To add or remove an image associated with an item, follow these steps: Click on the Add button. This action will reveal the Image Media Library, where you can manage your images. The Image Library displays the images you have uploaded, which can be assigned to items. If you haven't uploaded any items yet, you will need to add some images to the library before proceeding. To access the Image Library, click on the Add button. This action will open a pop-up window with the following tabs: Upload: Allows you to upload new images to the library. Sort: This enables you to organize and sort your existing images. Assign: Allows you to assign images to specific items. Settings: Provides access to additional settings and preferences related to the Image Library. Please note that these tabs will be visible once the pop-up window appears after clicking the Add button. Upload Image To add an image to the Image Library, you can either drag and drop the image file into the indicated area or click on the marked area to browse for an image. Accepted file types for the images are as follows: .jpg, .png, .jpeg, .gif, .svg, .webp. You can select any image files with these extensions to upload them to the Image Library. Image Library The Image Library displays the images currently stored in your library. To delete an image from the library, follow these steps: Select the image(s) you want to delete by clicking on them. Once the desired image(s) are selected, click on the "Delete" button. This action will remove the selected image(s) from your library. Please note that deleting an image from the library does not delete it from any associated item(s) that have already been assigned to it. URL Image If you wish to include a link to an image that is located outside of Imagine, kindly provide the URL in the designated space below and select "Import." Please note that since the image is stored externally, if it is ever deleted or becomes unavailable, we will be unable to display the image within the Imagine app. To select an image and highlight it in green, please click on the image(s) you wish to associate with your item and then click "Add." Remember that the same image can be assigned to multiple items. The primary image, which is displayed as a large image, is determined by the order of the thumbnail stack. To change the primary image, simply drag the desired image to the leftmost position in the stack. The large image will then reflect this change. If you want to remove an image associated with an item, select the corresponding image thumbnail and click "Remove." Please note that this action will only remove the association between the image and the item, and the image will still be available in the Image Media Library. The image itself will not be permanently deleted.

title: Item List Overview
text: The Item List page will show all items. You can choose to show or not show inactive items in this list. Use the Search bar to enter a search term. Press the green browse button to continue the search of all items. If you wish to see inactive items in any results ensure you toggle the 'Show Inactive' option on. Clear the search bar of any search terms ready to make a new search. Do not show inactive items in the search results. Show inactive items in the search results. Start the search. The Enter button on the keyboard will perform the same action. This will bring up a list of options to add or remove columns. Name This is the Master Item Name. Item Number This is the Master Item Number. Hierarchy Name The Name for the item as shown in the Hierarchy Tab. Hierarchy Code The Code for the item as shown in the Hierarchy Tab. Primary Vendor(s) The Vendor shown here is the primary vendor most often associated with variants across the Master Item. Where there are even numbers of 'most used' Primary Vendors then the vendor shown here is the most used primary vendor that was first associated with an variant in the Master Item. i.e. the longest associated, most popular Primary Vendor. Sales Price The Selling price of an item. If there are different selling prices between shops the lowest and highest sales price are displayed. For example: If Shop A = 20.00, Shop B = 17.00, Shop C = 25.00 and Shop D = 20, the range is 17.00 : 25.00 as Shop B being the lowest and Shop C being the highest. On-Hand Range The lowest and highest stock figure of the item over all shops. For example: If Shop A = 3, Shop B = 5, Shop C = 55 and Shop D = 20, the range is 3 : 55 as Shop A being the lowest and Shop C being the highest. Total On-Hand The total stock over all shops. Manufacturer Item No This is the manufacturer item number at the Summary level. Unit Cost The lowest and highest Cost Price range, displayed in the tenant’s base currency. Item List Search You can use symbols or words in your search to make your search results more precise. Some other common search techniques are: Exclude words from your search Put - in front of a word you want to leave out. For example, car -seat will exclude results that include seat Search for an exact match Put a word or phase inside quotes. For example, "car" will only show results with car Wildcard search Put * before or after the search string. For example, ca* will show results where ca is the beginning part of the word like carpet, case, caterpillar, cabinet as well as car. Can use at the beginning of a set of letters too like *ar to find bar, jar, star as well as car

title: Receive Goods Overview page
text: The "Receive Goods" function is used to record the addition of stock quantities into the system. This can be done either by creating new entries during the goods receiving process or by generating quantities based on existing purchase orders. Shop Choose a shop who's Receive Goods you wish to see. The Submit button is not available until a shop has been selected. Vendor You can pick a vendor to narrow down the search or leave the field blank to search all vendors. Status Creating: any Receive Goods that has not been completed. Creating status allows the editing of the Receive Goods. Completed: any Receive Goods that has been completed through the Save and Commit option. Completed Receive Goods cannot be edited.
