Definitions - The Hierarchy Nodes can be classified into two types: Root Nodes and Sub Nodes. A Root Node signifies the highest level within the hierarchy. Sub Node means it is below the Root level. This can be 1 or more levels below. Edit a Hierarchy Node To Edit a Root Node / Sub Node click the pencil to the right and amend the details on the form and Save. Delete a Hierarchy Node NOTE: Hierarchy Nodes can only be deleted if no items are using them. Choose the X to the right of a Root or Sub Node and choose Delete. Should there still be items, a warning top right will appear and the delete request will be ignored.

title: Create Hierarchies Root Node
text: Click on Create a Root Node from the top menu bar. Fill in the fields as required once completed click "Save". Code This must be unique as it identifies the Root Node. It may be used in reports, data export/import, and can consist of any combination of letters and numbers. Image URL Not in use. Tax Rates A drop-down list showing all available tax rates. When creating an item, this tax rate will be assigned to the item by default, saving time in selection. It is recommended to set the most commonly used tax rate for the root node, but it can be changed when creating the item. Label Template A drop-down list showing all available label templates. When creating an item, this label template will be assigned to the item by default, saving time in selection. It is recommended to set the most commonly used label template for the root node, but it can be changed when creating the item and printing a label at a later date.

title: Create Hierarchies Sub Node
text: Sub Node - To add a Sub Node, click on the PLUS button [+] to the right of the relevant Root or Sub Node. This opens the same form used to create the Root Node. Fill in all relevant details and Save. Sub Nodes appear under the Root Node. Use the arrow to the left of the node description to expand and collapse the Hierarchy levels.

title: Items Dashboard
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Item Data Filters Key Performance Figures Data Performance Table The Dashboard has been broken down into 3 sections to explain what each area is used for. Item Data Filters NOTE: If a field is left blank this will automatically choose all options available. NOTE: The search will only return up to the number of lines of data as configured in Analysis Configuration. If your search exceeds the limit a notification will display. Shops Choose from your set list of shops. Vendor Select specific or all vendors available. Shop Group Choose a group of selected shops. Company This can be used if a Tenant has multiple companies within Imagine. Hierarchy This is to narrow down a category as required by only one level. NOTE: You can narrow down Hierarchy Levels further by using the Column Chooser. Dimensions Here you can input particular Dimensions of a product that were given at Item Creation. Master Item Name This is the Name given to the Item at creation. Item Description This can be used to narrow down descriptive information about a product such as Material type, weight, size, artist information, design notes etc. Item Barcode This is used as the item identifier when purchased or scanned. Vendor Item Number The Vendor number or code by which the master item is known or referenced. Master Item Number This is the number or code by which the master item is known or referenced. Item Number This is the number or code by which the master item is known or referenced. Item Status Select between if an item is Active or Inactive. Group by Columns Used to group data into summary rows based on the number of columns you pick. For example if you pick 1,2 then, after you press Submit, the data will be grouped by the left most column and then by the second left column and you will see one row for each combination. This can be beneficial where you are planning on viewing large data sets and wish to see summary information initially. To see detailed grouping you should use the 'Drag column header' feature explained in Grouping Categories. NOTE: When pressing Submit you may receive a warning about invalid group column, you should adjust the left most columns to valid entries. Saves Reports, this will also save the format you have configured. Resets the filters to default values This will fetch the data if available. To review past saved reports. See My Analysis for more details. Key Performance Figures These are static boxes of overall information from the data shown in the Item Performance Table. Qty On-hand The current quantity of items in-store that are available to sell. This includes Reserved stock but excludes Offline. Where more than one shop is selected the value here is the sum of all selected shop's Qty On-hand. Val On-hand The quantity On-hand for a shop multiplied by the weighted average tenant cost. Where more than one shop is selected then Val On-hand is calculated for each individual selected shop and summed together. Note: the Val On-hand is the weighted average tenant cost rather than the weighted average shop cost as shown in the Figures Tab. Qty On-Order The number of items on Placed PO's, meaning those items outstanding not on a Completed Goods Receive. Where more than one shop is selected the value here is the sum of each selected shop's Qty On-Order. Val On-Order The monetary value amount of items on order calculated as the current weighted average tenant cost multiplied by the current quantity on order. Where more than one shop is selected then Val On-Order is calculated for each selected shop and summed together. Qty In-Transit The number of units in transit between shops, awaiting completion of the transfer. Specifically, the quantity of items that have been transferred out from the selected shop but have not been received at the 'transfer in' shop. Once the receiving shop has transferred this item(s) in then the stock is no longer deemed as 'In Transit'. Where more than one shop is selected then the value here is the sum of each selected shops Qty In-Transit. Val In-Transit The monetary value amount of items that have been transferred out of your shop calculated as the current weighted average tenant cost multiplied by the current quantity in transit. Where more than one shop is selected the Val In-Transit is calculated for each selected shop and summed together. Qty Off-Line The number of units held as offline stock for the shop, that is items you have in-store but are not available to sell for a particular reason i.e. damaged or unaccounted for. Where more than one shop is selected the value here is the sum of all selected shop's Qty Off-Line. Val Off-Line The monetary value amount for items marked as offline calculated as the current weighted average tenant cost multiplied by the current quantity offline. Where more than one shop is selected then Val Off-Line is calculated for each selected shop and then summed together. Item Data Performance Table The table shows the data of which information you have selected from the fields above, you can modify the way the information is displayed. Search Use the Search Bar to find data in the table below Export All Data This will export the data to a .xlxs file for use. There is no option to print directly from this page. Column Chooser This will bring up a list of options to add or remove columns. Reset Grid Filters Resets any filters applied to the Data table

title: Grouping Catagories
text: To group data in the Item Data Performance Table, follow these steps: Click and hold the header you want to group by (e.g., "Shop"), and drag it into place. If you want to remove a column header from the grouping, perform the reverse action by dragging it from its position and dropping it back into the table where you want the header to be placed. Notes The table will automatically update as you add, remove and alter positions of the headers. Headers placed furthest to the left will automatically be the major grouping, whilst headers further to the right will be subsequently more minor groupings. The example below explains this in more detail. Columns that display variable digital denominations, large blocks of text and other limitations cannot be grouped. You will not be able to drop these headers in the 'drag and drop' area. In Items, examples of the headers that cannot be grouped are: Qty On-hand Value On-Hand Qty On-Order Sales Price Example of grouping with a single column: Once you group the data, the Item Data Performance Table will display the information in a different format, showing the groups. In this case, it will be grouped by "Shops." You can use the arrow next to each shop's name to expand and view more detailed information. Example of grouping with multiple columns: If you choose multiple headers to group by, you will have a stack of groups. For example, you may have "Shops" as the major header, and within each shop, you can further group by "Date". To change the hierarchy of the data, arrange the groups in the desired order. The data will stack based on the order of the groups you arrange with major priority to the left, moving to minor priority as you move to the right.

title: Saving a Report
text: When saving a report, please keep the following points in mind: Saving a report does not save the data itself; it only saves the formatting and configuration of the report. To save your created report, click on the "Save This Report" button. A pop-up window will appear. In the pop-up window, you can provide a name for your report. It is recommended to choose a descriptive name for easy future reference. There is an option for setting the report's visibility or permissions: "No One": Only you will be able to see this report. "My Role": Other members with the same role as you will have access to this report. "Everybody": Anyone with access to reporting will be able to see this report. Click the save button within the pop-up to save the report along with the chosen settings. After saving, you will receive an on-screen notification confirming that the report has been successfully saved. NOTE: You can save multiple versions of the same report with the same name. They will not replace or stack on top of each other. Each saved report will be distinct and separate.

title: Recalling a Saved Report
text: To view a previously saved report, follow these steps: 1. Click on the "Show Saved Reports" button. 2. A pop-up window will appear on the page, presenting a list of saved reports. Select the report you want to open. 3. After selecting the report, click the "Submit" button to retrieve the associated data. 4. Saved reports are categorized based on the share option chosen when saving. The available categories are: "Saved Reports": This category displays reports saved under any of the three share options. "Shared Reports": This category shows reports saved with the "Everybody" or "My Role" share options. In the pop-up window, you will find the following information for each saved report: Description: The name given to the report at the time of saving. Share Type: The chosen share option when saving the report. Created: The date when the report was initially saved. Modified: The date when any changes were last made to the saved file. Type of Report: Indicates the type of report that was saved, such as Sales or Customer. Additionally, you have the following options for each saved report: Edit: Allows you to edit the report's name and share type. Delete Deletes the report. A confirmation message will appear asking you to confirm deletion with options to choose "Yes" or "No."

title: Custom Attributes
text: Custom Attributes are a way to extend the item properties with your own values. This is useful for holding additional information about an item which may be used for identification or reporting. Examples of Custom Attributes may be Country of Origin, Material, Author, Season, Brand etc. Existing Custom Attributes are listed on the Custom Attribute home page The table shows you the Code and Name for the Custom Attribute, along side the Type and whether the Custom Attribute is required on not. To create a new Custom Attribute click the "Create New" Code - This should be a unique user defined code. Name - Unique description of the Custom Attribute. NOTE: For each Custom Attribute the combined Code and Name must be unique Data Type - Use the drop-down to select the Data Type required. Number - This should be a number up to a max length of 15 digits and can include a decimal point. Currency - Standard Currency values formatted to 2 decimal places. Text - Free text field up to 2000 characters Date - Date field formatted as DD/MM/YYYY. Calendar selection available. Yes/No - This is a Toggle type box with 2 options. Yes or No. List - A list of values is defined and is then made available to the user as a drop-down list. Only 1 value can be selected by the user. NOTE: There are additional value fields available for List. In the Blank text box, enter the description of the value and press Save to save the value entry. Remember to use the main Save button for the actual custom attribute. All values in the list will show in the drop-down box on the item. In the Item details the List type shows so the user can select the correct value. The user cannot enter a new value here. Only one value can be selected. Required - Mandatory Custom Attributes require the user to enter a value for the item. An example of a mandatory Custom Attribute may be a Yes/No question asking if the item needs batteries. All items would need this Custom Attribute setting. Ticked Box - This attribute will be mandatory. Unticked Box - This attribute will be optional. To edit an existing attributes click to make any amends, click to keep any amends made. To remove or delete an attribute click the you will be prompted if you want to delete click yes to confirm or no to cancel.

title: First Login or Forgotten Password
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS First Login Forgotten Password First Login If you are a new user, then on your first login you will be required to reset your password. When you log in you will see the below message. Clicking to proceed will then take you to a fresh page to reset your password as shown. Once you have filled in your new credentials press Reset. If successful you will be taken to the page shown for confirmation. Forgotten Password If you have forgotten your password, you will need to reset it. Click on the Forgot Password this will take you to a new page. From here enter your Username and press Send Reset Link. The linked email address to your username will receive a Reset URL, clicking this link will take you to the Reset Password page. Once you have entered your new credentials click on 'Reset Password. If successful you will see the message below.
subcategory: Logging into the Portal and Navigation

title: Portal Navigation
text: Once you have logged into Imagine you will see the Portal. NOTE: The assigned modules can only be changed by the Tenant Administrator or K3 Support. Each Module contains Sub Modules that can be accessed by clicking on the drop-down arrow. Store Specific Modules Some modules such as ADMIN are store specific and when clicked a pop-up menu will be displayed to allow shop selection.
subcategory: Logging into the Portal and Navigation

title: Updating Details
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS General Details Identity Preferences Security Modules Personal Access Tokens General Details This is the Profile user's Name and Surname details. When you have filled in the details ensure you save them using the Save Changes button. Identity This is how Imagine recognises you. Username*: This will be used in various areas to define you as a user. Email Address*: This will be used across Imagine. Preferences Here you can select which language you wish Imagine to be displayed in. Security Here you can change your current password and also set up 2FA for more secure access. Modules The Modules on the left-hand sidebar can be rearranged to suit the user. Navigate to Modules within your profile from here you can easily rearrange the Modules by dragging them into position. Once you have arranged your modules a Save Option will appear. Click to save and a notification will appear to confirm. Personal Access Tokens To begin click Create Token. A pop up window will appear with fields to fill in. User Name This will allready be filled in. Password This is the password you use to log into the portal. Token Name This should be a suitable name usedfor ref. Token Description This should be a description of what the Token is going to be used for. Once you have filled in the details click Create Token and you will be presented with your generated Personal Access Token you can copy using the + Copy to Clipboard then paste it into the application required. Your created tokens will be displayed in the list, from here you can Revoke any Tokens that have been created. NOTE: If a Token is revoked you will be unable to recover it.
subcategory: Logging into the Portal and Navigation

title: General Settings
text: Quarantine Days This controls the duration between the date of earning loyalty points and the point at which they can be utilized. By setting the value to '0' (zero), customers can use their points immediately as long as they have met the minimum point requirement. Validity Days This refers to the timeframe within which loyalty points remain valid following the quarantine period. A value of '0' signifies that there is no expiration date. Minimum available points before spending In order to redeem their points for purchases, the customer must possess a points balance that is equal to or exceeds a designated threshold. This threshold represents the minimum number of points necessary for redemption. Gift vouchers earns points When this option is activated, customers can accumulate loyalty points for purchases made with gift vouchers. Can purchase gift vouchers with points Enabling this option will allow Gift vouchers to be purchased using loyalty points. Discounted items earn points When the loyalty points feature is activated, reduced-price items will accumulate loyalty points. Web orders earn points Loyalty points will be accumulated for online orders when the feature is activated.

title: Exchange Ratio
text: A relationship between two values, such as loyalty points and rewards, is defined by the exchange ratio, which determines the amount of one value that can be traded for the other. For instance, if the exchange ratio is 100 points to $1, a customer would require 100 points to receive $1 in rewards. To set or add local currencies use the Shop Setup module via Admin. From currency to points This is the number of points accrued per currency unit. In the example above, the customer will accrue 1 loyalty point for every £1 (GBP) spent. From points to currency This is the monetary value of each point. In the example above, a customer with 100 loyalty points has the value of £10 (GBP) to redeem against future purchases.

title: Excluded Shop Groups
text: You can exclude specific shop groups from the loyalty scheme. Choose from the list of shops you want to exclude, or use the search function to find the desired shop.

title: Includes Excludes
text: Please select from the drop-down option to specify whether the selected items in this section should be "included in" or "excluded from" the loyalty scheme. Based on the "included in" or "excluded from" rule, please select or deselect the relevant options from the list of Hierarchy Nodes, Vendors, and Items. For larger lists such as items, use the search function to filter the list. To select/deselect all options within a table, use the checkbox in the table header. Use the ‘Save Configuration’ button at the top of the page to save any amendments to the loyalty scheme.

title: Audit Log
text: Any changes to the loyalty scheme are recorded in the Audit Log.

title: Check Customer Points via POS
text: You can verify a customer's total loyalty points and their corresponding monetary value using either the Customer module or the POS (Point of Sale) system. To check loyalty points via the POS, make sure the 'Customer' widget is enabled. For detailed instructions on enabling widgets, please refer to the documentation on Widgets. Once the widget is enabled, you will find the customer widget conveniently located on the left-hand side of the POS screen when you log in as a user. This widget provides you with the necessary functionality to search for customers and access their loyalty points information. Click ‘Search Customer’ to view the customer list to select from. Use the filter option to break down the search if required. When a customer has been selected, the customer details will be displayed in the customer widget on the left-hand side of the POS screen. Loyalty Points and their monetary values are separated into. Available – Points that have completed the quarantine period are now available for redemption. You can use these points to offset the cost of future purchases. Not yet available – Points accrued within the quarantine period are not yet available for redemption. These points can only be redeemed once the specified number of quarantine days, as defined in the scheme rules, have passed since the date the points were accrued. Accruing Points To enable customers to earn points during their shopping experience, you can easily add them to the transaction using the widget before finalizing the sale. The transaction should be partially paid with currency or, if allowed by the loyalty scheme's rules, with gift certificates. The points earned will be calculated based on the amount paid with currency or gift certificates, adhering to the scheme rules. When it comes to redeeming loyalty points for a purchase, the customer must have a sufficient "Available points" total that meets or exceeds the specified "Minimum available points before spending" requirement as outlined in the scheme rules. To proceed with the redemption, you can include the customer in the sale utilizing the "Customer" widget. If the available points fall below the minimum requirement for spending, the POS system will display a relevant message indicating the need for more points. Add items that the customer wishes to purchase. When the sale is ready to be paid for, select ‘Payment’ at the bottom of the POS screen. From the payment options on the right-hand menu, select Loyalty Bonus. Additional Notes If the value of the available loyalty points is insufficient to cover the total value of the sale, an additional payment method will be necessary. This means that the customer will need to provide an alternative form of payment to cover the remaining amount not covered by the loyalty points. In transactions where loyalty points have been redeemed, customers will still accrue loyalty points. However, points will only be accrued for the portion of the transaction value that is paid with currency or, if permitted by the loyalty scheme, with gift certificates. The redeemed portion of the transaction value will not earn additional loyalty points. When loyalty points are redeemed, they will be deducted from the customer's "Available points" total. This ensures that the customer's remaining balance accurately reflects the redeemed points.

title: Step 1 - Create a New Stocktake (Partial)
text: Step 1: Select "Create New" to start the process. Step 2: Type in a meaningful description for the new stocktake. Step 3: From the stocktake type drop-down, select "Partial". Step 4: Select a shop from the shop drop-down. Step 5: A new section called "Add Partial Stocktake Selection" will appear. Here, you can choose what you wish to count. Partial Stocktake - Selection: Step 6: Use the drop-down to choose "Selection". Step 7: In the "Select Filter" box, click on the drop-down box to see the filter options. Step 8: A further selection panel will appear on the right for you to select from. The available options will vary depending on your original selection. Vendors: Select one or more Vendors from the list, or use the Select All button if you wish to select every vendor in the list. Click OK to make this selection Custom Attribute: Select a Custom Attributes from the list then use the data type field to narrow your search. Click OK to make this selection Item Group: Select one or more Item Group(s) from the list. You may need to expand the node names to reveal sub nodes. Click OK to make this selection Master Item: Search for the the Mast Item Number in the search bar, clicking the search button to perform the search. Where a matching Master item Number is found this will be added to the selection list. Alternatively use the Look Up... button to Add Items to Stock Take For example, if you selected "Vendor," you can choose one or more vendors from the available options. Step 9: Clicking "OK" will add your filtered selections to the "Partial Stocktake Selections" area. It is possible to add multiple filters by choosing filters again. Step 10: For example, you can filter "By Vendor only" or use multiple filters like "By Vendor and By Item Group." Step 11: Click "SAVE" to save all the partial selection choices. Step 12: Once you click "SAVE," wait a few moments, and you will be taken to the newly created Stocktake form. Step 13: From here, you can begin counting your stock. NOTE: The steps mentioned above guide you through the process of creating a new stocktake with partial selection, where you can choose specific criteria to count.

title: Step 2 - Count Add Items to Stocktake
text: Step 1: Find the stocktake you want to add a count to and open it by clicking on it. Make sure it is the correct partial stocktake by checking the selection filters shown on the screen. Step 2: Select "Count". Step 3: This opens a counting page where you can manually add items or choose to import a count from a file. For importing a file, refer to the separate section on File Import. Step 4: Enter the Physical Section you are currently counting. You can choose to add your counts in individual sections, which may reflect the way you break down the count with the shop. If you are importing, the sections may be determined by the import file. These individual count lists can be selected later and amended before completing the stocktake. Step 5: If you leave the Physical Section box blank, all counts will show under the header of "Default" in the Count drop-down list. Step 6: Enter the Barcode by scanning or manually typing it into the barcode box. When selected, a default quantity of 1 is added. Step 7: Alternatively, you can "Find Item Manually" by searching using text, vendor, or item groups. When selected, a default quantity of 1 is added. The "Total Number of Unique Barcodes" represents the number of entries in the stocktake. The "Total Counted Quantities" represents the total number of counted quantities. When "Negate Quantity" is set as "Yes," adding an item via the Enter Barcode option will deduct the quantity from the count. Step 8: If "Add Items Not Currently in Stocktake" is set as "No," only items in the selected filter can be added. If set as "Yes," items outside the selected filter can also be added to the stock list and counted. Find Item Manually: "Search Text" allows you to find an item based on a whole word or use an asterisk () before or after the word to search for all possibilities. For example, "can" for candles or "*proof" for waterproof. Use the drop-down "Vendor" list to select one or more vendors from the available options. Use the drop-down "Item Groups" list to select one or more item groups from the available options. Clicking "Search" starts the search process and displays all the results in the list below. Note: The steps mentioned above guide you through the process of adding items to a stocktake, either by manually entering information or searching for items using different filters.

title: Step 3 - Manual Count
text: Step 1: If counting by sections, enter a description in the physical section box. Step 2: Scan or key in a barcode or use the Find Item Manually option to alter count quantities. Quantities are increased by 1 after each scan, and the Last Scanned item box shows the most recently scanned item. Step 3: You can manually adjust the quantity here rather than in the Manual Count list before moving to the next item. Step 4: If adding directly from the item list, count quantities can be adjusted using the Plus and Minus buttons or directly by choosing the quantity field. The quantity is limited to a maximum value of 10 digits (e.g., 9999999999) and up to a maximum of 2 decimals (e.g., 99999999.99). The minimum value is 0. Step 5: Use the items by page [5 10 20 50] and the page number [7 of 11 (54 items)] to scroll through and find more items. Step 6: When all counts are added, choose the Back button to close the count page. All counts are automatically saved. Step 7: If you entered a description into the Physical section box, it would appear in the Count list. Step 8: Use the drop-down to see all counts. Count - Location 55X: This indicates a specific count for Location 55X. Step 9: You can add more individual counts by choosing Count again from the top right-hand side (Step 3) and adding a different physical description. Step 10: To amend a specific location, e.g., Location 55X, choose Count again from the top right-hand side (Step 3) and type in the same description again. It MUST be the same; otherwise, it will show under a new count location.

title: Step 4 - Calculate / Recount
text: Step 1: From the Count screen, choose Calculate. Step 2: Confirm by selecting Yes to start the calculation process. Step 3: Wait for the stocktake to display "Calculating." Please allow sufficient time for processing, especially for a full stock calculation. Avoid changing any stock quantities while the calculation is in progress. Once finished, it will change to "Calculated." Step 4: Click on a Calculated stocktake to see the results. Step 5: The header section shows a summary of the calculation, including Expected, Counted, and Variance for Quantity, Cost, and Price. The item list provides more detailed quantity figures. Step 6: Check the discrepancy report as needed. This column can be sorted from highest to lowest or vice versa to assist with finding discrepancies. Step 7: If amendments need to be made, choose Recount. Step 8: Confirm the recount by selecting Yes to proceed or No to cancel the recount request. Step 9: Recount takes you back to the counting section, allowing you to adjust quantities as required. When done, choose Calculate again (Step 4). Step 10: You can recount as many times as you wish until you are ready to Commit. Step 11: Check the discrepancy report as needed. This column can be sorted from highest to lowest or vice versa to assist with finding discrepancies. Discrepancies are the difference between the counted and expected figures. Step 12: By default, only lines with a discrepancy (where the Expected Quantity does not match the Counted Quantity) will show in the Stocktake Discrepancy list. To view all items, whether they have a discrepancy or not, slide the toggle off. Step 13: The Discrepancy list can be exported to Excel using the XLSX button.

title: Step 5 - Commit
text: Step 1: If all the discrepancies in the report are correct, choose Commit to accept the discrepancy report and update the stock figures. Step 2: Confirm the commitment by selecting Yes to proceed or No to cancel the Commit request. Step 3: The stocktake list will show "Committing" while making the final adjustments and then display "Closed" when completed. Step 4: You can view the closed stocktake again by clicking on it in the stocktake list.

title: Adding a New Customer
text: To begin click the Add New Customer button. A Create New Customer form will appear with various fields to fill in. Once you have filled in the information click Save. NOTE: If you click Back you will loose any information you have input. Field Descriptions (Fields with an * are required) First Name* This should be the Customers first name. Last Name* This should be the customers last name. Phone Number For more information see Settings in regard's to E.126 format. Mobile Phone Number This needs to be the mobile number of the customer. Email Must be a valid email address. Can be left blank. Birthdate Dates available run from 1/2/1900 through to today's date. You cannot set a birthdate for a future date. Language Use the drop down menu to select the relevant language. External Unique ID* This is the Customer Number you allocate, it is used on the POS and Receipts. Associated Company Imagine allows you to create company accounts, you can link the customer record to a company one. Date Created When the account was created. Last Visit When the customer last made a purchase in-store. Account Currency* The currency the customer keeps their account in, any transactions in another currency will be converted to this one.

title: Editing a Customer
text: If you want to modify the details of a customer, you can access their information by locating their name on the list and clicking on it. Alternatively, you can use the search bar to find the customer more quickly. Simply type in their name or relevant information, and the search results will display the relevant records. Once you have made any changes ensure you click Save to keep them. NOTE: If you press Back without saving you will loose any changes made.

title: Adding a Customer Address
text: To add a new address to the customer record switch to the Addresses tab and select Add New Address. This will open a New Address box with the following fields. Please ensure that you fill out the address section with at least the minimum required fields, as indicated by the red asterisk*. NOTE: You can add more than one address, and use the toggles at the bottom of the form to specify whether an address is the Primary Billing address and/or Primary Shipping address. After adding the address(es), click on the Save button located at the top right of the form. A success no will appear to confirm that the address(es) have been saved to the Customer.

title: Viewing Customer Transaction History
text: By navigating to the Transaction History tab, you will be able to access a Customer's transaction records for a specific time frame. This section enables you to view all transactions that took place within the given dates. Sales Statistics Field Descriptions Total Sales Value The total amount a customer has spent with your business. Total Discount Value The total amount of monetary value a customer has been given in discounts. Remaining Credit Voucher Amount Outstanding Credit Voucher balances the customer has still to redeem. Number of Visits The number of transactions recorded for this customer. This depends on the customer being selected at the POS when a transaction is being performed. Last Visit Date The most recent date this customer was recorded on a transaction in any of your shops. Receipts To search for a specific transaction or range of transactions, use the search function located on this page. If you want to locate an individual transaction, enter the Receipt Barcode, which resembles R0001-001-000001. You can find this code on the printed receipt or by utilizing the Find Receipt feature on the POS system. Alternatively, if you are unsure of the specific transaction, you can enter a range of dates for your search. Once you have entered the relevant information, click on the Load button to initiate the search. Any matching transactions will appear in the columns below.

title: Viewing Customer Account
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Account Details Loyalty Points Transaction History On the Account page, you can view a customers account information, which encompasses their account balance and credit limit, participation in any loyalty programs currently in place, and a transaction history. Account Details Balance Customers current balance, this is the difference between any deposits and charges to the account. Total Spent The total charges to the account since creation. Credit Limit The total amount that can be charged to the account before any deposits are required. Unbound Credit Limit The Customer may charge purchases to their account without limit. No. of Transactions Transactions on the account, this includes charges to the account and deposits, it doesn't include transactions paid for off account. Loyalty Points Currently Available The current points accrued on the account yet to be spent. Not Yet Available These are the accrued points that have yet to pass any quarantine period as set in the loyalty configuration. Total Used The total number of points used against purchases. Transaction History The Transaction History displays all activities related to the customer's account, including any transactions that could impact their balance or loyalty points if applicable. The data grid provides sorting and filtering functionalities. Sorting can be done by clicking on a column header, and an arrow will indicate the sort order (ascending or descending). Filtering can be done by entering text in the search box located under the column header. For example, to filter charges on an account, you can enter the keyword "charge" in the search box. By clicking on the magnifying glass icon, additional filter options become available. These options provide greater search flexibility and vary depending on the data type of the column. Finally, you have the choice to export the transaction history of the account to an Excel spreadsheet using the 'Export to Excel' button. Note: This feature will export the data as it appears. If you have filters applied, the exported data will also be filtered. Therefore, if you want all the data, make sure to remove the filters before exporting.

title: Start / Main Screen
text: Start Screen To initiate a transaction and access the main screen, the user has two options: they can either touch the screen directly or start scanning their items. To change the language, the user can simply touch the Flag icon located at the bottom centre of the screen. This action will reveal a list of optional languages. By touching the desired language, the user can make their selection. It's important to note that the start screen will always revert to the default language once the transaction is completed. To optimize efficiency, the screen automatically returns to the start screen if it remains inactive for a specified period. The duration of this idle timeout is determined by the Idle Timeout Settings in the Configuration. Idle Timeout If no action is taken within a specified timeframe, the SCO application will issue a warning indicating that the basket will be emptied and the user will be redirected to the start screen in another x seconds. It's important to keep in mind that while using the SCO, an "idle" timer constantly operates in the background, monitoring the user's activity and ensuring the system remains responsive. Main Screen The main screen of the SCO serves as the primary interface for user input before making a payment. It accommodates various input methods, including keyboard input such as a Keyboard Wedge Scanner. Upon scanning an item or manually searching for an item, the touch function is temporarily disabled until the item is successfully added to the transaction. This prevents any accidental inputs or disruptions during the process. To provide visual feedback and indicate the ongoing addition of an item to the transaction, a loading symbol will be displayed in the "My Items" section on the screen. This assures the user that the system is actively processing the request. Language Details Pressing the flag icon will give you a range of other languages to select from. Help! Pressing this will activate help mode if configured. It will notify the SCO Companion and also activate the TRI-Light for attention. My Items Details This area displays the item image, name and description as the items are scanned. My Items This section displays the list of items you have scanned and need to pay for. The example above illustrates a "non-flattened" list, which can be customized. Alternatively, you can choose a flattened list format, where each item is displayed in a single row without showing the quantity. Look Up Items This will show you the tiles which are configured as the Landing Group in the Visual Composer. See separate section. Press To Pay This button will advance you to the next stages of the process

title: Looking up Items
text: Please note that while the SCO application does not offer complete support for Composer Groups, it does provide accessibility by flattening the groups into individual items. This allows users to access and interact with the grouped items as if they were single entities. If you have enabled the item details configuration, the SCO application will provide additional information about each item before you proceed to add it to the basket. This allows you to review the details and make an informed decision before confirming the item selection. When attempting to add an item from the lookup screen, the SCO application will prompt you to specify the quantity of the item you are adding. This ensures accurate tracking and proper inclusion of the desired quantity in the transaction.

title: Supervisory Functions
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Supervisor Interventions Item not Found Restricted Item Help Supervisor functions are essential for proceeding at this stage as without introducing it and explaining what it does, you will be unable to complete a transaction. To access Supervisor functions, simply scan any barcode which has been printed which begins with the same Clerk prefix which you have previously set up in Configuration. This will take you into the Supervisor functions screen. You can generate such barcodes with any common barcode generator and print them on whichever printer you like. For example, https://www.barcodesinc.com/generator/index.php Return Will return you back to the Main Screen with no further action Enter Full screen Puts the SCO in Full screen Mode (Does not work if the SCO is in Chrome's Kiosk mode as the browser overrides the behaviour) Exit Full screen Takes the SCO out of Full screen Mode (Does not work if the SCO is in Chrome's Kiosk mode as the browser overrides the behaviour) Print Last Receipt Will reprint the last receipt sent to the connector, in case there was a failure. Payment Device Allows you to choose the connector the SCO is using. These get configured in Admin. Disable Payments If this is deselected, then it will simulate payments and approve all transactions. This is not to be used in Live mode. Basket Here, you can alter the quantities for each line. Use the + and - buttons to adjust the quantity as needed. Useful if the shopper has scanned too many of an item and wants to reduce the quantity, or the item has been accidentally scanned and needs to be removed from the transaction. To remove an item reduce its quantity to 0 (zero) and the item will automatically be removed from the basket. Cancel Transaction This will void the transaction and return the SCO to the start screen. Supervisor Interventions There are some other scenarios where the supervisor will be required to scan their supervisor barcode. In these scenarios, if configured, the SCO Companion and/or Tri Light will be alerted also that action is required to be taken. Item not Found In the event a barcode is scanned but not recognised, it blocks the transaction proceeding. This is in order to not allow the customer to put it in their bag without realizing, and also so a colleague can note and identify why it would not scan. Restricted Item When a shopper tries to buy Age Restricted or Qty Restricted items then the TriLight (if configured) will turn orange indicating that attention will be required. Also at this point the SCO Companion will also turn Orange for the SCO and allow them to remotely approve. This allows the shopper to keep shopping and only be approved once at the end of the transaction. NOTE: Age Restricted or Quantity restricted items and are configured in Product Configure. Scan the supervisor barcode and then you will be asked to Approve Help Pressing the Help! button will alert the clerk and then the TriLight (if configured) will turn orange indicating that attention will be required.

title: Payments & Receipts
text: By pressing the "Press To Pay" button, you will initiate the payment process within the SCO application. Before finalizing the payment, the system may prompt you (if configured) to indicate the number of bags you have used or purchased during the transaction. This allows for the inclusion of the bag count in the overall transaction. Unless payment functionality has been disabled for demonstration purposes, the SCO application will initiate the Connector to communicate with the Pin Entry Device (PED) and proceed with the payment. At this stage, the SCO relinquishes control and awaits further input. During this processing period, you will observe the following screen indicating the ongoing payment transaction. During this screen, the idle timeout feature is overridden and instead relies on the configurable timeout set specifically for the Pin Entry Device (PED). This timeout duration may vary depending on the payment provider and their respective settings. Upon successful payment, it indicates that the transaction has been completed, and the necessary information has been submitted to Imagine's backend for further processing. If you have configured receipt printing as an optional feature, you will be prompted to choose whether you want to print a receipt or not. This allows for customization based on individual preferences or business requirements.

title: Headless POS
text: This application is specifically designed to facilitate customer service using a Headless POS system. In addition to supporting cash and card payments, the Headless POS also includes functionalities for discounts and refunds. Here are some key points to note: - The Headless POS utilizes the Currency and Language settings configured in the Backoffice. These settings determine the default locale of the Headless POS, including formatting conventions for numbers and currencies (such as decimal or comma separators, and whether the currency symbol appears before or after the value). - The application will display the logo associated with the shop, which is obtained from the Backoffice's Shop Logo setting. - For live implementations, the use of a Pin Entry Device is required to process card payments. This necessitates having a K3 Connector, a compatible printer, a supported Payment Terminal, and a Payment Service Provider. However, for demonstration and testing purposes without a Connector, a Virtual payment option is available. - It's important to note that this application is designed to run on dedicated kiosk hardware without keyboard input. To prevent unintended actions, it is recommended to utilize Google Chrome's Kiosk mode, which helps prevent users from holding down the touch screen for extended periods and simulating a right-click action.

title: Start Screen
text: From the Start Screen of the application, users have the ability to temporarily change the language by selecting the dropdown menu located in the right-hand corner. They can then choose the desired language from the options provided. However, it's important to note that the language selection will revert to the default language after each transaction is completed. To set up languages, navigate to the Self Serve Admin section and select the desired shop. Under the languages tab, you can add and configure various languages according to your requirements. The image displayed on the Start Screen is customizable through the Visual Profiles of the Visual Composer. Simply access the Assets tab to configure and upload the desired image. Please keep in mind that if the application remains unused for a certain period, the Hpos (Headless POS) will automatically return to the Start Screen. The duration of this idle timeout is determined by the Idle Timeout Settings in the Configuration.

title: Looking Up Items
text: TOC TO BE ADDED ONCE COMPLETED Composer View The Composer View is the main screen used within the application. The clerk uses this screen to select which items the customer is ordering. The screen will always display the Landing Group for the selected store as the starting point for navigation. The Hierarchy and navigation can be expanded and customised further using the Composer Groups and Visual Composer Modules. You can choose to drill into the subgroups (Blue tiles) to see another layer of the hierarchy, or you can use the +/- buttons to add your items to the basket. If you press the + on an item which is a Bundle or has Modifiers, you will be asked to make your selections before adding to the basket. IMAGE REQUIRED On-screen navigation - If you have Bundle Groups set up, you will see navigation buttons appear when in those groups. For example Home > Drinks > Pepsi / Sprite / Coke. you can use this to return to the Home Screen or a section by selecting the POS. ICON REQUIRED Tile Button The The tile button if pressed will return you to your home group from wherever you are in the application. ICON REQUIRED Supervisor Functions This button will ask you for a PIN code to enter supervisor functions. ICON REQUIRED Product Information Any tile with the I symbol means there is some more information you might want to see for an item. It also indicates that there may be Bundle Groups or Modifiers for the item when selected. ICON REQUIRED Basket Button The basket button shows you how many items you have in your basket. You can press the button to view the basket, which you have to do to proceed to Payment. Items, Bundles and Modifiers When you add a Bundle or Modifiable item to your basket, you will be prompted to make the relevant selections before adding them to the basket. If your Bundle main item has Modifiers linked to it, it will automatically take you to the Modifiers tab if you wish to make any alterations. IMAGE REQUIRED Non-bundled items with Modifiers will only show you the Modifiers. The min-max rule for selections is displayed next to the Modifier title, You will also see any additional prices for the modifiers. Modifications that you make get printed on the order confirmation slip and also make their way through to the Order Status Display to be used in the order preparation area. IMAGE REQUIRED Basket The Basket screen is a listing of all of your items, along with any bundle selections and modifiers you have made. They are grouped, so if you have made more than one item with the same selections and modifiers they will be on the same basket line. It denotes the extended price of the basket line and also displays the quantity multiplied by the single item price. IMAGE REQUIRED ICON REQUIRED Edit Line You can use the pencil icon for the basket line to make alterations to that line (change modifiers or bundle selections). ICON REQUIRED Delete Line Use the trash can icon to remove the line from the basket. ICON REQUIRED Delete Basket Use the black trash can next to the Pay button to clear the basket and return to the start screen.

title: Supervisory Functions
text: To access the Supervisor Functions, follow these steps: 1. Locate the settings cog icon in the top right-hand corner of the POS screen. 2. Click on the cog icon, and you will be prompted to enter a supervisor PIN. Supervisor permissions are set up in the Configuration. NEW IMAGE REQUIRED Here are the available Supervisor Functions: - Previous Receipt: This option allows you to view the previous receipt and provides the choice to either email it or print it. - Full Screen: Clicking this button will toggle the full-screen mode on or off. Please note that this function may not work with Chrome due to specific browser settings. - Choose Payment Provider: This function lists all the payment providers that you have set up in the Admin section. If you don't have a payment provider or if you are performing a demo or test, you can select the "Virtual" option. The Virtual payment bypasses the actual payment process and assumes a full payment has been made. However, please note that the Virtual option should not be used in a live environment. - Refund Mode: Selecting this option allows you to enter Refund Mode, where the entire transaction is treated as a refund. - Logout: Clicking this button will empty the basket and return you to the login screen. Please ensure that you have the necessary supervisor permissions and use these functions responsibly and by your operational requirements.

title: Payments & Receipts
text: Payment At the bottom of the Basket screen, you will have your payment options. You can choose your payment method to use and you can split your payment types in use as well. NEW IMAGE REQUIRED A Card payment type will initiate communications with the Connector that has been configured to use for a real EFT payment. A Cash payment will also utilise the connector in order to pop the cash drawer. A Manual Card payment does not use an integrated card terminal and is designed for use with stand-alone chip and pin. it only requires the connector for receipt printing. If the payment fails, you will be advised and after 5 seconds it will return you the basket to try another card. You should refer to the PED for details on why the transaction was declined, as each provider is different, so we only display a failure. NOTE: You will also see a failure if the Simple POS is unable to communicate with the Connector. NEW IMAGE REQUIRED If the payment is successful, the transaction will be submitted into Imagine's back-end for onward processing. It will now. Submit the order to the Order Status Display. Return you an order number which is displayed on screen and used in the OSD and ORB. Print an order confirmation slip including the order number and any bundle selections and modifiers which are applied. Show you the estimated waiting time, which it calculates based upon the last 15 minutes order throughput. Before returning the user back to the start screen. NEW IMAGE REQUIRED Refund Mode Refund mode is available in the Supervisor Functions. When you are in Refund mode, the entire transaction is classified as a refund. There is no ability to perform an exchange. When you are in refund mode it is very clear in order to ensure you do not make a mistake. NEW IMAGE REQUIRED Discount After registering an item against the POS there are options available to discount them. These options will be detailed below. NEW IMAGE REQUIRED NEW ICON Clicking one of these will set the percentage discount against the item(s) in the basket. NEW ICON Clicking onto ‘Custom Discount’ brings up a dialogue allowing the users to choose to discount by a percentage or a set amount. NEW IMAGE REQUIRED Once the discount has been entered press ‘Apply Discount’. This will then set the amount or percentage against the product in the basket. NEW IMAGE REQUIRED

title: Hiearchy
text: Each item must be assigned a Hierarchy. [Often referred to as Departments or Categories]. Select an existing one or create a new one. Select a Hierarchy from the available list. The Root Node [Top Level] Hierarchy is shown first. Use the side arrow [1] to show the Sub Node options [Categories]. [2] Once selected, Next to move to the next step. [5] If the Hierarchy is not available, you can create a new Root Node using the Create a New Root Node option. [3] or a Sub Node using the Plus Sign to the right of the Root Node. [4]. See Item Hierarchies for further details if required.

title: Details
text: This is where you add all the main information about the item you are creating. Complete each field as required, then Next to move to the next step. NOTE: If creating an item with variants, some variants may have slightly different information, however, enter the most common value, then change as required in Step 6 – Variants. e.g., Vendor Item Number per colour, variant item number, and price per size. NOTE: (*) Indicates a Mandatory field. Name* This is the Master Item Name. Used by the Item List and parts of Imagine where the items are listed at the Master Item level instead of variant level [Colour and Size]. Master Item Number The number or code by which the master item will be known or referenced. It will appear in most lists and reports where the master item is listed. NOTE: If left blank, it will automatically generate one for you. Manufacturer Item Number If required, the Manufacturer number or code by which the master item will be known or referenced. Vendor Item Number If required the Vendor number or code by which the master item will be known or referenced. Description This field is an extended description of the Name field and is commonly used to hold more descriptive information about a product. It can include material type, weight, size, artist information, design notes, etc. Type* Stocked: This is where there is physical stock to count and manage. Non-Stock: This is where there is no stock to count or manage, such as postage, service, or repair fees. Serialized: This is when you want to keep individual instances of a particular item when they are received, transferred, sold, or returned. This helps with keeping track of item warranties and high-value goods. NOTE: For this option, it will need to be activated via the Portal>Configuration>Tenant Tab. Vendor* This is who supplies the item, sometimes referred to as the Supplier. Select an existing Vendor from the list. If no Vendor exists, use the Manage Vendors button to create a new Vendor. NOTE: Only the Vendor Name and Vendor Code are created. All other Vendor details should be added in the Back-Office – Vendors section. Sales UOM Code UOM is a Unit of Measure by which an item is sold. This could be weight, length, pack size, or something else. Currently, this field is for reference purposes only. Tax Rate This is the Tax Rate to be applied when the item is sold. If there are multiple Tax Groups, select a Tax Rate from each as required. Only 1 tax rate can be chosen from each group. Default Label Template This is the label format which will be used for label printing unless an alternative format is selected at the time of printing. For more information, see Label Templates. Restock Level This is the maximum amount of stock to hold for the variant item. Currently, this field is for reference purposes only. Reorder Point This is the lowest amount of stock to be held for an item. It indicates when an item requires ordering again. Reorder Number If required the Reorder number or code by which the master item will be known or referenced. POS Block Discount When set to YES, the item is blocked from being discounted at the POS. The default setting is NO – Item can be discounted. POS Prompt for Price When set to YES, a prompt appears at the POS asking the user to enter a price. The default setting is NO – The item is not prompted for a price. POS Block Quantity Entry When set to YES, the user cannot change the quantity of the item being sold. The default setting is NO – A quantity can be set against the item.

title: Local Prices
text: Here you enter the cost and selling price of the item, Cost Price The cost price of the item. The cost of an item can be altered at a later stage, either directly or by receiving in goods. At each transaction, the current cost of the item is recorded as it is sold or returned. This ensures an accurate profit margin can be maintained. Costs are recorded by shop in case of regional differences in tax or shipping cost. Retail Price The retail price of the item. Estimated Margins Displays each Tax Rate and Estimated Margin. Exchange Rate Price If you have shops with different currencies, then Imagine will automatically calculate the price for these based on the current exchange rate. You can override these by unticking the exchange rate price and manually entering the price in the entered Sales Price.

title: Attributes
text: Here you enter the Required and Optional Custom attributes are shown based on your Custom Attribute. Required Attributes (*) - Enter the information against all required attributes. Optional Attributes - Use the select drop-down menu to select an optional Attribute. To remove any optional Attributes click the bin icon to delete. To create a new attribute click on 'Create an Attribute' this will then give you a pop-up. Fill in the information required and press save. NOTE: Depending if this item needs to be Required or Optional tick the box. OFF - This item will be Optional and you can select it in the drop-down menu. ON - This item will be required and will be shown in the Required Attributes list.

title: Dimensions
text: This is where you choose if an item has variants. [Colour, Size, Fit, Width] or just a standard item. For Standard items leave the Number of Dimensions set as 0 and move to the next step. For Variant items Choose Number of Dimensions: Move the slider to the required number of Dimensions the maximum you can choose is 10. NOTE: Whilst there are no strict rules on Dimensions, it is recommended to be consistent where Dimension 1 is the Colour, Dimension 2 is the Size, Dimension 3 is the width/fit etc. A dimension panel will appear for however many you have selected. Here you can set up the Dimension from a pre-defined template or setup using the custom option. If you already have Pre-Defined Templates you can use the Drop down to select a Template and Dimension values which have already been created into groups of colours, sizes, widths or other values. Dimension values can be reordered by clicking on the group of 6 dots and dragging up and down the list. Dimension values can be removed by unticking the selection [2]. Dimension values can be added by choosing the PLUS option [3]. Just key in a new value when prompted. Custom - Custom Dimensions are not saved, they are only to create the current item. Enter a relevant Dimension name. Use the option to key in a new value when prompted. Dimension values can be reordered by clicking on the group of 6 dots and dragging up and down the list. Dimension values can be removed by unticking the selection. Repeat for All Dimensions required then Next to move to the next step. Completed example of 2 Dimensions using Colour [as a Custom selection] and Size [as a template selection].

title: Variants
text: A list of variants is shown based on the selections from the previous steps. Here you can check and change the details of each variant before they are saved. Each variant may have specific requirements, such as a custom item number or a manufacturer's barcode. Additionally, different colour variants might have distinct manufacturer or vendor numbers. There could also be varying prices for certain sizes, and the extended description may differ between different colour variants. To modify any of the fields displayed on the screen, simply click on the relevant field and make the necessary changes. Click on the Edit Pencil icon for each variant to access additional editable fields [2]. Variant Item Number - If left empty, Imagine will automatically assign a number to each variant. Barcodes - If left empty, Imagine will automatically generate an internal barcode for each variant. Save - Remember to select Save on this page to preserve any changes made to individual variants. Fields indicated by the pencil symbol can be modified. Clicking on it will open a new window, allowing you to review and edit any previously entered information. SAVE - Finally clicking Save will create your new item and on successfully creating a green prompt confirming “Item was created successfully” will appear before returning to step 1 of the wizard. It will take a few moments for your item to be created. Once completed the below notification will show.

title: Export Customers
text: The "Export Customers" feature enables you to export customer account data to an Excel spreadsheet format. This allows for convenient storage and analysis of customer information. Furthermore, you have the option to filter the list of customers based on specific fields within the table. This filtering capability allows you to refine the exported data and focus on particular subsets of customers based on your requirements. External Unique ID: The customer number used in the POS system. First Name: The customer's first name. Last Name: The customer's last name. Email: The customer's email address. Mobile Phone Number: The customer's mobile phone number. Phone Number: The customer's phone number. Associated Company (if applicable): The company associated with the customer, if applicable. Primary Billing Address: The customer's primary billing address. Primary Shipping Address: The customer's primary shipping address. Birthdate: The customer's birthdate. Language: The language preference of the customer. Currency: The currency preference of the customer. Credit Limit: The maximum amount that can be charged to the customer's account. Total Spent: A running total of all charges made to the customer's account (excluding off-account transactions). No. of Visits: The number of times a transaction has been completed with the customer's account linked via the customer widget. Loyalty Points: Currently Available: Loyalty points earned and available to spend. Not Yet Available: Loyalty points earned but not passed any qualifying period set in Loyalty Configuration. Total Used: Loyalty points that have been spent. Loyalty Points Currently Available (Converted): Points value converted to the customer account currency. Date Created: The date when the customer account was set up. Last Visit: The most recent time when the customer account was linked to a transaction.

title: Groups
text: Within Imagine, customers can be assigned to different customer groups. These customer groups serve as a means to categorize customers based on specific criteria. These customer groups can also be associated with promotional or discount offers within the Price and Promotion Engine (PPE) module. By linking customer groups to promotional offers, you can ensure that the discounts or promotions are automatically applied when qualifying items are added to a transaction. To trigger the promotional offers at the point of sale (POS), make sure to include a qualifying customer by utilizing the Find Customer widget. This will enable the system to identify the customer and automatically apply any relevant promotional offers associated with their assigned customer group. Creating a Customer Group To make a new customer group, click ‘CREATE NEW’. Enter an appropriate ‘Name’ for the customer group, then click ‘SAVE’. The group ‘ID’ will be assigned automatically and cannot be edited. Assign / Unassigned Group Members. Once the group is saved, group members can be assigned. In the ‘Unassigned’ search bar, enter either the first or last name of a customer. The list of matched results will be displayed below. Using the checkboxes, select the customers from the list. The checkbox in the column header next to ‘First Name’ will select all customers in the search results list. Click the blue button pointing to the ‘Assigned’ list. All selected customers will be moved to the ‘Assigned’ list. To remove a customer from a group, use the ‘Assigned’ search bar to locate the customer in the list. Use the checkbox to select the customer, then click the Red button pointing to the ‘Unassigned’ list. This will move the customer record from the ‘Assigned’ list to ‘Unassigned’. Click ‘SAVE’ in the top right corner of the page to save any changes to the customer group. Edit an Existing Group From the Customer Group list, select a group to be edited. Amend the following details as required: Group Name Group Members Click ‘SAVE’ in the top right corner of the page to save any changes to the customer group. To delete the group, use the ‘DELETE THIS GROUP’ button, then click on the orange confirmation message.

title: Settings
text: To enable international E.164 phone number validation, follow these guidelines: When the feature is enabled: Phone numbers entered at the point of sale (POS) or in the Customer section must adhere to the E.164 standard. The phone number should start with a "+" symbol. The country code should consist of 1 to 3 digits. The subscriber number can have a maximum of 12 digits. Spaces are not allowed in the phone number. In the POS, the "+" symbol will be automatically added after the number is entered. When the feature is not enabled: The Phone Number field becomes a free-text field. The maximum character limit for the field is 20 characters. Enabling international E.164 phone number validation ensures that phone numbers follow the standard format and simplifies the validation process.

title: Creating a New Promotion
text: To create a new Promotion click "Create new". A page will appear, complete this with the relevant information. Promotion Settings Name The name for this promotion. This will appear on the receipt for your customers. Promotion Code An internal code you can use to assist with promotions in reports. Promotion Trigger Barcode This is an option to create a barcode to scan at the POS to activate a specific Promotion. Within Global Settings, you can set a prefix. Priority Priority of which promotion is given to a product. If you chose a priority already in use then other promotions will be pushed down the priority list in preference to this promotion. Item Bundles The filter of products that go into the promotion. See Item Bundles for more details. Shops Select which Shop(s) the promotion applies to. By default, all shops are included. Customer Groups Select which Customer Groups the promotion applies to. By default, all customer groups are included. Timing Settings Name The name for this promotion. This will appear on the receipt for your customers. Promotion Code An internal code you can use to assist with promotions in reports. Promotion Trigger Barcode This is an option to create a barcode to scan at the POS to activate a specific Promotion. Within Global Settings, you can set a prefix. Priority Priority of which promotion is given to a product. If you chose a priority already in use then other promotions will be pushed down the priority list in preference to this promotion. Item Bundles The filter of products that go into the promotion. See Item Bundles for more details. Shops Select which Shop(s) the promotion applies to. By default, all shops are included. Customer Groups Select which Customer Groups the promotion applies to. By default, all customer groups are included. Start Date The date the promotion is active. This date is inclusive. End Date The date the promotion is made inactive. The end date is included as part of the date range. Week Days Select specific days of the week the promotion is active. Time Of Day All Day - The promotion applies all day / Custom - Select a Start At and End At the time for the promotion. You can select from the drop-down or enter your own time as HH: mm Calculation Settings Promotion Engine - The promotion type that is to be given to this promotion. Adding a rule under Calculation Settings allows you to choose a type of discount/promotion with the Promotion Engine. Each promotion type has its settings see Promotion Engine Settings for more information.

title: Adding a New Connector
text: The PoS Admin - K3 Connector Manager menu should be used in preference to this menu, Admin will be removed in future releases and will not be accessible. Please follow the instructions below to add and configure a new connector for your store: 1. Adding a New Connector: - Click on the "ADD DEVICE" button for your store. - Note: You can add multiple connectors simultaneously if needed. 2. Connector Setup Time: - After adding and configuring a new connector, the process may take up to 10 minutes to complete. - You will receive a startup notification printout once it's finished. 3. Checking Existing Connectors: - If you don't see any connectors listed, it means there are currently none set up for this location. 4. Saving Connector Options: - Once you have entered the necessary information for the new connector, click on the "Save" button to save your selections. 5. Connector Details: - Connector Name: Enter a descriptive name for the connector or device (e.g., Front Till 01). - Connector ID: This ID is printed on the startup slip when the connector is first booted. For more information, refer to the documentation on "Assembling the Connector." - The ID should consist of exactly 6 groups of 2 numerals or letters (0 to 9, A to F), with each pair separated by a hyphen (-). 6. Connector Configuration: - Connector Terminal: Select the type of integrated card terminal being used. If there is no integrated card unit present, choose the "No payment service provider" option. - Most integrations require the IP address and port number for the terminal. - Connector Printer: Choose the appropriate option for your receipt printer, either 'DdD' (K3 Receipt Printer) or 'Epson'. These options determine specific paper sizes and receipt logo printing settings. 7. Marking for Deletion: - If you wish to remove a connector from this store, set the "Mark for deletion" option to 'On'. The related connector will be deleted when you click on "Save". 8. Virtual Connector: - The "Virtual Connector" option is currently reserved for future use and is not applicable at this time.

title: Verifone Configuration
text: The PoS Admin - K3 Connector Manager menu should be used in preference to this menu, Admin will be removed in future releases and will not be accessible. Here are the specific configurations for Verifone terminals: Terminal IP Address: Please refer to the information provided either on the terminal itself or by Verifone. User ID: Enter the User ID associated with your Verifone device. PIN: Enter the PIN for your Verifone device. Merchant Account ID: Enter the Merchant Account ID specific to your Verifone device. Manager PIN: Enter the Manager PIN for your Verifone device. Checkboxes: Enable each option based on the installation advice provided for your terminal or as advised by Verifone. Please make sure to input the correct information according to your Verifone terminal's specifications and any instructions given by Verifone.

title: Updating / Rebooting the Connector
text: The PoS Admin - K3 Connector Manager menu should be used in preference to this menu, Admin will be removed in future releases and will not be accessible. If your Connector needs to be rebooted or updated but is installed in an inaccessible location, you can perform a reboot using the POS Screen. Follow the steps below: 1. Accessing the Connector Reboot Option: - Locate the Connector symbol in the top right menu of the POS Screen. - The available Connectors will be displayed below. 2. Initiating the Reboot: - Click on the symbol to proceed with the reboot. - A pop-up window will appear, asking you to confirm the reboot. 3. Confirming the Reboot: - Click on the confirmation button to proceed with the reboot process. 4. Reboot Confirmation Message: - Once the reboot is initiated, you will receive the following message: "Your Connector will now be rebooted." 5. Note about Re-adding the Connector: - Important: After the reboot, there is no need to re-add the Connector via the back office module. The rebooted Connector will automatically reconnect and resume its functionality. If you have any further questions or encounter any issues, please refer to the provided documentation or contact our support team for assistance.

title: Discount Label Page
text: Discount Labels can be found within the Inventory Module. A Discount Label is a barcode which is scanned at the POS and has an altered price. There are 2 types of Discount Labels. Percentage - Applies a discount against the item to reduce the selling price by a set %. Value – Overwrites the selling price of an item to the amount on the Discount Label. IMPORTANT: It does not reduce the selling price by the amount. To be able to print Discount Labels, you will need to have the following setup and available. A Barcode Printer connected to a valid Connector. A Label Template created for discount by % or discount by amount (Formatted to the size of label used by the barcode printer) If the Label Template is not correct or not available, please contact your system administrator or your local support team for more details. Using a Discount Label at POS. Scan or add the item onto the POS screen. Whilst the item is highlighted or in focus, Scan the Discount Label Barcode. If you have Discount Reasons setup, choose one from the left-hand menu. The price is then altered depending on the type of the Discount Label scanned. Either as a Percentage discount or the value of the item is overwritten. Discount Label – Percentage 25% Discount Label – Value £6.99

title: Discount Label - Percentage
text: Printer Select the connector which has the Barcode printer attached. Template Select a pre-created template made in Label Templates. Text This is where you can add some extra information to the label. E.g., a promotional name or a description of the discount. Quantity How many labels are to be printed. Form Type This must be set as Percentage. If set as Value, the percentage figure will be printed as zero regardless of what value the percentage box says. Percentage The percentage value of discount required. Print Will set the printer to printing the labels as required. Printed Label Example with % Discount

title: Discount Label - Value
text: Printer Select the Connector which has the Barcode printer attached. Template Select a pre-created template made in Label Templates. Text This is where you can add some extra information to the label. E.g., a promotional name or a description of the discount. Quantity How How many labels are to be printed? Type This must be set as Value. If set as Percentage, the Amount [Value] figure will be printed as zero regardless of what amount the value box says. Value The amount [value] required. Print Will set the printer to print the labels as required.

title: Sales Dashboard
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Data Filters Key Performance Figures Data Performance Table The Dashboard has been broken down into 3 sections. Data Filters NOTE: If a field is left blank this will automatically choose all options available. NOTE: The search will only return up to the number of lines of data as configured in Analysis Configuration. If your search exceeds the limit a notification will display. From Date Pick a Start Date. To Date Pick an end Date. Shops Choose from your set list of shops. Vendor Select specific or all vendors available. Shop Group Choose a group of selected shops. Company This can be used if a Tenant has multiple companies within Imagine. Hierarchy This is to narrow down a category as required by only one level. Clerks Use to narrow down to a specific Clerk member or all Clerks available. Customer Select a specific customer or a collection of specific customers. Type Choose between Sale or Return. Receipt Use the saved receipt number to narrow it down to a particular sale/return. NOTE: All other filters will be ignored when using the Receipt Number filter Group by Columns Used to group data into summary rows based on the number of columns you pick. For example if you pick 1,2 then, after you press Submit, the data will be grouped by the left most column and then by the second left column and you will see one row for each combination.
