This can be beneficial where you are planning on viewing large data sets and wish to see summary information initially. To see detailed grouping you should use the 'Drag column header' feature explained in Grouping Categories. NOTE: When pressing Submit you may receive a warning about invalid group column, you should adjust the left most columns to valid entries. Saves Reports, this will also save the format you have configured. Resets the filters to default values This will fetch the data *if available. To review past saved reports. See My Analysis for more details. Key Performance Figures These are static boxes of overall information from the data shown in the Data Performance Table. SalesSales Ex TaxTaxQtyCostDiscountProfit Overall figure for sales within the table. The overall figure for Sales Excluding Tax Total Tax figure from the data in the table overall. Overall Quantity of items generated within the data. Overall costing of outgoings that are not sales through the till (e.g., postage) Overall discount applied across all sales. Overall Profit figure Data Performance Table The table shows the data of which information you have selected from the fields above, you can modify the way the information is displayed. Search Use the Search Bar to find data in the table below Show Local Currency Columns Allows local currency columns to show in the Column Chooser. Local currency columns will be denoted by a * such as Tax* Export All Data This will export the data to a .xlxs file for use. There is no option to print directly from this page. Column Chooser This will bring up a list of options to add or remove columns. Reset Grid Filters Resets any filters applied to the Data table

title: Grouping Catagories
text: To group data in the Sales Data Performance Table, follow these steps: Click and hold the header you want to group by (e.g., "Shop"), and drag it into place. If you want to remove a column header from the grouping, perform the reverse action by dragging it from its position and dropping it back into the table where you want the header to be placed. Notes The table will automatically update as you add, remove and alter positions of the headers. Headers placed furthest to the left will automatically be the major grouping, whilst headers further to the right will be subsequently more minor groupings. The example below explains this in more detail. Columns that display variable digital denominations, large blocks of text and other limitations cannot be grouped. You will not be able to drop these headers in the 'drag and drop' area. In Sales examples of the headers that cannot be grouped are: Cost Sales Qty Tax Profit Example of grouping with a single column: Once you group the data, the Data Performance Table will display the information in a different format, showing the groups. In this case, it will be grouped by "Shops." You can use the arrow next to each shop's name to expand and view more detailed information. Example of grouping with multiple columns: If you choose multiple headers to group by, you will have a stack of groups. For example, you may have "Shops" as the major header, and within each shop, you can further group by "Date". To change the hierarchy of the data, arrange the groups in the desired order. The data will stack based on the order of the groups you arrange with major priority to the left, moving to minor priority as you move to the right.

title: Saving a Report
text: When saving a report, please keep the following points in mind: Saving a report does not save the data itself; it only saves the formatting and configuration of the report. To save your created report, click on the "Save This Report" button. A pop-up window will appear. In the pop-up window, you can provide a name for your report. It is recommended to choose a descriptive name for easy future reference. There is an option for setting the report's visibility or permissions: "No One": Only you will be able to see this report. "My Role": Other members with the same role as you will have access to this report. "Everybody": Anyone with access to reporting will be able to see this report. Click the save button within the pop-up to save the report along with the chosen settings. After saving, you will receive an on-screen notification confirming that the report has been successfully saved. NOTE: You can save multiple versions of the same report with the same name. They will not replace or stack on top of each other. Each saved report will be distinct and separate.

title: Recalling a Saved Report
text: To view a previously saved report, follow these steps: 1. Click on the "Show Saved Reports" button. 2. A pop-up window will appear on the page, presenting a list of saved reports. Select the report you want to open. 3. After selecting the report, click the "Submit" button to retrieve the associated data. 4. Saved reports are categorized based on the share option chosen when saving. The available categories are: "Saved Reports": This category displays reports saved under any of the three share options. "Shared Reports": This category shows reports saved with the "Everybody" or "My Role" share options. In the pop-up window, you will find the following information for each saved report: Description: The name given to the report at the time of saving. Share Type: The chosen share option when saving the report. Created: The date when the report was initially saved. Modified: The date when any changes were last made to the saved file. Type of Report: Indicates the type of report that was saved, such as Sales or Customer. Additionally, you have the following options for each saved report: Edit: Allows you to edit the report's name and share type. Delete Deletes the report. A confirmation message will appear asking you to confirm deletion with options to choose "Yes" or "No."

title: Item Price
text: The PPE needs to have items pushed to it from your PoS, back office, ERP or another source. If an item is marked as ‘POS Block Discount’ in Inventory > Item List then the item will not be included here. Use the search box by entering the variant items name to find items in order to set the price for. Also narrow the search by Item Hierarchy and Vendor filters. It will return the list of matching items. To see all the prices for the item use the small drop-down arrow to the top left. You will see all prices for all variants associated with the item. From here you can update, delete, or add a new price. To edit the current price click the type in the new price and press enter. To add a new Variant Price click a popup will appear. Fill in the details for the price you are adding and click Add to complete. The new Variant will now be shown when you use the drop-down arrow. To remove the Variant Price use the to delete.

title: Item Bundles
text: Item Bundles allow you to create specific promotional bundles This allows you to create bundles of items that you want to put on a specific promotion. To edit an existing bundle use the Edit icon. To remove existing bundles use the bin icon. To create a new Bundle use the Create New button You have the option to add items based upon filters. Name Filter Vendor Filter Custom Attribute Filter Barcode Filter Hierarchy Filter Master Item Number Filter NOTE: If an item has been marked as ‘POS Block Discount’ in Inventory > Item List then the item will not be included when the bundle is created. Once the bundle has been created press "Save" to complete. The bundle will now show In Queue, this is while it gathers the items. Once the bundle has been created and all items gathered it will now say succeeded within the table.

title: Global Settings
text: Global settings are where you can set up environmental PPE settings. Here you enter a prefix for your promotion trigger barcode when creating a new or editing an existing promotion.

title: Purchase Order List
text: Within Purchase orders, the Shops list shows all active shops. You must select a shop before the Search button is available. Vendor and/or Status optional fields can be set to narrow down the search. Statuses Draft - A PO that has been saved but not Placed. Placed - When a PO is ready to be sent to the vendor the Place Order button should be used. This marks the PO as an order placed with the vendor. The Quantity and Cost values on a Placed PO may be edited depending on the configuration in Portal - Global Configuration Management under the Inventory section Partly Received - When linked to a Goods Receive some goods have been received but there are some quantities still outstanding. Complete - The PO has been fully received on the linked Goods Receive. Cancelled - When linked to a Goods Receive and not all goods are going to be received the Cancel Remainder button can be used to complete the PO.

title: Create New Purchase Order
text: Here you raise Purchase Orders for stock also known as a PO You have the option to 'Create new', you are required to enter a 'Title', 'Vendor' and 'Shop' and optional you can add the 'Order number' and 'Currency'. NOTE: only active shops are shown in the Shop list. NOTE: The currency used will be the one that was set at Vendor creation using the Accepted Currency field this cannot be changed. If you require a different currency then another vendor should be created with the required currency set. Then you can select the items to incorporate into the order, you can auto-populate, bulk import or find them manually. Auto Populate - This feature automatically compares the quantity of stock currently available and the quantity already allocated to other purchase orders (but not yet received), with the predefined Restock Level. Based on this analysis, it generates a suggested quantity for replenishment. The concepts of Reorder Point and Restock Levels are explained in the Matrix. NOTE: Currently, Imagine maintains Reorder and Restock levels at the item level only, without considering specific levels for individual stores. Therefore, it is assumed that the same Reorder and Restock levels apply to all locations. However, provisions should be made for scenarios where Reorder and Restock levels are defined at the Item/Store level. Export Bulk Template - On the Export Bulk Template option, a spreadsheet is exported, named PurchaseOrder_ImportTemplate by default. The Item, Barcode, Name, Variant and Vendor Item No columns on this spreadsheet are read-only. You can alter the Vendor Cost Price and Quantity fields ready for import to the PO. NOTE: Although it is possible to export more than 5000 lines to Excel, if you intend to re-import the same spreadsheet you must make steps to ensure your import file is 5000 lines or less and file size is below 200Kb. If you do not meet these requirements you will receive the below warning. Import Bulk Template - Bulk Import Template and Export Bulk Template allows you to browse and import an excel spreadsheet. Or you can Find the Items Manually, you have a search facility, and it will limit the items to only those from the selected vendor. You also have the option to limit to specific item groups. NOTE: If expected items do not show or are greyed out on the PO check the items 'Do not place on Purchase Order' setting in Standard Attribute on the Matrix tab for Item Details. This option may be controlled by your Head Office. Save - This will save the PO in its current state. The PO has not been placed yet and cannot be linked to a Goods Receive. Place - This tells Imagine the order has been placed with the vendor and no further changes will be made to it. Placed POs can be linked to Goods Receive Notes.

title: Download PDF
text: Within the Purchase Order use the Download PDF button located on the top right. After clicking download PDF, make a change to the filename if required and click the "Submit Sheet" button to download the PDF. NOTE: If the shop image (see Creating a New Shop - Image URL) cannot be rendered in the PDF, e.g. the image cannot be found from a website then the shop image will be shown as empty on the PDF.

title: Prerequisites
text: Important: K3 recommends reading all of the Digital VAT (UK) documentation here before starting training or testing on the K3 Digital VAT (UK) App. Failure to do so may lead to making an incorrect submission and the potential for locking data accidentally. Before you can use the K3|imagine Making Tax Digital (MTD) app, you need to sign up with HMRC for the Making Tax Digital scheme. You can find more information about signing up to the scheme in the HMRC's Overview of Making Tax Digital. HMRC gives you a Government Gateway login that you use to identify yourself and the App to the HMRC Making Tax Digital Service. You need this login when you first use the Making Tax Digital (MTD) app. The following prerequisites also apply: You have installed connector/bridging software between your financial system(s) for VAT and the K3|imagine Digital VAT (UK) app. VAT setups are configured fully in your financial system(s). You have configured your financial system to extract VAT records and send them to the K3|imagine Digital VAT (UK) app. You have uploaded transactions for the period you wish to submit, via your connector/bridging software, to the K3|imagine Digital VAT (UK) app.

title: Using the App in Test Mode
text: To enable you to test the upload of data and the reconciliation in the app without actually making a real submission to HMRC, K3 has provided a test mode. You can enable test mode in the Settings tab and by clicking the Enable Test Mode checkbox. Important: If test mode is not turned on, the application communicates with the HMRC production API and the system should be considered live for all transactions. Test mode offers the following options: Enable Test Mode ticked, but no other options ticked The user’s interactions are directed to the HMRC test API. There are limited options available regarding filing periods etc, but this is a real-time call to the actual HMRC test service. This can be used to test connectivity to the HMRC services and confirm authentication. The filing periods provided by the HMRC test API are 3 periods in 2017, which may not be sufficient for testing. Therefore, you have the following additional options. Enable Test Mode ticked, Use Dummy Data ticked The Digital VAT app enables you to use a simulated user experience in testing and training. HMRC authentication is used, but the service does not call the HMRC test or production API’s. This provides the following dummy data, which you can use to simulate the full user experience without the risk of making an accidental submission to HMRC. This also allows for more periods than are available from the HMRC test API: Dummy submission periods, by quarter or month based on the Use Monthly Periods flag. Dummy Liabilities and Payments data. This shows what the screen will look like once populated with data from your live account and enables you to test the filters. Dummy submission IDs returned when clicking Submit. This simulates the actions of the HMRC API, but never actually contacts it. Enable Test Mode ticked, Use Dummy Data ticked, Use Monthly Periods ticked. Toggles the dummy submission period data between quarters (unticked) and months (ticked). K3 recommends, for initial testing Use Test Mode: Ticked Use Dummy Data: Ticked Use Monthly Periods: User option, based on their usual submission period setup.

title: Authenticating with HMRC
text: To authenticate with HMRC before using the Digital VAT app: When you first access the app on the K3|imagine portal, the Digital VAT Authorization screen appears. Click on the Settings tab and enter your VAT Number. Press the Save button. A confirmation message will appear stating that changing this number will result in having to re-authenticate with HMRC. Press the Confirm button. A banner message confirms that Settings have been updated. Open the Authorize tab. Press the HMRC Authorization button to send an authorization request to the HMRC Government Gateway website. An authority to interact message from GOV.UK appears. Press the Continue button. The GOV.UK credentials page is shown. The screenshot is from the GOV.UK test environment. NOTE: The live environment may differ slightly. Enter your Government Gateway User ID and Password. The values above are test data only. The Grant Authority screen appears. This screen shows that you are allowing the K3 digital VAT App to access your account details and transactions and act on your behalf. IMPORTANT: If you do not wish the application to access your account details, do not approve this message. However, if you do not approve you will be unable to use the K3 UK Digital VAT App to file your return. If you want to remove the authority to access, click on the remove this authority link. If, and only IF, you are happy for the K3 Digital VAT app to access your HMRC account details, press the Grant authority button. An authentication success message appears. Following successful authentication, the UK Digital VAT menu options will appear in the Portal Menu.

title: Starting a VAT Submission
text: Before starting a submission, you should have uploaded your transaction data to Imagine using the connector/bridging software from your ERP or finance system(s). Refer to your individual configuration and connection guide for instructions on how to perform these procedures. NOTE: Ensure that all data you wish to submit has been uploaded before continuing. To start a VAT submission: Click on the Submissions tab. Click on the period for which you make a submission and click Create. A submission creation confirmation message appears. Check that the date range is correct. Click Confirm or Cancel as appropriate. Cancel returns you to the Submissions page. On clicking Confirm, there is a short pause while the app calculates the 9-box summation for the return. The VAT Calculation screen then appears, set out in the 9 boxes: If there are data errors, a banner message appears to notify you of this. Until the data errors are corrected or marked as ignored, you cannot access the Submit button. Refer to the later sections on correcting or ignoring data errors in this document, and the equivalent section in your ERP user guide.

title: Choosing to Submit or Perform Data Changes
text: Now that you have populated the 9-box summation of the VAT submission, you can choose to go ahead with submitting the VAT return (see Making a Submission to HMRC) or perform any of the following actions: Navigate to the Clear Tax Data tab to see a summary of any transactions that have data errors. For any such errors, you can: Correct them in the source ERP/finance system and re-upload e-upload the data for the period to the Digital VAT app. Mark them in the ERP/finance system as ignored and re-upload the data for the period to the Digital VAT app. If you are using an ERP connector that handles the returning of status information from the Digital VAT app, these error transactions are marked in your ERP system with an error status. Refer to the Error handling section in your ERP user guide for details of these actions. Navigate to the Clear Tax Data tab and clear all data from the VAT submission. You would typically do this if a reconciliation error needed to be corrected by excluding one or more transactions, or if you are not happy with the data uploaded for any reason. The status of the data upload will need to be re-set in the ERP/finance system and a new data upload session performed with the replacement data. Refer to your ERP user guide for a description of this process from an ERP perspective. Additional transactions which may have been missed in the initial upload can be uploaded and the calculation re-run by refreshing the Digital VAT app page in your browser.

title: Clearing Uploaded Data for the Submission
text: If you are unhappy with the uploaded data in the Digital VAT app, you can choose to clear out any data from the app that has not been previously submitted to HMRC. You then need to re-upload data to the application after performing whatever data corrections were required in the source system. To clear the unsubmitted data from the Digital VAT app: Click on the Clear Tax Data tab. Press the Clear Data button. A confirmation message appears advising that data for the date range will be removed. Click the green Confirm button if you wish to continue. Once the data is cleared from the Digital VAT App, you will need to run the appropriate jobs in your ERP/finance system to reset the data status on that side. When the data has been returned to the previous state, necessary corrections can be made, and the data re-uploaded to the Digital VAT app. You can repeat this procedure as many times as required until you are happy with the data in the VAT submission.

title: Making a Submission to HMRC
text: IMPORTANT: Submitting locks transactions so they cannot be re-used. This is not reversible. Please do not submit unless you are sure that the transactions to be used are the correct ones. Once all data errors are cleared, you can submit to HMRC: Return to the Submissions screen and select the Submission period desired. Accept the confirmation to recalculate the 9-box based on the latest data. If you are happy with the 9-box data, click the Submit button. A message appears containing a legal statement from HMRC. Please read and understand it before clicking Accept and Submit. If you do not agree with the statement in this message, click Cancel. Disclaimer: K3 Business Technologies and its agents or affiliates accept no responsibility for the content or calculation of any return filed. It is solely the responsibility of the user filing the return to confirm the completeness and correctness of any information sent to HMRC. 5. When you click Accept and Submit, the Digital VAT app returns a successful submission message: 6. The submission Receipt ID is stored in the app for all the transactions that made up that submission. 7. If you are using an ERP connector that enables retrieval of submission data from the Digital VAT app, you can now pull this submission data back to the ERP system using the job as described in your ERP How-To guide. 8. Press the Return to Submissions button. The Submission line now shows the Receipt Date on which the submission was made, and the submission Status is set to Fulfilled. Your VAT submission is now complete.

title: Additional Information
text: Payments You can retrieve a full list of payment information for the defined VAT number by clicking on the Payments tab: You can filter the date range using the Start date and End date fields at the top of the form. Liabilities You can retrieve the VAT liabilities for the account from HMRC and display them by clicking on the Liabilities tab: You can filter the date range using the Start date and End date fields at the top of the form.

title: Home View
text: When a user visits the URL they will land on the Home View, this is how customers will select the items they want to order through the POP. NOTE: The URL will look like this: http://pop.k3imagine.com/yournamehere The POP will always display the Landing Group for the selected store as the starting point for this navigation. This hierarchy and navigation can be further expanded upon and fully customised using the Composer Groups functionality in Visual Composer. You can choose to drill into the subgroups (black tiles) to see another layer of the hierarchy, or you can use the +/- buttons to add your items to the basket. If you press the + on an item which is a Bundle or has Modifiers, you will be asked to make your selections before adding to the basket. POP is aware of your current stock levels. So if your item is a stock-keeping item and you run out of stock, it will display a tile as Sold Out so customers cannot purchase it. There are various ways a customer can navigate the page. Search Bar You can also use the Search bar to find an item to add to your basket. On-screen, navigation If you have Bundle Groups set up, you will see navigation buttons appear when in those groups. For example Home > Drinks > Pepsi / Sprite / Coke. You can use this to return to the Home Screen or a section by selecting the POS. Information Button This button will show the user your Terms and Conditions, FAQ, Delivery Information and Privacy Policy if you have them configured. Currently, only Consultants can add this content. Product Information Any tile with the I symbol means there is some more information you might want to see for an item. It also indicates that there may be Bundle Groups or Modifiers for the item when selected. Basket Button The basket button shows you how many items you have in your basket. You can press the button to view the basket, which you have to do to proceed to Payment.

title: Items / Bundles / Modifiers
text: When you add a Bundle or Modifiable item to your basket, you will be prompted to make the relevant selections before adding them to the basket. If your Bundle main item has Modifiers linked to it, it will automatically take you to the Modifiers tab if you wish to make any alterations. Non-bundled items with Modifiers will only show you the Modifiers. The min-max rule for selections is displayed next to the Modifier title, You will also see any additional prices for the modifiers. Modifications that you make get printed on the order confirmation slip and also make their way through to the Order Status Display to be used in the order preparation area. You can also add manually entered comments against the line too. Modifications and Comments that you make are sent through to the Order Status Display to be used in the order preparation area.

title: Basket / Time Slots / Checkout
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Basket Time Slots Checkout Basket The Basket screen shows a list of your items, along with any bundle selections and modifiers you have made. They are grouped, so if you have made more than one item with the same selections and modifiers they will be on the same basket line. It denotes the extended price of the basket line and also displays the quantity multiplied by the single item price. Edit Line You can use the pencil icon for the basket line to make alterations to that line (change modifiers or bundle selections). Delete Line Use the trash can icon to remove the line from the basket. Delete Basket Use the black trash can next to the Pay button to clear the basket and return to the start screen. Continue Use the Continue button to proceed to the payment phase. Time Slots If your POP Configuration is set to use Time Slots, the user will be prompted to choose a time slot for which they want their order to be prepared. Checkout With the POP the first thing you will be asked is if you want to pick up your order or have it delivered. You will always be asked to enter your basic customer information. And if you select delivery, you will be asked to enter a delivery address. Pressing the Continue button may then ask for some other parameters which vary between payment providers. Once complete you will be taken to the payment screen When you press continue you will be asked to enter the card details to pay for the order. This screen will vary between providers, and this example is with GlobalPay. If the payment is successful, then it means that the payment has been made and the transaction has been submitted to Imagine's back-end for onward processing. It will now. Return you an order number which is displayed on the screen and used in the OSD and ORB. Email an order confirmation and receipt including the order number and any bundle selections and modifiers which are applied. Email of the order will be sent to the Shop email address.

title: Payment Providers
text: This is the section where you set up the payment provider to be used in TOP and POP. Please note that payments for Kiosk and Simple POS are set up in Admin since they use the Connector. To get started, choose the desired payment provider from the drop-down list, which can be either Valitor or OB Pay. Depending on the selected provider, you will be asked to fill in specific fields. Key This is the API Key provided to us by Valitor. Private Key This is provided by Valitor. Name This is the name of the payment integration, provided by Valitor. Is Production Environment This switches configuration to be in test or production mode. OB Pay is the provider used for GlobalPay as the Payment Acquirer and can be used worldwide. Payment Provider Config Client ID This is provided to K3 by OB Pay. Shared Secret Saved This is provided to K3 by OB Pay. It is obfuscated at entry, the check mark shows the shared secret has been entered correctly and saved. NOTE: If OB Pay provides a new key the Set New Shared Secret button can be used to apply the new key. Once applied, the field will say Shared Secret Saved and the check mark will be shown. Account This is the account name provided by OB Pay. Use Production Environment Switches configuration between test and production mode. Payment Methods Merchant Country Code Required for Google Pay accounts if shown. Enable Apple Pay Choose On if Apple Pay is to be accepted Apple Pay Merchant Identifier Enter this here for Apple Pay. Enable Google Pay Choose On if Google Pay is to be accepted. Google Pay Merchant ID Required if Google Pay is accepted. This must be set up in conjunction with an OB Pay account, Google Pay is provided via the OB Pay account. Enter the Merchant Id for Google Pay her Click Save when complete. Apple Pay Payment Method Configuration Follow the on-screen steps to complete the Apple Pay set-up.

title: POP Landing Page
text: The URL and QR Code for the Pop-up Order and Pay Store(s) can be accessed from the POP landing page. Entering the listed ‘Shops URL’ or accessing the ‘QR Code’ will open the POP for the store that is chosen. as shown below.

title: Payment Icon Settings
text: The Payment Icon Settings feature in the SCO (Self Serve) application offers users configurable options to control the visibility of payment type logos on the initial splash screen. It also allows users to display custom icons as per their preference. Default Payments Icons The Payment Icon Settings feature in the SCO (Self Serve) application provides a default set of card schemes that are displayed on the initial splash screen. Users can utilize toggle buttons to control the visibility of specific icons, either showing them (On) or hiding them (Off). By default, all icons are initially set to On. Please note that the icon URLs are predefined within the system and cannot be modified, as well as the list of default card schemes. Remember to click Save in order to apply any changes made. Custom Payment Icons "If any card schemes are not displayed in the Default Payment Icons list, you can add them here. Utilize the Add Payment Icon section to create new payment icons. Once a payment icon is created, use the toggle buttons to control its visibility, either showing it (On) or hiding it (Off). If you wish to remove a specific card payment icon permanently, you can click on the adjacent Delete button." Please note that this revised version maintains the original meaning while providing a clearer and more concise explanation. Add Payment Icon To add payment icons to the Custom Payment Icons section, follow these steps: Enter the name of the payment icon (required). Provide the Icon URL (required) for the payment icon. Click the "Add Payment Type Icon" button to add the payment icon to the custom list. By following these steps, you can successfully add a payment icon to the custom list in the application.

title: Stripe Setup for TOP
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Introduction Stripe Details Secret Key Webhook Secret TOP Setup Setup Complete Introduction This article describes the setup process for implementing Stripe as the payment solution for TOP. This article assumes a Stripe account has already been set up as is out of scope of K3 services. Note, there is a minimum transaction amount of 30pence with Stripe, so it is important to note this when testing the setup. Stripe Details In order to configure TOP, we need to key pieces of information from within the Stripe dashboard of the retailer. Secret Key Webhook Secret (Which requires a webhook to be setup) Secret Key Once logged in, Click the Developers button in the topbar of the dashboard. Click the API Keys tab, and then reveal secret key. It is this secret key we need as part of the setup. Webhook Secret In order to obtain a webhook secret, you need to create a webhook. The Webhook receives notifications back from Stripe to indicate that transactions are successful. Click the Webhooks tab, still within the Developers section and Add an Endpoint Enter the endpoint URL first. For production setups this is https://portal.k3imagine.com/ms-stripe/api/v1.0/Webhook. Then press Select Events wich allows us to choose what events they will send to our webhook. Scroll down and expand the Checkout section and enable checkout.session.complete. Click Add Events and then Add Endpoint and you'll see the webhook details. Reveal the signing secret and make a note of it, as we need that for the TOP setup. The Stripe setup is now complete. TOP Setup In the Imagine Portal, go to Self Serve Admin > Payment Providers. Select Stripe and enter the secret key and webhook secret you obtained above. Setup Complete The setup is finished. You should now have Stripe as your payment provider in TOP.

title: Refunds for TOP Transactions Using Stripe
text: When using TOP, there are scenarios where you may need to issue a refund. As Stripe is our preferred payment provider for TOP, we have extended our integration to allow you to refund transactions from within Imagine. In Self Serve Admin > Shops Choose your Shop from the list, and there is a new tab for Stripe Refunds This shows you a filterable list of transactions that have been processsed through Stripe. It also shows you the Stripe Payment intent ID so you can cross reference the payment to the Stripe Dashboard. You will see there are 2 columns. Transaction Amount (The amount the original transaction was for) and Refunded Amount which is how much for that transaction has been refunded. This is a good visual indicator of any refunds you have had to process. When you have identified the transaction to refund, press the Arrow for it. You will see an itemised list of refunds applied to that transaction if any exist. Otherwise, enter the amount you want to refund into the box and press Refund. At this point the refund will be charged back to the customer on the card they originally paid with, and they will be emailed with a receipt from Imagine advising them of the refund. You'll get a toaster notification to advise its been successful. Reviewing the transaction with the refund applied will show the successful refund.

title: Norway
text: The functionalities provided for Norwegian fiscal support are as follows: 1. Compatible Cash Drawer: A cash drawer with an "open" sensor is required for Norwegian fiscal support. 2. Logging and Printing Corrections: All corrections such as price changes and voided lines are logged and printed on the X/Z report. 3. Quantity Adjustments: Quantity adjustments are disabled in the POS when Norwegian fiscalization is activated. 4. Cash Drawer Open Restriction: Sales cannot be initiated while the cash drawer is open. 5. Cancelled Sales and Voided Lines: Cancelled sales are logged to the connector, and their values are printed on the X/Z report. Voided lines are also recorded as part of this process. 6. Manual Drawer Openings: All manual openings of the cash drawer are printed on the X/Z report. 7. Special Receipt Titles: Sales and return receipts have special titles: "Salgskvittering" for sales and "Returkvittering" for returns. 8. Total Sales, Returns, and Exchanges: The X/Z report will display the total number and values of sales, returns, and exchanges (currently in development). 9. Total Non-Sales/Returns/Exchanges: The X/Z report will show the total number and values of non-sales, returns, and exchanges (currently in development). 10. Journal Data Recording: All journal data will be recorded in a tamper-proof, exportable S-AFT format on the connector using blockchain technology (currently in development). To configure the Norwegian fiscal features in Imagine, you need to set up a Shop Feature in the Support Platform with the following details: Name: NorwegianFiscalisation Type: Fiscalisation Group: Fiscalisation Values: - Active: Boolean value indicating if the fiscalization feature is currently enabled for the shop. - reprintsAllowed: Number indicating the maximum number of reprints allowed for each receipt. Please contact your local support team for more information and assistance in configuring the Norwegian fiscal support in Imagine. Additionally, Imagine supports preventing the generation of a Cash Statement when there are open parked notes.

title: Profile Overview
text: The Profile Overview is where you can select the Composer Group to be used as the "Landing Group" for each of your applications at a specific location. This allows you to customize your apps based on the location they are used in. You can use the tabbed menu to switch between the applications and view the list of stores you have within Imagine in the table below. To create or modify your stores, use the Backoffice. The Composer Profile is the layout of buttons that will be displayed as the initial view for the selected location's application. To select or change the Composer Profile and Visual Profile for a specific location, click on the corresponding row in the table. This will display a dropdown menu where you can make your selections. When making changes to the Composer Profile or Visual Profile for a store location, it is important to save the changes by clicking the "Save" button. It is recommended to save changes before switching to another application tab. It is important to note that any changes made here will be immediately reflected in your front-end applications, so make sure to double-check your changes before saving.

title: Visual Profiles
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Visual Profiles Creating a new Profile Colors Tab Text Tab Assets Tab Visual Profiles Visual Profiles contain basic information that determines the appearance of the self-serve application, this is currently only used in the SCO and old Kiosk applications. Creating a new Profile To begin creating a new profile click the button. You will be taken to the below page. Colours Tab Within the colours tab, you can change the primary, secondary and tertiary colours of the application. All values must be entered as hex codes. Text Tab Within the text tab, you can change the text that is shown on the splash screen when the applications first load or in between transactions. Assets Tab Within the assets tab, you can assign the company logo used on the self-serve application the profile is applied to.

title: Creating a New Composer Group
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Creating a New Composer Group Adding Tiles to a Composer Group Time Restricted Tiles Amending Tiles Composer Groups are a collection of tiles that are presented to the user as a selection of options in front-end applications. Each application requires a "Landing Group," which serves as the starting point for users to engage with the application. The selection of the landing group is configurable on a per-application and per-location basis in the Profile Overview section of the Backoffice. Creating a New Composer Group The Composer Group List displays all existing groups. To edit a group, simply click on the relevant group. To create a new Composer Group, click the "Create New" button. You will be taken to the below page. Display Name Refers to the name that will be visible to customers on the Self Serve Applications. It is the name that identifies the Composer Group and its content. Name It's important to use a unique name for the Composer Group as you cannot use the same name multiple times. If you try to use a name that already exists, you will receive a warning message. Image URL This is the image that will appear on the tile. The supported image types are .bmp, .gif, .jpeg, and .svg. Image Fill Setting This setting determines how the image will be displayed within the tile: Centred: The image will be positioned in the middle of the tile. Fill: The image will be resized to fill the entire tile, potentially cropping parts of the original image. After making any changes or updates to the Composer Group, click on the "Save Composer Group" button to save the changes. Once saved, a notification will appear in the top right corner to confirm that the changes have been saved. Adding Tiles to a Composer Group To add a Tile to a composer group, follow these steps: Click on the Composer Group you want to add a Tile to. Select the "Add Tile" button. A window will appear with options for which type of Tile you require. Choose the type of Tile you want to add. You will then be asked to search for and select an instance of the type you have chosen. Once you have selected the Tile instance, you can configure the settings for the Tile. Click "Save" to save the Tile to the Composer Group. A notification in the top right corner will appear to confirm that the Tile has been added to the Composer Group. Choosing a Tile Type Item This is a single Tile without grouping or stacking. Composer Group This is a Tile in which tiles will have a group or stack. Bundle A Composite Tile allows for multiple items to be displayed in a single Tile, such as a meal deal that includes both a drink and a meal. Advert This will create an Advert Tile. Advert Tiles are typically used in apps that run on the consumer's devices, but may not be suitable for kiosks or self-checkout systems. Options for Creating a New Entity and Relevant Pages Create a new Item This will take you to the Item Creation page. Create a new Bundle This will take you to the Product Configurator> Bundles page. Create a new Composer Group This will take you to a blank new Composer Group Page. Time Restricted Tiles You can set times for when you require a tile to appear or disappear. This is helpful for certain periods of the day, for example, having different meal types for Breakfast or Lunchtimes. You can also have promotional tiles linked to different items/bundles with special prices if required. Times are set in 30-minute increments and are not a specific reference to a time of day relevant for time zones. For example, if you set the time for "3 pm" then the tiles will display relative to the time of that location I.E Happy Hour in London and New York can both be 3 pm-4 pm, relative to when those cities reach that time. Amending Tiles When you hover your mouse over a tile, the edit symbol will appear. Click this to begin editing the tile. To delete a tile, use the delete button located in the top left corner. If the tile is part of a Composer Group, you will see a "Go to Group" button. Clicking this will take you to the selected group for editing. To save any changes made to the Composer Group, click on the "Save Composer Group" button. Note that this button is disabled until changes are made on the selected group. If you wish to delete a Composer Group, click on the "Delete" button. A prompt will appear to confirm the deletion. Selecting "Yes" will permanently delete the Composer Group, while selecting "No" will cancel the action. The Tiles are displayed in a grid format that can be rearranged by dragging and dropping them into place. The order of the Tiles is always from left to right, assuming one long wrapped row. This is because each device has different dimensions, and the Tiles need to be responsive to fit all screen sizes. Active Tiles are displayed with a white background, while inactive Tiles are displayed with a grey background. Inactive Tiles are not displayed to customers.

title: Adverts
text: Adverts are tiles that allow you to sell promotional space within your front-end apps and provide links to off-site content. However, it's important to note that this functionality does not include link tracking or any metrics. Adverts are not recommended for use with the Kiosk or SCO, as they are designed to be used on personal devices. Adverts List This is the Advert List. Here you can view all existing adverts, search for a specific advert, create a new advert, or edit an existing one. Advert Adverts only require 3 properties to be provided Name The Advert Name is used for internal reference and is not displayed to customers in the front-end applications. It helps you identify and organize your adverts in the Backoffice. Redirect URL This is the URL the user will be sent to, in a new browser tab, if they click the tile on their device. Image URL The URL to the image that appears on the tile. Only .bmp, .gif, .jpg and .svg type images are supported.

title: Shop Setup
text: The PoS Admin - General Information menu should be used in preference to this menu, Admin will be removed in future releases and will not be accessible. In this section, you have the ability to edit general information about your shop. Please select the specific store for which you need to make changes. After entering the necessary information, click on "Save" to finalize your changes. If you wish to discard any modifications you made, click on "Cancel." The base language refers to the default language used in the Point of Sale (POS) system. You can modify it by selecting the desired language from the drop-down menu. For more detailed information, please refer to the "@Clerks" section.

title: Gift Settings
text: The PoS Admin - Gift Voucher Setup menu should be used in preference to this menu, Admin will be removed in future releases and will not be accessible. In this section, you can configure the printing options for gift receipts and labels. Use the drop-down menu to select the type of gift receipt or label you want to customize. It's important to note that if you need to print both the receipt and label, both must be available to the Connector to avoid unexpected results. Ensure you have compatible hardware, and for more information, refer to the POS Hardware guidelines. Once you have set all the necessary options, press "Save" to apply the changes. A confirmation message will be displayed once the changes have been successfully saved. If you choose the "Gift Label" option, you will need to select the label template from the drop-down menu. Next, you'll need to enter information for the default exchange period. Select the type (either "Number of Days" or "Until Specific Date") from the drop-down menu. If your return policy specifies a certain number of days for return, choose the "Number of Days" option and set the default exchange period accordingly. If you have a specific return date, such as for Christmas return periods, choose the "Until Specific Date" option and enter the desired date. For example, if your return policy is generally 30 days from the date of purchase, select "Number of Days" and enter "30" as the default exchange period. However, during the Christmas period, if you accept returns from January 1st to January 15th, you would need to change the period type to the 15th of January. This information will be displayed on the printed gift label. Remember to save your changes to complete the process. Please note that if you have previously set up a gift receipt to print on a gift label in the setup, you must select a label template here. If you are only printing a gift receipt, this option will not be available. Additionally, you can set the expiration period for gift certificates and credit notes. The gift certificate expiry refers to the number of days within which the certificate will be valid, and the credit note expiry determines the validity period in days for credit notes.

title: Local Currency
text: The PoS Admin - Shop Currency Rates menu should be used in preference to this menu, Admin will be removed in future releases and will not be accessible. In this section, you can view the local currency used by this shop. Please note that once set, the shop's currency cannot be changed (refer to Back Office - Shops for more details). If the shop accepts other currencies, they will be listed here along with their respective conversion rates. Local Currency - Select the desired currency from the drop-down list. This list is predefined within Imagine. Add Currency - Choose from the drop-down list to add an additional currency. This list is also predefined within Imagine. Currency Exchange Rate - Enter the exchange rate for the additional currency. This value is determined by the retailer and should be manually updated whenever there are changes in the exchange rate. For example, if you want to charge 8.5 DKK for each 1 GBP, set the Currency Exchange Rate to 8.5 and click on ADD CURRENCY. Currency Exchange Rate - This displays the list of currencies that have already been defined. To edit the exchange rate, simply click on the Currency Exchange Rate box and make the necessary changes. To remove a currency, tick the corresponding box, and upon clicking Save, the currency will be removed. Don't forget to press Save at the top of the page to finalize any changes.

title: Customer Display
text: The PoS Admin - POS Options menu should be used in preference to this menu, Admin will be removed in future releases and will not be accessible. This section provides you with the ability to configure your Customer Display settings, which are utilized in conjunction with the Customer Display widget. External Site - Select a web page that can display dynamic content or store branding. If you are linking to an insecure site (HTTP), you may need to "allow content" in the Customer Display widget if the browser blocks it. Show customer display on the monitor number - Choose the display where the External Site will automatically pop out. Please note that you need to use the K3 Imagine Chrome Extension for this feature to function. Show change for (in milliseconds) - Determine the duration for which the transaction details will be displayed to the customer. This duration is specified in milliseconds, for example, setting it to 2000ms will display the information for 2 seconds. Background Colour and Text Colour - Customize the background and text colors for the transaction details that appear on the screen. Remember to click Save to apply and finalize any changes you have made.

title: Start Screen
text: In the Product Configurator, items can be restricted in two ways. Firstly, an item can be flagged as "Age Restricted," which requires the clerk to determine if the customer is legally allowed to purchase the item based on their age. Secondly, the quantity of items that can be purchased together in a single transaction can be restricted using the "Restricted Quantity" field. When a restricted item is scanned, both the Tri Light and SCO Companion will display an orange status. This indicates that although it doesn't block the customer from proceeding with the transaction, it presents an opportunity for the clerk to remotely approve the restriction. By approving the restriction promptly, the clerk can facilitate a faster checkout process for the customer.

title: Composer View
text: Composer View is where a customer will make their selections for items ordered through the Kiosk. The Kiosk will always display the Landing Group for the selected store as the start point for this navigation. This hierarchy and navigation can be further expanded upon and fully customised using the Composer Groups functionality in Visual Composer. You have the option to explore subgroups (black tiles) to access deeper levels of the hierarchy. Additionally, you can use the +/- buttons to add items to your basket. When pressing the + button on a Bundle or an item with Modifiers, you will be prompted to make your selections before adding it to the basket. The Kiosk system is aware of your current stock levels. Therefore, if an item is a stock keeping item and you have run out of stock, it will be displayed as "Sold Out" to prevent customers from making a purchase. There are various ways a customer can navigate within the page. Icon Meaning Function On Screen Navigation If you have Bundle Groups set up, you will see navigation buttons appear when in those groups. For example Home > Drinks > Pepsi / Sprite / Coke. you can use this to return to the Home Screen or to a section by selecting on the POS. Information Button This button will show the user your Terms and Conditions, FAQ, Delivery Information and Privacy Policy, if you have them configured. Currently, only Consultants are able to add this content. Supervisor Functions This button will ask you for a PIN code to enter supervisor functions. Tile Button The tile button if pressed will return you back to your home group from wherever you are in the application. Product Information Any tile with the i symbol means there is some more information you might want to see for an item. It also indicates that there may be Bundle Groups or Modifiers for the item when selected. Basket Button The basket button shows you how many items you have in your basket. You can press the button to view the basket, which you have to do in order to proceed to Payment.

title: Supervisor Functions
text: To access the Supervisor Functions in the Kiosk, follow these steps: Locate the settings cog icon in the top right-hand corner of the Kiosk interface. Click on the settings cog icon. You will be prompted to enter a supervisor PIN. Enter the supervisor PIN provided to you. If the entered PIN is correct and you have the necessary supervisor permissions, you will gain access to the Supervisor Functions. Please note that the supervisor permissions are set up in the Configuration, and only users with the appropriate authorization will be able to access the Supervisor Functions. You will then be presented with the following functions that a supervisor is perform via kiosk. Here are the explanations for the remaining functions in the Kiosk Supervisor Functions: Full Screen: This function toggles the display between full screen mode and regular mode. Please note that when using Kiosk mode in Chrome, the full screen function may not work as it is overridden by the browser's settings. Choose Arm Device: The term "Arm" refers to the Connector. In this function, you can select from a list of Connectors that you have set up in the Admin settings. If you don't have a physical Arm device, you can use the Virtual Connector as an alternative. However, please be aware that the Virtual Connector should not be used in a live environment, as it bypasses payment processing and assumes a full payment has been made. Refresh Kiosk: Selecting this option will clear the current basket, return you to the start screen, and reload all the Composer tiles. It allows you to start fresh and begin a new transaction. These functions provide additional control and customization options for supervisors using the Kiosk system.

title: Items / Bundles / Modifiers
text: When you add a Bundle or Modifiable item to your basket in the Kiosk, you will be prompted to make the necessary selections or modifications before adding them to the basket. This ensures that you can customize your order according to your preferences. If the Bundle main item has Modifiers linked to it, the Kiosk will automatically direct you to the Modifiers tab, providing you with the option to make any desired alterations to the modifiers associated with the item. This allows you to tailor the item to your specific requirements before finalizing your order. For non-bundled items with Modifiers in the Kiosk, only the Modifiers will be shown to you. You won't see any other bundled items in this case. Next to the Modifier title, you will find the min-max rule for the selections, which indicates the allowed range or limits for choosing the modifiers. Additionally, any additional prices associated with the modifiers will be displayed. It's important to note that any modifications you make to the item, including the chosen modifiers, will be printed on the order confirmation slip. Furthermore, these modifications will be reflected in the Order Status Display, which is used in the order preparation area. This ensures that your customizations are accurately communicated for the preparation of your order. Modifications made during the ordering process are seamlessly incorporated into the system. These modifications are effectively recorded and conveyed through two channels: Order Confirmation Slip: The order confirmation slip, generated upon completion of the order, includes a comprehensive summary of all the modifications made. This ensures that the printed confirmation slip provides a clear and detailed record of the customized order. Order Status Display: The modifications are also transmitted to the Order Status Display, which serves as a visual reference for the order preparation area. The Order Status Display prominently presents the modifications, ensuring that the staff can easily access and implement them during the order preparation process. By integrating modifications into both the order confirmation slip and the Order Status Display, the system facilitates accurate and efficient communication of customizations, streamlining the overall order fulfillment workflow. Basket The Basket screen shows a list of your items, along with any bundle selections and modifiers you have made. They are grouped together, so if you have made more than one item with the same selections and modifiers they will be on the same basket line. It clearly denotes the extended price of the basket line and also displays the quantity multiplied by the single item price. Icon Name Function Edit Line You can use the pencil icon for the basket line to make alterations to that line (change modifiers or bundle selections). Delete Line Use the trash can icon to remove the line from the basket. Delete Basket Use the black trash can next to the Pay button to clear the basket and return to the start screen. Pay Button Use the Continue button to proceed to the payment phase.

title: Time Out / Payment
text: Idle Timeout When using the Composer View or the Basket View in the Kiosk, an "idle" timer is continuously running in the background. This timer is designed to monitor user activity and engagement. If no action is taken within the defined timeframe, the Kiosk will issue a warning indicating that the basket will be emptied and you will be returned to the start screen after a specific number of seconds. This feature serves as a reminder to keep the session active and prevents prolonged periods of inactivity, ensuring an efficient and responsive user experience. Providing a warning before emptying the basket and returning to the start screen, allows users to take appropriate action or continue their interaction with the Kiosk to avoid unintended disruptions. This idle timeout is configurable. Payment Pressing the Pay button will, unless you are using the Virtual connector for testing and demo purposes, initiate the Connector to instruct the Pin Entry Device to make a payment. At this point, the Kiosk has handed over control and is awaiting further input. You will see the below screen whilst it is processing. On this screen, the idle timeout is ignored and instead uses whatever configurable timeout is used for that PED, and that will vary between payment providers. If the payment fails, you will be advised and after 5 seconds it will return you to the basket to try another card. You should refer to the PED for details on why the transaction was declined, as each provider is different, so we only display a failure. NOTE: You will also see a failure if the Kiosk is unable to communicate with the Connector. If the payment is successful, then it means that the payment has been made and the transaction has been submitted to Imagine's back-end for onward processing. It will now. Submit the order to the Order Status Display. Return you an order number which is displayed on the screen and used in the OSD and ORB. Print an order confirmation slip including the order number and any bundle selections and modifiers which are applied. Show you the estimated waiting time, which it calculates based on the last 15 minutes of order throughput. Before returning the user to the start screen. The Estimated Waiting Time can be hidden from this screen if configured to do so in Self-Serve Admin.

title: TOP Tables
text: This is where you configure your tables for use by TOP. Press the + button to add a new row. Name In Imagine, a table is linked to a physical table using a name, which appears in the Table Overview Page (TOP) and the On-Screen Display (OSD). This name is known as the "Table Name". Description This should be a loose description of how you might reference a table. it could be based on general location or number of seats. TOP URL This is generated automatically when you save the record. This gives you the URL that can be used to access TOP to be embedded elsewhere if you choose to link to it from an external source. Clicking the URL will copy it to your clipboard for pasting elsewhere - for example encoding to an NFC dot. TOP QR Code This is generated alongside the URL. You can then copy the generate image and print it in whatever collateral you want to attach to your table, like a fixed menu or laminated sticker. Edit Amend or change any information. Delete This will give you a prompt below before deletion.

title: POP Config
text: This is where you make any configurations for POP. Path This is the unique web address that you use to access POP (Point of Purchase) for the selected shop. It is used to validate the URL and must be unique for your shop and all tenants using Imagine. Pickup Available This will enable the ability for you to have a Collection order in POP. Delivery Available This enables the ability for you to have a Delivery order in POP. Delivery Item Id This is a unique code assigned to an item in inventory that is used to apply a delivery charge to the transaction. Without this code, it is not possible to charge a delivery fee. Free Delivery Threshold This is the minimum transaction value that must be reached in order to qualify for free delivery. Orders with a total value below this threshold will be subject to the delivery charge. Order Email Address This is where you receive notifications for orders that need to be processed, typically in the OSD.

title: Time Slots
text: Time Slots are used to allow customers using POP to determine a future time that they want to collect or deliver their order. Use Time Slots This needs to be On for POP to display time slots dependent on the configuration provided here. Order Processing Time This field is used to estimate the preparation time for an order and to generate time slots for pickup or delivery based on the given interval. For instance, if the preparation time is set to 15 minutes, the system will create a time slot every 15 minutes. Times These are necessary to enforce shopping within the designated time slots for customers. Throughput This is the maximum number of orders that can be processed during each time slot, which helps in managing the order volume during peak hours. For instance, on a Monday, if you have enough staff to process five orders every 15 minutes, then you can set the maximum order limit to five per time slot.

title: Kiosk Config
text: This is where you can change settings for the Kiosk. Hide Average Waiting Time ON Waiting time will not appear. OFF Waiting time appears at the end of a Kiosk transaction.

title: Languages
text: This is where you select the preferred languages to be displayed on your customer-driven SelfServe Apps, such as Kiosk and SCO. Imagine supports multiple languages, and you can choose which languages to display to customers based on your location's needs. Languages Pick which languages get displayed to the user. Default Mode You can choose the default language from your selected options. The default language will be the first one presented to the customer.

title: Shop Policies
text: The Policy Settings section in POP allows you to configure your FAQ, Terms and Conditions, Delivery Policy, and Return Policy. You can toggle the relevant "On/Off" switch to enable or disable a particular policy. Use the text box to provide the content customers will see. Once you have made changes, click Save to apply them.

title: SCO Config
text: The SCO Config setting allows you to configure the "Enable Out of Paper" option, which when turned on, will disable the SCO machine when it runs out of paper. If this option is turned off, the SCO machine will continue to function even if it runs out of paper, which could result in issues such as receipts not being printed. After selecting the desired option, click on "Save SCO Config" to apply the setting. A confirmation notification will appear once the changes are successfully saved.

title: OSD Config
text: The OSD Config is used when the Order Display becomes backlogged with pending orders that may have been processed but have not been moved along the board, causing orders to become visibly delayed. Please note that using the Clear Down option will remove ALL orders on the OSD and this action CANNOT be UNDONE. Select which Shop you wish to Clear the OSD Board for from the list. Navigate to the OSD Config tab on the far right and click the Clear Down button. Warning: Once confirmed this cannot be undone. You will be asked to confirm the clearing of all orders, the warning will indicate using (Brackets) which shop you are choosing ensure you have selected the correct shop as this cannot be undone. Clear Down: This will remove ALL orders from the OSD and will not be able to recover them. Cancel: This will cancel the action.

title: Creating a New Shop
text: To begin making a new shop click the Create New Shop button. You will be offered a variety of fields to complete for your shop, such as the Shop Name, Group, Currency, Base Language, Manager, Shop Location, and Tax Groups. Note: any fields marked with an asterisk (*) are mandatory, and the Save button will only become active once these required fields have been filled out. Shop Details Field Description Shop Code Identify the shop with a code, can be letters, numbers and special characters. Should shorter than the Shop Name Shop Name Give the shop a name, can be letters, numbers and special characters, with a maximum length of 100 characters Base Language These are system available languages, select the most appropriate from the list Manager Choose one clerk marked as 'manager' from the selection here Image URL Link to an image for the shop Groups* Select the group(s) the shop will be in. You must select at least one group from this list so that a Primary Group can be selected Primary Group* From the Groups selection pick a single primary group. The shop will take any settings initially from the Primary Group. If a setting cannot be found then the groups listed in Groups will be taken into consideration Note: As a shop must have a Tax Group assigned you will not be able to Save the shop until the shop has a group assigned that has a tax rate set, or you select a Tax Group in Shop Configuration on this screen Shop Area The square meterage of the shop as a whole number Company Select a company from the list Currency* These are system available currencies, select the most appropriate from the list Company Number Used to display your tax registration number on the receipt. Can be letters, numbers or special characters Allow over receive of PO When the option is enabled, on Receive Goods that have a Purchase Order selected, you are able to over receive the quantity compared to the Purchase Order When the option is disabled, on Receive Goods that have a Purchase Order selected you are not able to receive more than stated on the Purchase Order Shop Location Field Description Address 1* Give the shop a first address line, can be letters, numbers and special characters, with a maximum length of 100 characters City* Give the shops city, can be letters, numbers and special characters, with a maximum length of 100 characters Postal code Give the shops postal code, can be letters, numbers and special characters, with a maximum length of 100 characters State/County Give the shops state or county, can be letters, numbers and special characters, with a maximum length of 100 characters Country* Give the country a shop is in, can be letters, numbers and special characters, with a maximum length of 100 characters Phone1 Give the shops phone number, can be letters, numbers and special characters, with a maximum length of 20 characters Phone2 Give the shops alternative phone number, can be letters, numbers and special characters, with a maximum length of 20 characters Email Give an email address, can be letters, numbers and special characters, with a maximum length of 254 characters. This email address must be correctly formatted with an @ symbol and domain name. When given, this will appear as the sending address for emailed receipts. Shop Configuration Field Description Tax Group Where you have Groups and a Primary Group selected, but none of these have a Tax Group assigned, you must select a Tax Group here. Note: in order for an item on a transaction to have the correct tax percentage assigned, the transaction needs to know the Tax Group for the shop. For every item in Imagine, a single Tax Code from each Tax Group can be assigned. When the item Tax Group matches the Tax Group for the shop then the transaction can successfully record the correct tax due.

title: Editing an Existing Shop
text: If you wish to modify the information of an existing shop, simply click on the store name to open its details page. Here, you will find all the relevant information about the shop, as well as three options located in the top-right corner of the screen. Please keep in mind that deleting a shop will permanently remove it, and it cannot be restored. As an alternative, you may wish to use the Active toggle instead. Cancel Button: This will return you to the list of shops. Delete Button: Once you initiate the process of removing a shop entry, you will be prompted to confirm the deletion. After confirmation, you will receive a notification indicating that the shop has been successfully deleted. Save Button: Use this to keep any changes that you make. Inactive Shops: The Show inactive shops toggle can be used to show or hide inactive shops from the list. This is the only place where inactive shops can be seen. Inactive shops are not shown elsewhere, if you need to take action on an inactive shop then you must make it active first

title: Sales Budget
text: You can manage your Sales Budgets via this page. At the bottom of the page there is a Sales Budgets section. When you download the template, an Excel file will be generated containing all the dates for the current month, with a separate column for each store. You can then use Excel to enter your sales budgets for each store on the corresponding dates. Remember to save any changes you make, and use the Upload Budget function to apply your budgets. Once uploaded, your budgets will be reflected in the POS Charts. Please note that the budget will only be visible in the weekly and monthly views when the summarized button is selected.

title: Fixed Percent Discount
text: When the customer adds the Item Bundle to their transaction at the point of sale (POS), they will receive a percentage off the price of all the items included. For instance, if there is a hierarchy of items that are eligible for a 10% discount, you can create an Item Bundle containing all those items and apply a Fixed Percent Discount of 10%. As the cashier scans the qualifying items at the POS, 10% will be subtracted from the sales price. Once you're done, click the Save button to finish.

title: Deal Bundle
text: If you purchase all the products included in the 'Deal Bundle', this is the price you will pay. This promotion is ideal for bundling together related items, such as batteries for a remote control car or wrapping paper with a gift. To take advantage of this promotion, you need to create Item Bundles that include the item(s) eligible for the promotion. At least one quantity of each item should be added to the transaction to activate the promotion. You can create multiple Item Bundles, but remember that you must purchase at least one of each item to qualify for the promotion. Once you select the 'Deal Bundle', make sure to complete the 'bundle cost' fields to indicate the price the customer will pay for the group of goods in each currency. For each item listed, adjust the Quantity field according to the promotion's requirements. For example, if the customer needs to buy 3 of a particular item, modify the Quantity field accordingly. To edit the quantity, use the provided and enter the required amount, then press enter. When you're done, click the Save button to finish.

title: Least Expensive
text: The "Least Expensive" promotion allows you to buy a certain quantity of items and receive a percentage discount on the lowest-priced item. For example, the promotion could be "Buy 3 and get the least expensive item for half price." To set up this promotion, follow these steps: Create an Item Bundle that includes the item(s) eligible for this promotion. In the first field, enter the number of items from the Item Bundle that the customer must purchase to qualify for the promotion (e.g., 3). In the second field, enter the percentage discount that the customer will receive on the lowest-priced item (e.g., 50%). In the third field, enter the number of items to which the promotion applies (e.g., 1, indicating that the discount applies to the least expensive item). Once you've filled in the necessary information, click the Save button to finalize the setup. Remember to adjust the values based on your specific promotion details.

title: Mandatory Choice
text: This promotion triggers when all the mandatory items are added to a single transaction, then a percentage discount is applied to all mandatory and optional qualifying items. For example, the promotion is to apply a 5% to a set of umbrellas when the customer purchases a box of golf balls. The golf balls are made the mandatory item by selecting the item check box and clicking Mandatory. All items in the promotion are detailed in an Item Bundle. An item can only appear as either Mandatory or Optional, but not both. You can add one or more items to the Mandatory list, noting that on the transaction each mandatory item must be added before the promotion is triggered. You can also specify the number of mandatory items that must be purchased e.g. two boxes of golf balls are required so the Quantity is set to 2. When the golf balls and an umbrella are added to the transaction the customer receives a 5% discount on both items. If the customer chooses to purchase only the umbrella they will not receive the 5% promotion. Click the Save button to complete.

title: Multi Buy with Percentage
text: This promotion allows you to set a per cent discount per unit when the unit(s) are bought in multiples. This is similar to Multi Buy With Price Per Item but based on percentage discount. For example, if the customer purchases 2 items listed in the Item Bundle a discount of 5% is applied to the transaction. If the customer wishes to buy 3 items the price per unit has a 7% discount applied. Under the Steps section click the + button. Enter the Quantity as the number of units needed to trigger the discount, then enter the Discount Percent. Click the Save button to complete.

title: Discount Item Percentage
text: This promotion allows you to discount individual items by a percentage. This is useful for items that do not fit into a bundle or where you wish to manage them individually. For example, I have a range of end-of-line items in different hierarchies and from different vendors. I wish to reduce these by a range of 10% to 20%. Note: the Item Bundles option is not available on this screen. Items are added individually. Set the Promotion Engine type to Discount Item Percentage. In the Discount Items By Percentage list click the + button. Enter the Item No for the item you wish to discount. If the Item No is not valid you should check the number, only Item No's as listed on the Matrix tab for an item are valid. Under the Discount Percent field enter the percent you wish this item to be discounted by. Click the Save button to complete.

title: Multi Group Deal Bundle
text: This promotion allows you to discount individual items by a percentage. This is useful for items that do not fit into a bundle or where you wish to manage them individually. For example, I have a range of end-of-line items in different hierarchies and from different vendors. I wish to reduce these by a range of 10% to 20%. Note: the Item Bundles option is not available on this screen. Items are added individually. Set the Promotion Engine type to Discount Item Percentage. In the Discount Items By Percentage list click the + button. Enter the Item No for the item you wish to discount. If the Item No is not valid you should check the number, only Item No's as listed on the Matrix tab for an item are valid. Under the Discount Percent field enter in the per cent you wish this item to be discounted by. Click the Save button to complete.

title: Discount Item Amount
text: This promotion allows you to discount individual items to a set price. This is useful for items that do not fit into a bundle or where you wish to manage them individually. For example, I have a range of end-of-line items in different hierarchies and from different vendors. I wish to reduce the price of these to assist with sales. NOTE: The Item Bundles option is not available on this screen. Items are added individually. Set the Promotion Engine type to Discount Item Amount. In the Select, The Item And Set A Price For It list click the + button. Enter the Barcode for the item you wish to discount. If the Barcode is not valid you should check the number, only Barcodes listed on the Matrix tab for an item are valid. Under the Price field enter in the price you wish this item to be sold for at the PoS. Click the Save button when done. Use the icons to make changes where necessary.

title: Multi Buy with Price Per Item
text: This promotion allows you to set a quantity price per unit when the unit(s) are bought in multiples, similar to price breaks. For example, your item's price is 15 for a single unit. If the customer purchases two of these items the price reduces to 13 per unit and if the customer wishes to buy three items the price per unit reduces to 11. The items applied to this promotion are specified in the Item Bundle list. Under the Steps section click the + button. Enter the Quantity as the number of units needed to trigger the new price, then enter the price per unit. If you use multiple currencies then you should enter a price for each currency. Click the Save button when done. Use the icons to make changes where necessary.

title: POS Options
text: The PoS Admin - POS Options menu should be used in preference to this menu, Admin will be removed in future releases and will not be accessible In this section, you can control various behaviours within the POS (Point of Sale) system. Please select the specific location for which you want to make changes. Once you have made the desired changes, click on "Save".
