Hide last sale details when the clerk is logged out - When a clerk logs out, the Last Sale Total and Change will display as 0.00 instead of showing the actual amounts. Hide chart on POS - The sales chart on the POS log-on screen will not be shown. Ask if the customer will receive a receipt as mail - When enabled, the clerk will have the option to email a receipt in addition to the POS automatically printing it. If a customer is selected and has a valid email address, the receipt will be sent to that email address when the clerk presses the 'Email Receipt' button. If this option is unchecked, a receipt will be printed automatically, but the clerk will not have the option to email it, regardless of whether a customer is selected or not. Please note that this option is overridden by the "The receipt should be emailed instead of printed as default" option, which always offers an email receipt option. The receipt should be emailed instead of printed as default - When enabled, the POS will not automatically print a receipt. The clerk will have the ability to manually print a receipt or send an email receipt, but not both. This option takes precedence over the "Ask if the customer will receive a receipt as mail" option by always offering an email receipt option. Stay logged in after finished sale - After completing a sale, the clerk will remain logged in without being prompted for their login details again. The clerk must manually log out if stepping away from the POS. Automatically aggregate identical item lines in a transaction - When this option is checked, items with the same barcode will be listed as a single line on the POS. The receipt will also display a single line with the total quantity. Allow overcharging of payment cards - Enabling this option allows for surcharges to be added to the receipt for payment cards. Only managers can do returns - By checking this option, only managers will be able to authorize returns or perform transactions that require management credentials. Refer to @ Clerk for more information. POS Discount Buttons - Use these options to customize the discount buttons on the POS according to your requirements. For more details, see Line Discount. Remember to click Save to apply and save any changes you have made.

title: Expansions
text: The PoS Admin - Expansion menu should be used in preference to this menu, Admin will be removed in future releases and will not be accessible Introduction: The Expansion framework, accessed through the Admin > Expansions Module, allows for the configuration of third-party extensions. Typically, your K3 representative will handle the setup of these extensions if needed. The Expansion Framework enables the integration of external extensions hosted outside of the Imagine platform, providing additional functionality beyond what is currently offered by Imagine. It is primarily available for Self Serve and Simple POS applications. Typical Uses: One example of using the Expansion framework is during a transaction before payment is made. At this point, a unique identifier is sent to the third-party API, identifying the session and the basket. Imagine will open a window for the external services to interact with the user and await a completion message. The third-party application can perform custom actions, such as collecting additional information from the user or directly interacting with the Imagine basket object. Expansions offer the ability to incorporate additional functions that may not be relevant or accessible to the retailer directly. For instance, there might be a shop feature that requires K3 to set up and configure, but the retailer needs the capability to enable or disable the feature independently. Clean Cash: If Clean Cash is enabled for the tenant and shop, you can enable or disable it within the Expansion framework. Please refer to the Clean Cash notes for information on when it can be temporarily disabled.

title: Vendor Return
text: Vendor Return is used to transfer unwanted or damaged stock back to Vendors or otherwise out of the business. The Vendor Return List shows an initial list of returns in progress, these can be filtered by shop, date range and status. NOTE: The list is sorted in descending order with the newest most recent displayed at the top. Status: Draft - Returns are in progress and can be edited. These items will have not been deducted from stock. It is possible to edit the Unit Cost value on a Draft vendor return, however, the edited Unit Cost only effects this individual vendor return. The edited Unit Cost does not effect related totals outside this specific vendor return such as the Last Cost for example. Value for the item is not effected by any edits to the Unit Cost here. Status: Closed - Returns have been completed and deducted from stock. To create a new Return click the "Create New" this will take you to the below page. Give the return a title and add the item by scanning the barcode or clicking search. To Add items manually to a goods receipt you must not have selected to receive from a purchase order. You can add items in the following way: Scan a barcode - this will add the item to the grid, if the item already exists it will increment the quantity by 1 for each scan. Find Item Manually Clicking Find Items Manually will show the Add Items modal window. From this screen you can search items based upon any of the item properties. By entering a quantity or incrementing the quantity using the +/- buttons you can populate the grid. Once all item quantities have been set select Add Items to add them to the Goods Receipt. Progress can be saved at any time by clicking Save. If you wish to cancel the changes click Back. When complete, clicking Save and Commit will change the status to Closed and remove the items from stock. Download PDF will produce a PDF version of the return which may wish to print to a local printer or attach to an email.

title: How to setup Fiskaly
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Step 1 - Create Fiskaly API Keys Step 2 - K3 consultant to add the Fiskaly Shop Feature Step 3 - Connector Setup Step 4 - Create Purchaser Agency Setup Step 5 - Generate Settings Document Step 6 - K3 consultant to configure the Docker Compose file Setup To get started with Fiskaly, follow these steps to set up your account and integrate it with Imagine. You will need to speak to your K3 consultant to enable certain features, ensure you have made arrangements for this before starting this process. Step 1 - Create Fiskaly API Keys: 1. Create an account on Fiskaly at https://dashboard.fiskaly.com/. 2. Go to the "Settings" section and select "API Keys." 3. Click on "Create API Key" and provide a name for the API key. 4. Make note of the generated API Key and API Secret. Step 2 - K3 consultant to add the Fiskaly Shop Feature: Your K3 consultant will add a Shop Feature for you. They will need to know your Tenant Name or ID Let your K3 consultant know which shop(s) need Fiskaly setting up for. For each shop they will create a new shop feature with the Name, Type and Group of "fiscalization" with the following values: Name Type Key and Value Active boolean true microserviceurl string http://ms-fiskaly/api/v2.0/ apidetails string { "apiKey":"xxxx", "apiSecret":"xxxx", "vatRates": "20,5,0", "skipQRPrint":false, "ItemDescription":"Parameter2", "ItemId": "Parameter3" } NOTE: the following details are required to be passed to your K3 consultant [apiKey] - is the API Key as obtained in Step 1 [apiSecret] - is the API Secret as obtained in Step 1 [vatRates] - represents the VAT percentages used for VAT codes in Fiskaly. Where there are more than one rate these should be separated by a comma i.e. "20,5,0" for 20% 5% and 0% [skipQRPrint] - set skipQRPrint to true if you want to skip QR code generation and printing on the receipt. See the 'how to use Fiskaly' page [ItemDescription] - this value is "Parameter2" and is used to map item details from Imagine. No additional detail is required for this key [ItemId] - this value is "Parameter3" and is used to map item details from Imagine. No additional detail is required for this key Step 3 - Connector Setup: 1. In the POS Admin Module select "K3 Connector Manager" 2. Against each connector, you will find the TssGuid, Client Id, and a button to generate the Fiscalization ID. Click the button to generate the necessary IDs for Fiskaly for each desired connector. Step 4 - Create Purchaser Agency Setup: 1. In the Back Office Module select Fiskaly from the menu. 2. Click on the "Register Purchaser Agency" button to create a new Purchaser Agency. 3. Select the connector for which you want to create the Purchaser Agency. The address fields will be populated based on the assigned shop, but you can make changes if needed. 4. Fill in the remaining fields and click "Register Purchaser Agency" to create the record in Fiskaly. 5. End-of-day transactions will now be associated with this Purchaser Agency. Step 5 - Generate Settings Document: Once all connectors and purchaser agencies are registered, you can press "Settings Document" on the Fiskaly screen. This will generate a PDF document containing all the Fiskaly settings that have been created and set up. Step 6 - K3 consultant to configure the Docker Compose file: Your K3 consultant will need to access each connector associated with Fiskaly (Step 3 above) and check the configuration of the Docker Compose file used by the Connector. they will need to: 1. Ensure that the latest "DeviceWorker_DeviceGateway" image is used. 2. Add the following line to the environment variables for the "Deviceworker_DeviceGateway" section: NOTE: Replace [Name] with the appropriate value, and make sure to use the correct API URL. Name Value FiscalizationGwUrl ${API_URL}/Fiscalization/

title: How to use Fiskaly
text: Fiskaly Receipt Capture: When a transaction is completed at the point of sale (POS), a request is made to the printer for a receipt. If the shop feature for the connector is enabled, a request is sent to the Fiskaly system. The details of the fiscalization are then sent back to the connector and printed on the receipt, including a QR code that captures the required fiscalization information. The transaction details and captured data can be viewed on the Fiskaly Dashboard Transactions. End-of-Day Reporting: When the end-of-day process is triggered from the POS (Cash Statement), and if the fiscalization shop feature is enabled for the store, the cash statement details are also sent to the Fiskaly system. To access a screen displaying all submitted cash statements to Fiskaly, go to the Back Office Imagine Module and select the Fiskaly Screen from the top menu. If the Fiskaly shop feature is enabled, a screen will appear where you can choose a specific connector, set start and end dates (optional), and then press the search button to query the Fiskaly API and retrieve all end-of-day and export requests. To request a file export, simply click the Request Export Button at the top of the screen. A pop-up will appear allowing you to select the connector, start and end dates, and send the export request to Fiskaly. This will generate a queued export, and you can log into the Fiskaly portal to retrieve the download.

title: Widgets
text: Widgets are buttons within the POS that can be used for numerous different functions, such as: Price and Promotion Customers Stock Lookup Web Orders Article Statistics Customer Display Product Image Shop Logo SAFT Export Downpayment If you require a widget to be enabled, please contact K3 through your sales representative, or account manager, or by emailing your local support team. Widgets appear on the left-hand side when using a standard PC screen. On a mobile device or a small screen, the panel is converted into a button on the top bar. Tap to access the Widget menu. All the widgets are then displayed as a horizontal list of buttons. You can tap the icon of the widget you want to use. NOTE: The Revide widget is now deprecated and cannot be used within Imagine. If you need to integrate with Revide, please contact your K3 representative for further details. NOTE: The Price and Promotion Widget is a silent widget that processes your promotional rules as items are added to the basket. If the widget is not applied to your shop's POS, promotions will not take effect. Item prices set in PPE are not affected by this widget and will be applied irrespective of whether the Price and Promotion Widget is enabled or not. No configuration is required for this widget.

title: Add a New Customer
text: To add a New Customer use the Widget to the left. Select Search Customer. The page will display a list of current customers. To add a new customer click. Add the customer's credentials and click. NOTE: Pressing the Tab when inputting the information will jump you to the next line. NOTE: See Customers Module / Settings in regards to E.126 format. The + symbol is added automatically after the number is entered when the E126 setting is enabled. When you have entered the information press "+ ADD" This will assign the customer to the transaction. After creation, the customer's details can be managed in the Customers module.

title: Customers
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Customer Widget Adding a New Customer Adding a Customer Address Customer History Customer Widget When you first log in to the POS you will see the Customer widget on the left-hand side of the screen. You then have the option to find the customer by inputting the customer number and clicking Find Customer. Selecting the search customer option allows you to search through the list of customers. At the bottom, you have the options to cancel, reset, filter and add new customers. Adding a New Customer To add a New Customer use the Widget to the left. Select Search Customer. The page will display a list of current customers. To add a new customer click Add the customer's credentials and click NOTE: Pressing the Tab when inputting the information will jump you to the next line. NOTE: See Customers Module / Settings in regards to E.126 format. The + symbol is added automatically after the number is entered when the E126 setting is enabled. When you have entered the information press this will assign the customer to the transaction. After creation, the customer's details can be managed in the Customers module. Adding a Customer Address With a customer attached to a transaction, within the widget menu select Shipping Address / Add new address, Fill in the Customers information as required. NOTE: Fields with * are required. By clicking this button, the selected address will be assigned as the customer's delivery address. This will cancel and close the page. Customer History When a customer is attached to a transaction you can view their purchase history by selecting This displays the list of receipts attached to the selected customer. Along the bottom of the window are some further options: Pressing this will cancel out the history view This allows you to filter the receipt history based on date, search string and whether to Search all stores. By default this displays 10 receipts,this option will load the next 10.

title: Stock Info
text: The Stock info widget shows stock quantity figures across the whole set of related variants. This is useful to see which variants you have low stock of in order to re-stock the shop by. Or to advise a customer if they cannot find the exact variant they are looking for, which alternatives you have in your shop. In contrast, the Article Statistic widget shows current quantity values for the item selected in the PoS. These statistics match the same values shown in Inventory - Figures. The key use of the Article Statistic widget is to see a specific items quantities across a range of metrics over a range of shops. This is useful for a customer who is looking for a particular sized and coloured item that you do not have in stock, but you can advise of other shops that may have it. In use, when adding an item to your transaction in the POS, the Widget panel will provide you with the currently available quantity for that particular item. For example, if you see "Stock (0200000002336)," it means that you are using the Stock widget, and the barcode for the item is "0200000002336." This information displays the amount of stock you currently have in each store (on hand), including offline stock or stock in transit. For more detailed inventory figures and statistics for this specific item, you can refer to the Article Statistic widget. You can utilise the Shops and Variants button to see other variants related to this item and their stock quantities. It allows you to also view the corresponding values in a Matrix Grid across all your shops. To see another shop you should choose from the list provided above the matrix grid. Note: only active shops will show their stock. Inactive shops will not appear in the list. Note: any inactive items will not display a quantity, like the Small Blue variant in example here. In contrast, all Large variants simply have no stock in the Brighton shop currently but are active items.

title: Web Orders
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Web Orders Print the Last Pick List Dispatch Note Web Orders Web Orders - These are dependent on an eCommerce provider managing web orders through the Imagine Public API. It assumes this work has been performed already and this document refers exclusively to the Widget operation in the POS. If the order is "Click and Collect" as in it is already fully paid, the order should be posted to us with a 0 price. If the order is "Pay On Collection" the order should have the price posted with it so the payment can be processed through the POS. To see a list of your web orders, press the button on the widget. The POS will then list all your open Web Orders. Tap the order and it will display the customer details and items for that web order. You have 3 options available. Print Picklist - See Print Picklist for details. Skip - Press this if the items are not available, or you are unable to fulfil the order. Add To Basket - Press this to progress through the order. Once the order is in the basket, you can complete the transaction like you would any other sale - including if the price is 0. Print Last Pick List The picklist is used to gather all items together for a customer web order on the POS. After clicking on the Print Pick list from the list of orders, a full preview of the order will be displayed including the quantity ordered and the number available in stock. From the Pick List preview you can Print as Receipt - This will print the item details and quantities on a picklist to the receipt printer Print to A4 - This will create an A4-sized preview and allow printing to any A4 printer available to the client. Dispatch Note After payment is completed in addition to the normal receipt options, a button will be displayed to print a dispatch note. Tapping this will display a preview of the dispatch note. This dispatch note can be printed to any A4 printer available to the client. Re-Print Dispatch Note The dispatch note can be reprinted at any time from the Find Receipt function. The Dispatch Note Footer can be edited in Admin Receipt Setup.

title: Article Statistic
text: The Article Statistic widget shows current quantity values for the item selected in the PoS. These statistics match the same values shown in Inventory - Figures. The key use of this widget is to see a specific items quantities across a range of metrics over a range of shops. This is useful for a customer who is looking for a particular sized and coloured item that you do not have in stock, but you can advise of other shops that may have it. In contrast, the Stock info widget shows stock quantity figures across the whole set of related variants. This is useful to see which variants you have low stock of in order to re-stock the shop by. Or to advise a customer if they cannot find the exact variant they are looking for, which alternative you have in your shop. Within this widget you are able to see article statistics for your shop or for another shop. Select the desired shop from the drop down menu and the statistics will be updated automatically. Quantity In Transit The number of units in transit between shops, awaiting completion of the transfer. Specifically, this is the quantity of items that have been transferred out from the shop but have not been received at the 'transfer in' shop. Once the receiving shop has transferred this item(s) in then the stock is no longer deemed as 'In Transit'. Quantity On Hand The number of units currently in stock, including Reserved but excluding Offline. Quantity On Purchase Orders The number of units requested from a vendor but not yet delivered. Quantity Reserved The number of units reserved for customer collections, such as web orders. Note: see the Item Figures page for more details about the figures given on this widget

title: Customer Display
text: If you are using hardware which has a secondary display you can have the Customer Display widget enabled. Pressing the button will pop open a new window for your custom display and will be formatted in line with the settings you perform in Admin. If you are using Google Chrome you can install our Chrome extension which will automatically pop the window to the right screen.

title: Product Image
text: The Product Image Widget displays an image of the product when set up via in the Image Media Library. Tapping the image will show a bigger version of the image in the main receipt panel

title: Shop Logo
text: The Shop Logo widget will display the logo defined against your shop as configured in the Backoffice module. No additional configuration is required.

title: SAFT Export
text: The SAFT export will only display on the POS if the Norway fiscalization has been enabled. To perform an export from the Imagine POS go to the top right ellipsis. From the menu choose. The POS window will now display the Print SAFT Report Screen, which is presented below: To generate the report, follow these steps: Select the desired Start Date and Finish Date. Please note that the reports run from the Start Date at 00:00:00 to the day after the End Date at 00:00:00. So, if you want to include the End Date in the report, set the end date 1 day forward. Enter the Company Name in the designated field. Click on the "Download" button. The report will be generated with a file name in the following format: SAF-T Cash Register_MVA_{DateTime).xml.

title: Downpayment
text: The Down Payment widget will be accessible once it has been assigned to the relevant shop through the Platform Admin > Tenants > Widgets Tab. Once added, users will be able to create and complete bookings directly from the POS. To process a booking in the POS, follow these steps: Select "New Booking" using the widget on the left side. The POS interface will turn pink, indicating that you are now in the Down Payment process. You will be directed to the customer page. Here, you can input the customer's email address or membership card number if available. NOTE: If the customer doesn't exist in your system, you can add a new customer. Enter the customer's email or membership details and confirm. Select the billing address associated with the customer. NOTE: If the customer requires a different address for delivery, use the "Add Address" button. Shipment Settings screen: Home Delivery: This option selects the delivery address from the previous screen. If unticked, the delivery fee will no longer be required. Allow Partial Delivery: When ticked, it allows the customer to receive a partial delivery if the supplier/seller has limited stock at the time. The rest of the items will be delivered once a new purchase order is received. Lease: When ticked, it indicates that the customer and seller have an agreement for monthly payments on the received goods. Delivery Fee: Specify the amount to charge the customer for delivery. Delivery Date: Enter the scheduled delivery date. Delivery Before Date: Check this box if the customer is willing to receive the delivery before the set delivery date. Order Note: Add any additional notes to the order. Once you have filled in the Shipment Settings, click OK> The shipment will now appear in the transaction line, along with the delivery cost (if applicable). Click the "Save Booking" button. You will be prompted to confirm the down payment. Upon confirming, you will be taken to a page where you can input the amount for the down payment. Select the billing address from the widget menu on the left. Choose the address already in the system or add a new one using the "Add Address" button. You will be redirected to the transaction page, where you can process the payment.

title: Accessing Top
text: TOP (Table Ordering Platform) is specifically designed for consumer self-service, allowing customers to access it by scanning a unique QR code or tapping an NFC tag. The QR code or NFC tag contains a URL that redirects them to the TOP application, carrying all the necessary identifiable information, such as the tenant, location, and table number. For detailed information on URL and QR code generation, please refer to the "Self-Serve Admin Shops" section, which provides comprehensive instructions on how to generate these unique codes. It's important to note that without setting up a supported Payment Provider, TOP functionality will be unavailable. To enable TOP and configure the appropriate Payment Provider, please consult the "Payment Providers" section for step-by-step instructions and further details.

title: Home View
text: Upon scanning a QR code or visiting the URL, users will be directed to the Home View within the TOP application. The Home View serves as the central hub for customers to browse and select the items they wish to order through TOP. To streamline the ordering process, the TOP application always presents the Landing Group of the selected store as the starting point for navigation. This hierarchical structure and navigation can be expanded and customized according to specific requirements using the Composer Groups functionality within Visual Composer. This allows for a tailored and personalized user experience, enhancing the efficiency and flexibility of the ordering process. You can choose to drill into the subgroups (black tiles) to see another layer of the hierarchy, or you can use the +/- buttons to add your items to the basket. If you press the + on an item which is a Bundle or has Modifiers, you will be asked to make your selections before adding to the basket. TOP is aware of your current stock levels. So if you run out of stock it will display Sold Out on the Tile and will be unavailable for selection by a customer. There are various ways a customer can navigate the page. Icon Name Function Search Bar Users can utilize the Search bar to quickly find specific items they wish to add to their basket. By entering relevant keywords or item names, users can easily locate and select desired items, enhancing the efficiency of the ordering process. On Screen Navigation If you have Bundle Groups set up, you will see navigation buttons appear when in those groups. For example Home > Drinks > Pepsi / Sprite / Coke. you can use this to return to the Home Screen or a section by selecting the POS. Information Button This button will show the user your Terms and Conditions, FAQ, Delivery Information and Privacy Policy if you have them configured. Table Number It also displays the Table number which it extracts from the scanned URL. Product Information By tapping on the tile with the "i" symbol, users can access the supplementary information and explore any available Bundle Groups or Modifiers associated with the selected item, enhancing their overall ordering experience and allowing for further customization. Basket Button Tapping the basket button allows you to review and verify the items in your basket, ensuring accuracy and making any necessary adjustments if needed. Once you have confirmed the contents of your basket, you can proceed to the payment stage, where you will be prompted to complete the transaction.

title: Items / Bundles / Modifiers
text: When you add a Bundle or Modifiable item to your basket, you will be prompted to make the relevant selections before adding them to the basket. If your Bundle main item has Modifiers linked to it, it will automatically take you to the Modifiers tab if you wish to make any alterations. Non-bundled items with Modifiers will only show you the Modifiers. The min max rule for selections is displayed next to the Modifier title, You will also see any additional prices for the modifiers. Modifications that you make get printed on the order confirmation slip and also make their way through to the Order Status Display to be used in the order preparation area. NOTE: You can also add manually entered comments against the line too. Modifications and Comments that you apply make their way through to the Order Status Display to be used in the order preparation area.

title: Basket / Payment
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Basket Payment Basket The Basket screen is a listing of all of your items, along with any bundle selections and modifiers you have made. They are grouped, so if you have made more than one item with the same selections and modifiers they will be on the same basket line. It denotes the extended price of the basket line and also displays the quantity multiplied by the single item price. Icon Name Function Edit Line You can use the pencil icon for the basket line to make alterations to that line (change modifiers or bundle selections) Delete Line Use the trash can icon to remove the line from the basket Delete Basket Use the black trash can next to the Pay button to clear the basket and return to the start screen Continue Button Use the Continue button to proceed to the payment phase. Payment Pressing the Continue button will then ask you for your email address and optionally some other parameters which vary between payment providers and partner extensions. If the payment is successful, then it means that the payment has been made and the transaction has been submitted to Imagine's backend for onward processing. After confirming the order, TOP will initiate the following actions: Submit the order to the Order Status Display (OSD): The order details will be sent to the OSD, enabling staff to process and prepare the order efficiently. Display the order number: A unique order number will be generated and displayed on the screen. This order number serves as a reference for tracking and can be used in both the OSD and ORB. Email order confirmation and receipt: TOP will automatically send an email to the customer, containing an order confirmation and receipt. The email will include the order number, and selected bundle choices, and applied modifiers, ensuring transparency and providing a record of the transaction. Provide estimated waiting time: The application calculates an estimated waiting time based on the order throughput over the last 15 minutes. This feature helps manage customer expectations by providing an approximate timeframe for order preparation. These functionalities aim to streamline the ordering process, enhance communication between staff and customers, and provide a smooth and satisfying user experience.

title: Customer documentation for K3 MStore TOP
text: Imagine and MStore K3Topsync Customer guide TABLE OF CONTENTS 1.Description 2.Imagine TOP (Table Order and Pay functions) 3.MStore side setup 4. K3TopSynch 5. Operation 6. Advice on functionality 1.Description The TOP (Table Order and Pay) Imagine application has been integrated to MStore so that it can be used as a cloud based Portal point of sale for Café/Resturant situations. This will allow customers to scan a QR code using a mobile device or smart phone which then opens a Shop related to the MStore site. Orders can be paid for online, this then creates orders in MStore specifically assigned to a Till MStore side which are then visualised on both Food prep/Kitchen and Customer facing order boards. The desired MStore items which need to exisit in Imagine TOP are marked in MStore and synchronised to Imagine via the K3TopSynch application which synchronises both Items and Transactions from TOP. There is also Membership integration where Members can validate their number to receive a membership discount on the order based on an overall percentage that is assigned in MStore Membership privileges Imagine discount percentage. 2.Imagine TOP (Table Order and Pay functions) Imagine is accessed through the customer Portal where the SelfServe Modules will have been configured and customised for the application. Imagine Portal Https://Portal.K3Imagine.com Within the Backoffice the Modules associated with TOP will be visible as below. Shop A shop can now be setup in the Backoffice/Shops Module as below example. An Email address should be included in the shop setup above as this will provide a forwarding address from which the TOP emailed receipts can be sent from Imagine. Ideally a noreply for customer purposes. Payment Provider (Self Serve Admin) A complete help link below to customer knowledge base is below. https://support.k3btg.com/en/support/solutions/articles/103000262086-stripe-setup-for-top The Stripe Payment provider will be registered by the customer The Webhook and Secret keys are provided by the registration process. https://dashboard.stripe.com/register Visual Composer A complete guide to setting up the Tiles for the online shop can accessed using the link below. https://support.k3btg.com/en/support/solutions/folders/103000304183 Accessed from SelfServe Admin Module this is where we setup the visual tiles that build the shop which is what the customer sees as a point of purchase. Example Here is what can be composed as a customer facing shop Product Configurator This is where the Items within Imagine Self Serve can be priced for promotion. This is also where the Modifier Groups are setup for the shop basket and checkout page. Here is the link to Imagine online help for detailed functionality. Example of where modifiers are shown in image below. https://support.k3btg.com/en/support/solutions/folders/103000304181 TOP (Table order and pay) Shop A QR code can now be generated which will create a url that loads the TOP shop visual pages. This can be accessed from Self Serve Admin/Shops as below. Functionality on Self Serve Admin can be found here in the Imagine online help. This is also where the Visual profiles to each of the shops can be assigned as well as Timeslots. These are explained in the online help link below. https://support.k3btg.com/en/support/solutions/articles/103000050221-top-tables 3.MStore side setup MStore Backoffice settings A Till will be setup in MStore backoffice Tills configuration an example as below. Bearing in mind printers/Depts may differ for specific customers. The Till type has to be set as “Handheld Table Ordering” Items which are required to be synched to Imagine TOP will need to be marked in MStore as example below. There is Membership Discount feature in the integration which allows members to have a set discount percentage applied to a TOP transaction. This discount is applied specifically to the member and does not allow varying discount percentages to be Item or Analysis code specific. Example setting as below in MStore backoffice membership types The membership discount/validation feature is displayed in the Basket section of the Imagine TOP as below and can be skipped if not required. MStore Order boards and customer Order Ready Boards. Although Imagine does have it’s own set of Order boards for both prep and customer these are not used for the MStore setup. MStore has it’s own applications for this purpose and since the MStore customer may also have Orders created in house on the MStore system outside of the Imagine TOP it makes sense that both in house MStore and Imagine TOP are displayed together rather than on separate boards, therefore we use the MStore applications for this purpose. PkitchenDisplay This is the board that displays the prep/Kitchen orders that are generated from both MStore (in house) and TOP. It’s configuration is set in the MStore.ini file located in C:\programdata\merac and as can be seen below defines rows, column sizes,Dept, Prep area and font size. The Dept for each customer will be the related dept set in MStore Backoffice for this example we can see that the Till 7000 is set to Sootys Diner Dept which is 47. The KitchenOrderPrep value 1 is set as the initial prep area defined in the K3Topsync settings. Example of PKitchenDisplay, clicking into the order let’s you progress the order and also print if required to kitchen printer or quit. FoodOrderDisplay This is the customer facing board which takes it’s settings from C:\Program Files\Merac\FoodOrderDisplay.exe.config This is an xml file which will be setup as part of the implementation. This will display as below 4. K3TopSynch K3TopSync v1.01 is an application which integrates MStore with the K3|TOP online selling portal. Using the K3TOPSYNC application When launching the program normally, you get the option to sync products or transactions. For a transaction sync, you must choose a date range. The program defaults to yesterday. You should not download “today’s” transactions unless you are sure there will be no more transactions, otherwise a duplicate cashdrawer would be created. You can choose a date span if you like. Any transactions already downloaded will be ignored. Once all transactions are downloaded, the program runs a database procedure which created cashdrawers for each new day with transactions. When syncing products, any PLU which has been ticked to go to K3|TOP will be uploaded. If the product already exists in K3|TOP, its record will be updated. Configuration changes to K3TopSynch can be made from Tools/Configuration These settings will have been set during implementation but it is possible that Polling times may want to be modified to optomise orders. E.g. 5. Operation a: Create all Items in MStore including complete meals and modifiers. b: For purposes of membership check Imagine discount settings in membership priviledge schemes in MStore. c: Run the K3 K3Topsync app and it will create the Items in Imagine that have been marked as Imagine in MStore. d: Load the TOP store in either a browser or a mobile using the shop QR code or url generated in SelfServe Admin/Shops e: Make a purchase using the TOP app and wait for the K3TopSync polling to finish synching transactions. f: Run the PKitchen.exe and check the order has appeared also check the Foodorderdisplay.exe board to show “preparing” now complete the order in the PKitchen.exe display, Foodorderdisplay changes to “Please Collect” g: The assigned TOP Till in MStore can be finalized as normal MStore operations. 6. Advice on functionality Not all of the Imagine Self Serve functionality applies to this implementation. TOP is purely meant to be used as a selling portal to MStore items. Bundles and Bundle Groups functionality will not be synched back to MStore and is therefore redundant. Any bundled items or meals need to be created in MStore. Imagine order boards could be used but crucially will only show Imagine orders and not orders created in MStore. TOP Timeslot functionality does work and affects the MStore order boards. Item descriptions in MStore are taken from the extended description and synched to the description in Imagine TOP to allow greater flexibility. Membership discounting is on a transaction level and so applies a fixed percentage to the transaction and doesn’t work in the same way that MStore discounts do where they can be applied at a Item and Analysis code level.

title: Functionality
text: The Order Status display is designed to use on an internal display this then allows the staff to view and move orders along the order flow. This is currently shown in 3 columns: Pending - This is a new order which has not been started processing yet. Does not appear in the ORB. In Progress - This is an order currently being processed (Orders in this state will show in the ORB as In Progress) Ready - This is an order which is ready (Orders in this state will show in the ORB as Ready) Orders will always display chronology, so the oldest orders will be nearest to the top. Order Details An order will show the items and quantities that you will need to prepare, including items, bundles (bundle groups) and modifiers these are shown in a sequence to help you understand what needs to be bundled together. At the top of the order, you will see the Order Reference Caption (Which is configured on a per-app, per-location basis) and the Order Reference. However, if you change your order since placement the Caption will not be changed. The Order Reference itself can vary depending on the front-end application. Kiosk This uses the Imagine Order No. This is also printed on the receipt and shown on the screen when the order is placed. TOP This uses the table number for where the customer is sitting. POP This uses the order number that is given on-screen when the order is placed and emailed to the customer. Delivery/collect in-store This is shown in the top right and indicated with icons. Time Slot If you have Time Slots enabled and it is a POP order, it may display the time slot information. Order No This is always included regardless of implementation and may be used just as an order reference. Order Age A timer since the order was placed. Employee Will displays the application name that the order originated from and the employee name. Order Date Time The actual date and time the order was placed. Print Order This will print the order to a desktop printer if installed. The printout shows details for the whole order, not just the parts of the order associated with the current Display Category. To close an order it should be moved to the right from the Ready column, any closed orders will no longer show on the ORB.

title: Processing Orders
text: Use the Arrows in the card header to bump the order between the statuses. The order genially will flow from left to right. Pending - When an order is placed it will be sat in pending, you then move this order to In Progress when someone has begun assembling/cooking the items. If for some reason the order needs to be cancelled you can move it to the left, doing this will permanently remove the order without the option of recovery. In Progress - When an order is In Progress this means the assembly/cooking of the items has begun, it can be moved to Ready when completed. You can either move the order to the left to put it back into Pending this will remove it from the ORB. Ready - When an order is marked as "Ready," it usually means the customer has received or can collect their order. If a mistake occurs and the order is not ready, you can change its status back to "In Progress." Once the customer has received the order, you can move it to the appropriate category, indicating successful processing. After the order has been moved, it will be removed from the system without any possibility of recovery. OSD Actions There are 4 buttons in the bottom right corner of the screen which allow you to perform specific actions on the OSD. By default, the OSD will display all orders up to the "current" time slot. If you want to see all orders for upcoming timings then you can toggle the button between them.

title: Time Slot Management
text: On occasion, throughout the day the order processing team might need to override the Time Slot Settings for the POP. For example, if they have just had a large influx of walk-in orders they can use the button to access the override settings for each slot. Open - This means the slot is open and that not all the pre-configured time slots are filled. it shows you how many of them have been filled next to the time slot. Closed - This means that the timeslot is closed and no orders can be placed for that time slot. Full - This means that all available orders for a time slot have been filled. Override - This means that the timeslot has a non-standard amount of orders it can take. You can press the Open, Close, or Override buttons to perform the actions required. Below shows you how you can set a new number of orders for a given slot.

title: Display Catagories
text: The OSD (Order Status Display) can be customized to show specific sections of order by using the Display Category feature. By selecting certain categories, the OSD will display only those categories that have been configured to be shown. This functionality allows for orders to be organized and divided based on workstations or specific categories such as Bar and Kitchen, or Starters, Mains, and Desserts. These categories are set up within the Product Configurator, where they are associated with individual items. To update the displayed information on the OSD, you can use the "Refresh Display" option. This retrieves the latest data from the system, which can be particularly useful in situations where there have been internet connectivity or outage issues.

title: Home
text: We offer a range of generic reports within Imagine, including: 1. Overview 2. Index 3. Employee 4. Top List 5. Stock 6. Financial Stock Please note that the employee report is the only one that includes Gift Voucher sales. All other reports mentioned above exclude Gift Voucher sales from their results. Each of these reports operates as a task. When you choose to generate a report, the browser will continuously check the task service to determine if the report is ready. In the meantime, a screen will display the following: Once the report is ready, it will be presented on the screen for your review. Furthermore, on the report screen, you have the option to provide an email address, as shown below. If you enter an email address, you are not required to remain on the screen while the report generates. Once the report is ready, you will receive an email containing a link to view the report.

title: Sales Analysis
text: The Sales Analysis feature enables you to examine sales data based on different breakdowns. You can choose to break down the data by the following categories: 1. Store: This option allows you to analyze sales data specific to each store. 2. Clerk: You can view sales data attributed to individual clerks or salespersons. 3. Hierarchy: This breakdown provides an analysis of sales data based on hierarchical categories, such as departments or product categories. 4. Item: You can analyze sales data for specific items or products. In addition to selecting the breakdown category, you also have the flexibility to choose how the results are presented. You can view the sales analysis based on: 1. Quantity: This option shows the sales data in terms of the quantity of items sold. 2. Value: You can see the sales data represented by the total value or revenue generated. 3. Profit: This choice displays the sales data in terms of the profit obtained from the sales. With these options, you can gain valuable insights into sales performance and analyze the data from various perspectives to make informed decisions.

title: Weekly Sales
text: The Weekly Sales report enables you to compare sales data on a weekly basis. You can analyze and compare sales performance across different weeks. The report provides the flexibility to break down the data by the following categories: 1. Store: This option allows you to analyze weekly sales data for each individual store. 2. Clerk: You can view the weekly sales data attributed to specific clerks or salespersons. 3. Hierarchy: This breakdown provides an analysis of weekly sales data based on hierarchical categories, such as departments or product categories. Furthermore, you can choose to view the results of the Weekly Sales report using the following metrics: 1. Quantity: This option displays the sales data in terms of the quantity of items sold during each week. 2. Value: You can see the sales data represented by the total value or revenue generated for each week. 3. Profit: This choice shows the sales data in terms of the profit obtained from the sales during each week. By utilizing these options, you can effectively track and compare weekly sales performance across different categories, gaining insights into trends and identifying areas for improvement or further analysis.

title: Financial Report
text: The Financial Report feature allows you to analyze transactions by breakdowns within a single store and a specified date range. Here's how it works: Filter: - Store: You can select a specific store for which you want to generate the report. - Include inactive shops: This option allows you to include inactive shops in the report if enabled. - Start date: Specify the start date of the date range for the report. - End date: Specify the end date of the date range for the report. - Refresh: Clicking this button will update the report based on the selected filters and date range. Result: The generated report will provide breakdowns for the following categories: 1. Total Sales: This represents the total sales amount for the selected date range. 2. Average Basket: This indicates the average amount per transaction. 3. Transaction Analysis: A breakdown of different transaction types, such as sales, returns, and exchanges. 4. Discount Analysis: A breakdown of the total and line discounts applied during the specified period. 5. Discount Reason Code Analysis: A list of discount codes used in transactions. 6. Return Analysis: Detailed information on returns processed. 7. Cash Statements: Provides details of cash statements processed within the specified date range. 8. Payment Methods: A list of payment methods used, along with the number of transactions and corresponding totals. 9. Time Analysis: Breakdown of transactions, items, and totals grouped by the time of day (hourly). 10. Tax Analysis: A breakdown of the amount collected based on tax rates. By utilizing the Financial Report feature with the provided filters, you can gain comprehensive insights into transaction details, sales performance, discounts, payment methods, and more for a specific store within a specified date range.

title: Customer Turnover
text: The Customer Turnover feature allows you to analyze your customer base within a specified date range. To get started, you can use the "from" and "to" date filters. You have the flexibility to select dates from the calendar or manually enter specific date ranges. Additionally, there are two toggles available to further refine the report: 1. Only Include Active Customers Toggle: - When set to ON: The report will only include your current active customers, excluding inactive customers. - When set to OFF: The report will display both inactive and active customers. 2. Only Include Customers with Turnover Toggle: - When set to ON: The report will include customers who have actively made purchases from your store within the selected date range. - When set to OFF: The report will include all customers, including those who have not made any purchases from your store. Once you have selected your desired options, click the "Load Report" button. This action will generate the report on the screen, presenting you with the analyzed customer turnover data based on your specified filters. By utilizing this feature, you can gain insights into customer activity and track customer turnover over time, helping you make informed decisions and tailor your strategies to improve customer retention and engagement.

title: Transaction Report
text: The Transaction Report feature allows you to view a list of transactions with the ability to apply filters based on store, date, and receipt number. Here's how it works: Filter: - Store: You can select one or more stores from which you want to generate the report. - Receipt No. Contains: This option allows you to filter transactions based on receipt numbers that contain a specific value. - Start date: Specify the start date of the date range for the report. - End date: Specify the end date of the date range for the report. - Search: Clicking this button will apply the selected filters and search for transactions. Result: Once the filters and date range have been set, clicking the "Load Report" button will display the report. The report will show 10 results at a time and can be navigated to view additional transactions. Example Transaction: The report will present transactions with the following information: Headers: - Date: The transaction date. - Store: The store ID that processed the transaction. - POS: The POS ID that processed the transaction. - Receipt No.: The receipt number associated with the transaction. - Clerk: The clerk who processed the transaction. - Receipt Barcode: The barcode assigned to the receipt. - Connector: Additional connector information. - Customer: The ID of the customer linked to the transaction. Lines: - Item/Voucher/Web Order/Group/Set Description: Description of the sale line, depending on the type of transaction. - Item Number: The item number if applicable. - Item Group ID: The item group ID for the item if applicable. - Item Retail Price: The retail price of the item. - Quantity Sold: The quantity sold. - Total Inc Tax: The total amount including tax (Sold Price * Quantity). - Total Excl Tax: The total amount excluding tax. - Tax Rate %: The tax rate percentage. - Discount Amount: The amount of discount applied. Below the transaction lines, you will see the total amount of the transaction, followed by the payment method and the corresponding amount. To view more transactions, you can load the next 10 results by pressing the "Load More Transactions" button. This button will become inactive (greyed out) when no more results are available for the selected date range. By utilizing the Transaction Report feature with the provided filters, you can access detailed information about transactions, including dates, stores, receipt numbers, items, quantities, prices, discounts, and payment details.

title: Promotions Report
text: The Promotions Report feature allows you to analyze your Promotions within a specified date range. To get started, you can use the "from" and "to" date filters. You have the flexibility to select dates from the calendar or manually enter specific date ranges. Additionally, there are 4 other fields available to further refine the report: Promotions Name/Code: The Promotions Name/Code refers to the unique identifier or name assigned to a specific promotion. It helps to distinguish and identify different promotions within the system. Shop: Refers to a specific retail location or store where the promotion is applicable select the required shop from the drop down. Vendor: Refers to the supplier or manufacturer of the products involved in the promotions select the required vendor from the drop down list. Hierarchy Node: Refers to a specific level or category within a hierarchical structure select the required from the drop down. Once you have selected your desired options, click the "Load Report" button. This action will generate the report on the screen, presenting you with the analyzed Promotions data based on your specified filters. By utilizing the Promotions report, you can analyze data related to different promotions. Apply filters based on shops, promotions, and vendors to narrow down the results. Group the data as needed and explore the report grid and KPI graphs to gain insights into the effectiveness of promotions.

title: Overview
text: The Overview feature allows you to view sales data based on a specified date range while also providing the ability to apply filters and group the results. Here's how it works: Filter: To add a filter, click on the "Add New Filter" button. The filter options include: - Shop - Master Items - Vendor - Hierarchy - Attributes Once you select a filter option, you can choose an operator from the following: - is equal to - is not equal to - starts with - ends with - contains - does not contain You can also add a constraint to further refine the filter. For example, you can exclude a shop named "Manchester". Multiple filters can be added by clicking the "+" button, and filters can be removed using the "-" button. Group By: The Group By toggles allow you to group the filtered results. You can select up to 4 groups, and the hierarchy of the groups can be adjusted by dragging and dropping them. For example, you can group by shop first and then by master item. Date Range: Specify the date range for the report. The default is the past month from the current date to the current date. You can select a start and end date within a 10-year period. A calendar is provided for selecting dates, and you can also choose today's date. Generate: Once you have selected the filters, grouping, and date range, clicking the "Generate" button will display the report in two sections. Report Grid: The report grid presents the data. It includes headings such as turnover, discount amount, return amount, turnover excluding tax, gross profit, gross profit percentage, number of sales, number of articles sold, average price of articles sold, average articles in the basket, and average basket amount. You can download the report as a CSV file. Graphs: The second section displays KPI graphs. The top graph shows financial KPIs, and hovering over the lines will display the chart figures. The bottom graph represents statistics KPIs, and hovering over the lines will display the corresponding figures. You can print or download the charts in various formats using the hamburger icon. With the Overview feature, you can analyze and visualize sales data within a specified date range, apply filters based on different criteria, group the results, and obtain valuable insights through the report grid and KPI graphs.

title: Index
text: The Index feature allows you to view sales data based on a specified date range, with comparisons to the same time period from the previous year. You can also apply filters and group the results. Here's how it works: Filter: To add a filter, click on the "Add New Filter" button. The filter options include: - Shop - Master Items - Vendor Once you select a filter option, the operator "contains" is applied. You can add a constraint to further refine the filter. For example, you can exclude the shop named "Manchester". Multiple filters can be added by clicking the "+" button, and filters can be removed using the "-" button. Group By: The Group By toggles allow you to group the filtered results. You can select up to 4 groups, and the hierarchy of the groups can be adjusted by dragging and dropping them. For example, you can group by shop first and then by master item. Date Range: Specify the date range for the report. The default is the past month from the current date to the current date. You can select a start and end date within a 10-year period. A calendar is provided for selecting dates, and you can also choose today's date. Generate: Once you have selected the filters, grouping, and date range, clicking the "Generate" button will display the report in two sections. Report Grid: The report grid presents the data. It includes headings such as turnover, turnover from the previous year, turnover index (turnover divided by turnover from the previous year), gross profit, gross profit from the previous year, gross profit index, gross profit percentage, gross profit percentage from the previous year, purchase value, purchase value from the previous year, purchase index, end-of-period (EOP) stock, EOP stock from the previous year, and EOP index (EOP stock divided by EOP stock from the previous year). You can download the report as a CSV file. Graphs: The second section displays KPI graphs. The top graph shows financial KPIs, and hovering over the lines will display the chart figures. The bottom graph represents statistics KPIs, and hovering over the lines will display the corresponding figures. You can print or download the charts in various formats using the hamburger icon. By utilizing the Index feature, you can analyze sales data within a specified date range, compare it to the previous year, apply filters based on different criteria, group the results, and obtain valuable insights through the report grid and KPI graphs.

title: Employee
text: The Employee feature allows you to view sales data based on a specified date range, split by employees. You can also apply filters and group the results. Here's how it works: Filter: To add a filter, click on the "Filter" button. The filter options include: - Shop - Master Items - Vendor - Hierarchy - Attributes Once you select a filter option, you can choose an operator such as "is equal to," "contains," "starts with," etc. You can add a constraint to further refine the filter. For example, you can exclude the shop named "Manchester." Multiple filters can be added, and they can be removed using the respective buttons. Group By: The Group By toggles allow you to group the filtered results. You can select up to 4 groups, and the hierarchy of the groups can be adjusted by dragging and dropping them. For example, you can group by shop first and then by master item. Note that the dimensions grouping will only display if you have configured Dimension types from within Item Management. Date Range: Specify the date range for the report. The default is the past month from the current date to the current date. You can select a start and end date within a 10-year period. A calendar is provided for selecting dates, and you can also choose today's date. Generate: Once you have selected the filters, grouping, and date range, clicking the "Generate" button will display the report in two sections. Report Grid: The report grid presents the data. It includes headings such as the number of sales transactions, the number of items sold, average items in the basket, average price of items sold, average basket amount, turnover, returns amount, discount amount, gross profit percentage, gross profit amount, and turnover percentage by employee or grouping. You can download the report as a CSV file. Graphs: The second section displays KPI graphs. The top graph shows financial KPIs, and hovering over the lines will display the chart figures. The bottom graph represents statistics KPIs, and hovering over the lines will display the corresponding figures. You can print or download the charts in various formats using the hamburger icon. By utilizing the Employee feature, you can analyze sales data within a specified date range, split by employees, apply filters based on different criteria, group the results, and obtain valuable insights through the report grid and KPI graphs.

title: Top List
text: The Top List feature provides a concise output displaying turnover, profit, weekly cover, and sell-through percentage. It also allows you to apply filters and group the results. Here's an overview of how it works: Filter: To add a filter, click on the "Filter" button. The filter options include: - Shop - Master Items - Vendor Once you select a filter option, you can choose the operator "contains." You can add a constraint to further refine the filter. For example, you can exclude the shop named "Manchester." Multiple filters can be added, and they can be removed using the respective buttons. Group By: The Group By toggles allow you to group the filtered results. You can select up to 4 groups, and the hierarchy of the groups can be adjusted by dragging and dropping them. For example, you can group by shop first and then by master item. Note that the dimensions grouping will only display if you have configured Dimension types from within Item Management. Date Range: Specify the date range for the report. The default is the past month from the current date to the current date. You can select a start and end date within a 10-year period. A calendar is provided for selecting dates, and you can also choose today's date. Generate: Once you have selected the filters, grouping, and date range, clicking the "Generate" button will display the report in two sections. Report Grid: The report grid presents the data. It includes headings such as turnover, number of articles sold, gross profit, gross profit percentage, weekly cover (number of weeks of stock cover), and sell-through percentage. You can download the report grid as a CSV file. Graphs: The second section displays KPI graphs. The top graph represents financial KPIs, and hovering over the lines will display the chart figures. The bottom graph also represents financial KPIs. You can print or download the charts in various formats using the hamburger icon. By utilizing the Top List feature, you can obtain a concise summary of key metrics such as turnover, profit, weekly cover, and sell-through percentage. You can apply filters based on shop, master items, and vendors, group the results, and analyze the data through the report grid and KPI graphs.

title: Stock
text: The Stock feature allows you to view stock and purchase figures, apply filters, and group the results. Here's how it works: Filter: To add a filter, click on the "Filter" button. The filter options include: - Shop - Master Items - Vendor Once you select a filter option, you can choose the operator "contains." You can add a constraint to further refine the filter. For example, you can exclude the shop named "Manchester." Multiple filters can be added, and they can be removed using the respective buttons. Group By: The Group By toggles allow you to group the filtered results. You can select up to 4 groups, and the hierarchy of the groups can be adjusted by dragging and dropping them. For example, you can group by shop first and then by master item. Note that the dimensions grouping will only display if you have configured Dimension types from within Item Management. Date Range: Specify the date range for the report. The default is the past month from the current date to the current date. You can select a start and end date within a 10-year period. A calendar is provided for selecting dates, and you can also choose today's date. Generate: Once you have selected the filters, grouping, and date range, clicking the "Generate" button will display the report in two sections. Report Grid: The report grid presents the data. It includes headings such as EOP Stock (stock as of the end date), EOP Stock Purchase Cost (cost price of the stock as of the end date), EOP Index (EOP Stock / EOP Stock from the specified date range minus 1 year), Turnover Quantity, Turnover, Turnover Index, Purchase Quantity, Purchase, Purchase Index, Gross Profit %, and EOP Stock Sales Price. You can download the report grid as a CSV file. Graphs: The second section displays KPI graphs. The top graph represents financial KPIs, and hovering over the lines will display the chart figures. The bottom graph also represents financial KPIs. You can print or download the charts in various formats using the hamburger icon. By utilizing the Stock feature, you can analyze stock and purchase figures. You can apply filters based on shop, master items, and vendors, group the results, and examine the data through the report grid and KPI graphs.

title: Financial Stock
text: The Financial Stock feature allows you to view stock, purchase, and correction figures. You can apply filters, group the results, and analyze the data. Here's how it works: Filter: To add a filter, click on the "Filter" button. The filter options include: - Shop - Master Items - Vendor Once you select a filter option, you can choose the operator "contains." You can add a constraint to further refine the filter. For example, you can exclude the shop named "Manchester." Multiple filters can be added, and they can be removed using the respective buttons. Group By: The Group By toggles allow you to group the filtered results. You can select up to 4 groups, and the hierarchy of the groups can be adjusted by dragging and dropping them. For example, you can group by shop first and then by master item. Note that the dimensions grouping will only display if you have configured Dimension types from within Item Management. Date Range: Specify the date range for the report. The default is the past month from the current date to the current date. You can select a start and end date within a 10-year period. A calendar is provided for selecting dates, and you can also choose today's date. Generate: Once you have selected the filters, grouping, and date range, clicking the "Generate" button will display the report in two sections. Report Grid: The report grid presents the data. It includes headings such as Opening Stock, Opening Stock Purchase Cost, Opening Stock Sales Price, No. of Articles Sold, Turnover Ex Tax, Cost of Sold Articles, Corrections Quantity, Corrections Cost, Purchase Quantity, Purchase, Transfer, Transfer Cost, EOP Stock, and EOP Stock Purchase Cost. You can download the report grid as a CSV file. Graphs: The second section displays KPI graphs. The top graph represents financial KPIs, and hovering over the lines will display the chart figures. The bottom graph also represents financial KPIs. You can print or download the charts in various formats using the hamburger icon. By using the Financial Stock feature, you can analyze stock, purchase, and correction figures. Apply filters based on shop, master items, and vendors, group the results, and examine the data through the report grid and KPI graphs.

title: Step 1 Downloading Template
text: Downloading a Template is done from the Item Import option of the Inventory side menu. Click on Download Template. Imagine will start downloading the Item Template file and when ready it will appear in your downloads folder unless you have a pre-set location. Additional information: The file is consistently named 'Item_ImportTemplate'. In the event of downloading multiple templates, a number is appended to the template's name to ensure they are not overwritten. These numbers are added in sequential order, such as (1), (2), (3), and so on. If you are working with numerous import files, it is advisable to rename the file to something more descriptive. This practice helps in better organizing and identifying the import files. Please note that it is recommended to avoid using spaces in the filename, as the import program will add plus signs between the words. For instance, 'Items+with+dimensions.xlsx'. Feel free to relocate the import file to a more suitable location than the default download area.

title: Step 2 Fixed Selection Fields
text: Within the Excel Template file, certain fields are populated with drop-down selections based on the information stored in Imagine. Additionally, some fields will only appear if they are enabled and set as required in Imagine. It is crucial to carefully review the items to be imported and ensure that the necessary information is set up in Imagine beforehand. Manual addition of these values to the spreadsheet is not possible. Here are some specific details regarding the fields: Vendors - These need to be set up in Imagine to appear in the drop-down list within the template. Hierarchy Nodes (Departments/Categories) - These also need to be set up in Imagine for them to appear in the drop-down list within the template. Tax Rates - Each Tax Group will be displayed as a separate field and present a list of available tax codes in their respective drop-down lists. For example, a UK Tax Group may show options like 20% and 0%, a French Tax Group may display 23% and 5%, and an Irish Tax Group may show 23%, 15%, and 0%. Dimension Types - This column refers solely to the type of dimension, such as Color, Size, or Fit-Width. Each dimension type will have its column at the end of the import template. Please note that this should not be confused with Dimension Templates. Custom Attributes - Only Custom Attributes marked as required will be shown in the template for input. Prices - The Selling Price for each currency will be included as an available field, based on the currencies set up against a particular Shop. Take care to ensure that the necessary data is properly set up in Imagine before using the import template, as this will ensure accurate and comprehensive information can be imported. The tabs at the bottom of the template contain the data used by the drop-down menus. These cannot be edited but are useful to see what is available from each of the drop-down selections.

title: Step 3 Entering Information into the Excel Template
text: When you first open the template file, you may see a protected view warning, click ‘Enable Editing’ and then you are ready to start adding item information. The template spreadsheet can be used for items with and without dimensions [Colours/sizes] and can contain a mixture of both. Field Information An item with No Dimensions - All information about the item will be entered on one line. When updating an Item with No Dimensions the Master Item information shown on the Summary tab will be matched up to the Item information as shown on the Matrix tab. An item with Dimensions - There will be multiple lines for this item, each line representing the colour/size combination. The Master Item Number must be the same for all lines for the item to be created properly with all the colours/sizes required. Requirements The Master Item Number (MIN) must be the same for each dimension variation of the item (e.g., Colour, Size, Fit). SKT01 in the example covers all dimensions of the Skye Tee Shirt. Item Number (IN) and Barcode (BC) must be unique for each dimension variation. If an item does not have a manufacturer's barcode, you must add one to the item. This could be the same as the Item Number [IN] field or your own internally generated number. E.g. 200001 or 201000345. If using a number structure please ensure you are consistent, and the number is unique. Contact your K3 project consultant for further advice if required. Dimension Details must be a unique combination covering all dimensions used for example if an item has 2 Dimensions, you cannot have Blue and Small together for more than 1 dimension variation. The Vendor must be the same for all dimension variations as per the Item [Master Item Number]. For all other fields, it is possible to make changes per dimension variation, but beware of how it may appear in Imagine, per dimension variation.

title: Step 4 Importing and Validating Information
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS [Optional] Review of Validated items. [If required] Validation Errors - Invalid Status. Export Validation Errors Click on Upload File. Browse for the Excel Spreadsheet. Submit the Sheet to start the first part of the import process. Use the browse for Excel Spread Sheet to find the sheet to import, then click submit sheet. The status “Processing” means the file is being checked, and then it moves to ‘validating’. If successful it will move to a status of ‘Validated’ with an Edit Pencil and Tick icon showing in the Actions column. If there is a problem, it will move to an ‘Invalid’ Status. [See Invalid Status section on what to do next] If there is no activity after a short period, use the Refresh List button to refresh the page. Processing and Validation time will vary based on the number of items and lines being imported. [Optional] Review of Validated items. When the status shows validated, the Edit Pencil can be used to review any of the items before completing the Import process. Items can be changed using the Edit pencil of each line, or if required items deleted using the recycle bin of each line. You must choose the ‘Validate’ button again if any changes are made, otherwise use the X to close the page, ready to ‘Complete the Import’. [If required] Validation Errors - Invalid Status. Invalid status means there is something not quite right with the data in the spreadsheet. Typically, it is missing information, or duplicated information such as the item number, a barcode or dimension variations. Some corrections can be made at this validation stage without re-importing the spreadsheet, others may require a spreadsheet change followed by another import. In the Actions column, click on the Edit Pencil to see exactly what the problem is and apply the correction. The items shown in RED are the items that require attention. Click on the down arrow at the start of each line to see the Validation Error message. [There may be more than 1 validation message per line] In this example, the Manufacturer Items Number is missing. Option 1: Update the spreadsheet and re-import again. Option 2: Click on the Edit Pencil between the arrow and the recycle bin to add the missing information. Use the SAVE icon between the down arrow and recycle bin to save your changes for this line. Repeat option 2 for all other lines showing in Red. Once all corrections are made, choose VALIDATE to re-validate the data. The status will show Validating then move to ‘Validated’ with an Edit Pencil and Tick icon showing in the Actions column if successful. If there is still a problem, it will move back to an ‘Invalid’ Status. If there is no activity after a short period, use the Refresh List button to refresh the page. Processing and Validation time will vary based on the number of items and lines being imported. Continue with the next step to ‘Complete the Import’. Export Validation Errors In the event there are a lot of errors, use the ‘Export All Data’ option to export to a spreadsheet for easier identification. The spreadsheet will be downloaded to the download folder or your specified download location.

title: Step 5 Complete the Upload & Import
text: This final step will import the validated items from the spreadsheet into Imagine as active items. To start the final import, Click the Tick icon in the Actions box. The status will change from ‘Validating’ to ‘Validated’ and ‘Importing’ whilst it is working. A successful Import will show a status of ‘Imported’. If there is no activity after a short period, use the Refresh List button to refresh the page. Importing time will vary based on the number of items and lines being imported. Check Item in Imagine A check of the items imported into Imagine is recommended for 2 reasons. To ensure they have been created properly, but also to add in any additional information or switch on functions that are not covered by the Import Template spreadsheet.

title: Adding a New Template
text: To add a new Label Template, simply click on the "Add Label Template" button. To create a Label Template, first, give it a name, and then copy or type your ZPL code into the designated Template field. After completing these steps, use the Save button to save your template. If you wish to exit without saving any changes, click on Cancel to return to the overview menu. If you have set up any Custom Attributes or Dimension Templates, they will also be available for selection on the page. For more information on this, please refer to the Variable section.

title: Editing a New Template
text: To edit an existing Label Template, click on the name of the label. This will open a new page where you can edit the template attributes. It is important to note that there is no "restore" option after deleting a template, so you will need to start again using the "Add Template" button. Back Takes you back to the Overview page. Test Label Select Test Label from the top menu of the open design. Select a Shop This will be the shop where your barcode printer is located. Select the Connector This is the connector your barcode printer is attached to. Valid Barcode Key or Scan in the barcode of an item.
