Print Sends the template design and item details to the barcode printer. Delete After a Save, you can delete your template if not required. Save Saves any changes made to the Label Template. Variables In the ZPL template, you can include various variables in curly brackets { }. These variables will link to the data of the item you are trying to print and will be converted into ZPL commands (such as Field Data (^FD)) before being sent to the printer. It is important to note that the variable names are case sensitive. If a value cannot be found for a specific variable, then no data will be printed on the label. {barcode} - As listed for each item as the Barcode in the Matrix tab of an Item. {currency} - Default currency designator of the tenant in ISO 4217 format. {customAttribute|} - See Custom Variable / Dimension / Sales Price for formatting details. {dimension|} - See Custom Variable / Dimension / Sales Price for formatting details. {discountAmount} - See Discount Labels in Item Management. This variable will show the value shown in the Value field when Type Value is selected. {discountPercent} - See Discount Labels in Item Management. This variable will show the value shown in the Percentage field when Type Percentage is selected. {itemDescription} – As listed for the Item in the Matrix tab under Description. {itemManufacturerItemNumber} – As listed for the Item in the Matrix tab under Manufacture Item No. {itemName} – As listed for the Item in the Matrix tab under Name. {itemNo} - As listed for each item as the Item No in the Item List. See Details for further details especially as this number cannot be altered after item creation. {itemVariantDescription} – Is system set at item creation. It is a concatenation of Dimension names set against the item. See the {dimension|} variable for individual elements. {itemVendorItemNumber} – As listed for the Item in the Matrix tab under Vendor Item No. {price} – As listed for the Item in the Matrix tab under Sales Price. This is always in the default currency, for alternative currencies see the {salesPrice|} variable. {salesPrice|} - See Custom Variable / Dimension / Sales Price for formatting details. {textLine} – Used by the system for arbitrary data, such as the Text field in Discount Labels. Not user configurable. {currentprice} – This displays the current price via the POS within the Item lookup list. NOTE: The Price may be affected by PPE Price Changes and can differ from the {salesPrice|} due to time based price changes. {itemVendorName} – The assigned Vendor in the Summary tab of an Item. {masterItemNo} – Prints the Master Item Number as shown on the Summary tab for the item.

title: Custom Variable / Dimension / Sales Price
text: Custom Variable To print the value of a custom attribute for an item, you can use the Custom Attribute variable. As an item can have multiple attributes, it is necessary to specify which attribute value to print using the variable. The Custom Attribute variable requires a single argument, which is the that defines the Custom Attribute ID to use. On the printed label, the data in the Value field of the specified Custom Attribute for that item will be printed. Custom Variables are structured as {customAttribute|} To use this variable, you need to replace with the actual ID of the custom attribute you want to print. The pipe character (|) must be used to separate the variable name from the argument. You can find the IDs of all custom attributes listed on the Custom Attribute overview page under Item - Custom Attributes. The variable will then print the value of the specified custom attribute for the item on the label. To insert the correct Custom Attribute variable on the label template, simply place the cursor where you want the variable and select it from the Custom Attribute list. The variable and argument will be inserted for you. Dimension Variable The Dimension variable prints the value of dimensions for an item. You need to specify which dimension value to print since an item can have multiple dimensions. To determine the range of dimensions for an item, check the Matrix tab for that item. The Dimension view also displays the values applied to an item. The Dimension variable requires a single argument , which indicates the Dimension Sequence ID to use. You can find Dimension Sequences in the Dimension view of the Matrix tab for the item. The ID of the far left-hand Dimension Sequence is 1, and the ID of the far right-hand column is 10. Select the current Dimension Sequence for the argument. Dimension Variables are structured as {dimension|} To use the Dimension variable, replace the argument with the value of the Dimension Sequence ID to print. The resulting label will show the value given for the item at the associated Dimension Sequence ID. The pipe character (|) should be used to delimit the variable name from the argument. Sales Price Variable The Sales Price variable allows you to display the value of an item in different currencies on the label. To specify which currency to print, you need to use the argument. This argument must be ISO 4217 compliant and can only be one of the currencies listed in the Matrix tab for the item. The available currencies are part of the value selectors and are labeled as "Sales Price." The variable is structured as: {salesPrice|} To create the label, replace the argument with the 3-letter currency code of the currency you want to print. The label will display the value of the item in the corresponding currency field shown in the Matrix tab. Be sure to use the pipe character (|) to separate the variable name from the argument.

title: Sample Templates
text: Listed are some sample template layouts and their intended uses. Discount By Percent. Used in Inventory – Discount Labels for the Form Type Percentage ^XA ^CFA,15 ^FWN ^FX ##### STANDARD LABEL - 40mm x 32mm ##### ^FS ^FX ### Barcode - Code 128 ### ^BY2,2.5,60 ^FO30,20,0 ^BC ^FD{barcode} ^FS ^FX ### DiscountByPercent ### ^FO130,150,2 ^A 150,25 ^FD{DiscountPercent} % ^FS ^FX ### Text box ### ^FO30,180,2 ^A 150,25 ^FD{TextLine} ^FS ^XZ Discount By Percent. title: View or Edit a Bundle
text: Selecting a Bundle will allow you to view/edit a bundle. NOTE: It is not possible to alter the main item of a bundle. It is recommended that you delete and re create. All the key properties you can edit are explained in the "Create Bundle Wizard" section. The tax rate set here will take preference and apply to the items sold under this Bundle, this may be different to the tax rate set in Inventory. Here you can resequence the order of the Bundle Groups as they will appear to your customers using the Handle in the Bundle Groups row.

title: Creating a New Bundle
text: 1. To begin creating a new bundle click the "Create Bundle" button and the bundle wizard will walk you through the steps. 2. Choose a main item which must already exist in your Items. This item could of course also be linked to Modifier Group. 3. Select the Bundle Groups which you want to offer alongside your Main Item. Click the "Add Bundle Groups" button. 4. You can either Add a Bundle Group or create a new bundle group (for which documentation can be found in the Bundle Groups section). 5. If you select 'Add Bundle Group' it will show you a searchable list of existing Bundle groups You can select multiple bundle groups using the checkboxes on the left-hand side. 6. Once you have selected your bundle groups, you can customise your bundle. On this screen, you add. Name This is the internal name of the Bundle Display Name The bundle name will be displayed on both the details screen of the front-end apps and the receipt. Please ensure that the chosen name accurately reflects the contents of the bundle. Description Allows for longer product descriptions that include dietary and allergen information, helping your customers make informed decisions. Image URL This is a link to the Image that is displayed in the details view of the bundles in the front-end apps. Only .bmp, .gif, .jpg and .svg type images are supported. Sales Price The price the bundle will be sold for. 7. Click next and this shows the summary of the bundle you are creating. 8. You have the option at this point to go to the previous screen and change anything or create the bundle.

title: Create a Bundle Group
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Bundle Groups Create a Bundle Group View/Edit Bundle Group Bundle Groups Bundle Groups are a collection of similar items that are presented for selection. For instance, you may have a group of side dishes that can be chosen to go with a main meal. The Bundle Groups selections can only be items and are linked exclusively to Bundles. Items can be added to as many Bundle Groups as needed. Bundle Groups are displayed as selectable items in the front-end applications, similar to the example shown below. The display names of the two Bundle Groups linked to the Bundle are Pastry and Sweet Stuff. The Bundle Group List displays all the groups you have currently set up. From here, you can create a new Bundle Group or select an existing one to view and edit its details. Please note that you cannot delete Bundle Groups that are linked to other Bundles for which sales have already been registered. Create a Bundle Group When creating a new Bundle Group, you will need to specify two key properties and the items you want to include in the group. To start creating a new Bundle Group, click on the "Create Bundle Groups" button. This will open up the following page: Name This should be the name used internaly Display Name This is the name seen by front end users. Add Item to Bundle Group Clicking on this button will display a list of searchable items that can be assigned to the Bundle Group. To add multiple items at once, simply select the checkboxes next to each item and click on the button to assign them. Ensure you press to add the created bundle group to the system. View/Edit Bundle Group To edit a Bundle Group, simply select the group you wish to modify. Note that you can delete items from the group, but this action only removes the item from the group and does not delete the actual item. It's important to keep in mind that any changes made to a Bundle Group will immediately be reflected in any Bundles that are currently live and in use in the front-end applications.

title: Create a Modifier Group
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Modifier Groups Modifier Groups List Create a Modifier Group Number Picker Example. Modifier Groups Modifier Groups enable you to apply certain prescribed modifications to an Item. Note that you can only modify an Item or a Bundle Main item, but not a Bundle Group Item. You would use a Modifier Group if you wish to add one or more variable modifiers to a particular item. Modifiers can have additional prices added on top of the item price. For instance, suppose you order a cup of coffee. You choose a Latte but would also like to select your preferred type of milk, an extra shot of espresso, and a flavour of syrup. This would require three modifier groups: "Milk": This Modifier Group lists the milk options available, such as Semi Skimmed, Skimmed, Whole, Oat, Soy, and Almond. "Shots": This Modifier Group includes the optional extra shots available. "Syrups": This Modifier Group provides the syrup choices. Please note that Modifiers are not currently linked to Items within Imagine and do not affect the stock. Modifiers appear in the front-end apps, similar to the example shown below: Modifier Groups List A Modifier Group List displays all the existing Modifier Groups that you have currently set up. From this list, you can create new Modifier Groups or select an existing one to view or edit its details. Note that you cannot delete Modifier Groups, as they may be linked to other groups for which sales have already been registered. Create a Modifier Group To begin creating modifiers use the This will then open up to the page below. Number Picker Uses a +/- button to increase and decrease selection amounts. Can be used for items like "Extra Shot". Checkbox Buttons Uses tick boxes for selections. Can be used for items like a sandwich with different fillings like lettuce, tomatoes or onion. Name The name is used internally. Display Name The name is seen by front-end users. Number Picker Example. You can add/edit as many different number pickers into your Modifier Group as required within the table. To add more modifiers use the to add a new line. Image Enter a URL for an image to be shown against the modifier in the front-end apps. Only .bmp, .gif, .jpg and .svg type images are supported. Name The name of the modifier as it appears in the front-end apps. ItemNo Used for integration purposes, you can link a modifier to an existing Imagine item which can then be related to a third-party ERP system item. Default Value The number you get by default upon selection. Min The minimum value you can enter for the modifier. Max The maximum number allowed to be entered for the modifier. Sales Price Optional sales prices for modifiers that get added to the price from the default value. As an example, suppose you have set a default value of 1 for shots, and each additional shot costs £1.10. In this case, the price for each shot added will be added to the item price. However, if the default value is 1, but you have set the minimum value to 0, then the price will not be subtracted if the default shot is removed. This means that the customer cannot lower the base price of the item by removing the modifiers. Ensure you save the individual rows before trying to add a new row or save the group. it will only save changes which have been individually saved in that table. Example Coffee Price: £3.00 Shot Price: £1.00 Default Shots: 2 Minimum Shots: 1 Number Of Shots Coffee Total Price Reason 1 £3.00 The base price is £3.00 and they have removed 1 shot, but you do not have the cost of the shot removed for your default shots. 2 £3.00 The default number of shots, therefore default coffee price applies. 3 £4.00 2 default shots are included in the price, and 1 additional shot for £1. 4 £5.00 2 default shots included in the price, s additional shots for £2. Checkbox Button Example. Checkbox Buttons are a type of modifier that allows you to provide one or more selectable options to customers, both as optional or mandatory selections. They are called Checkbox Buttons because they appear as clickable buttons that resemble checkboxes, which can be easily selected with a touch screen. These are particularly useful for providing choices of fillings for sandwiches or toppings for pizzas, for example. Customers can select one or more options or none of them, depending on their preferences. Name This should be the name used internally. Display Name This should be the name seen by front-end users. Min The minimum value you can enter for the modifier. Max The maximum number allowed to be entered for the modifier Checkbox Buttons are a way to offer optional or mandatory selections to customers, where they can choose one or more options from a list. If the modifier is not mandatory, the minimum value should always be 0, while if you want to ensure that at least one modifier is always selected, set the minimum to 1. The maximum value is typically set to 1, to limit the number of selections to one per group. However, for optional toppings, you may choose to set a higher limit. To create or modify modifiers, use the table below. You can add, delete, or modify rows as needed. Remember to save each row before attempting to add a new one or save the group, as changes are only saved for rows that have been individually saved within the table. Image Enter an image URL this will be shown against the modifier at the front end. NOTE: Only .bmp / .gif / .jpg /.svg image types are supported. Name The name of the modifier as it appears in the front-end apps. ItemNo Used for integration purposes, you can link a modifier to an existing Imagine item which can then be related to a third-party ERP system item. Default Value - If the button is selected by default. For example, in a Latte case, you might have Semi Skimmed selected by default. Sales Price Optional sales prices for modifiers that get added to the price of the default value. When you select a syrup for your coffee, an additional charge of £0.50 will be added to the item price. However, if the syrup is set as a default selection, the charge for it will not be subtracted from the item price. You can also set higher prices for more premium modifiers to increase revenue. Keep in mind that any additional charges for modifiers will be added to the item price, so the final price of the item may vary based on the selections made.

title: Functionality
text: The Order Ready board is designed for customer-facing displays It shows the current status of an order and is designed to work in conjunction with the OSD Order Status Display. The ORB displays 2 columns: In Progress - This is an order that is currently being processed, once it is "bumped" to that status in the OSD Ready - This is an order which is ready to collect, once it has been "bumped" to that status in the OSD, If this application does not fit the screen correctly you can use the browser magnification to zoom in and out until it fits.

title: My Analysis
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Saved Reports Shared Reports The Dashboard has been broken down into 2 sections to explain what each area is used for. Saved Reports Saved reports are reports you have created previously and chosen to save. For example you have chosen to list all inactive items only in a saved report. You would see and launch that report here. You can filter the list of Saved Reports by type such as Item, Sales or Movements. By default All reports are shown. The Saved reports are shown in a list. Select a report to launch it. The table shows the data of which information you have selected from the fields above, you can modify the way the information is displayed. Edit Description This will allow you to edit the Description of a report and change the 'Shared to' option Delete Report This will allow you to delete a saved report. You will be prompted for a confirmation. Deleted reports cannot be restored. Shared Reports Shared reports are reports you have created previously and have chosen to share with others. For example, everyone needs to see a list of Active Items so you have shared this report for others to use. There is no 'edit' function in the Shared reports list, and only reports that are marked as 'Everybody' or 'My Role' are shown in this list.

title: Start / Login Screen
text: In the Simple POS application, you can change the language by clicking on the flag icon located in the top right corner. However, it's important to note that the language setting will automatically revert back to the default language after each transaction is completed. Additionally, the landing image displayed in the Simple POS interface can be customized through Visual Profiles. This allows you to configure and personalize the initial image that users see when they access the application. By providing language options and the ability to customize the landing image, the Simple POS application offers flexibility and the opportunity to create a visually appealing and user-friendly experience for both clerks and customers.

title: Composer View
text: The Composer View serves as the primary screen within the application, where clerks can efficiently select the items that customers wish to order. When accessing the Composer View, the screen always starts by displaying the Landing Group specific to the selected store. This Landing Group serves as the initial point for navigation, providing a structured hierarchy of available items. For further customization and expansion of the hierarchy and navigation, the Composer Groups and Visual Composer Modules can be utilized. Within the Composer View, there are two main methods of item selection. Firstly, you can drill into the subgroups represented by blue tiles, allowing you to navigate to a deeper layer of the hierarchy to find specific items. Alternatively, you can use the +/- buttons to directly add items to the basket without navigating through the subgroups. If you select the "+" button for an item that is either a Bundle or has Modifiers, you will be prompted to make the necessary selections before adding the item to the basket. This ensures that any additional choices or modifications associated with the item are properly accounted for. By leveraging the capabilities of the Composer View, clerks can efficiently navigate through the item hierarchy, make selections, and add items to the basket, ensuring a streamlined and personalized ordering process for customers. Icon Meaning Function On Screen Navigation If you have Bundle Groups set up, you will see navigation buttons appear when in those groups. For example Home > Drinks > Pepsi / Sprite / Coke. you can use this to return to the Home Screen or to a section by selecting on the POS. Tile Button The tile button if pressed will return you back to your home group from wherever you are in the application. Supervisor Functions This button will ask you for a PIN code to enter supervisor functions. Product Information Any tile with the i symbol means there is some more information you might want to see for an item. It also indicates that there may be Bundle Groups or Modifiers for the item when selected. Basket Button The basket button shows you how many items you have in your basket. You can press the button to view the basket, which you have to do in order to proceed to Payment.

title: Supervisor Functions
text: To access the Supervisor Functions locate the settings cog in the top right-hand of the POS, you will be prompted to enter a supervisor PIN. Supervisor permissions are set up in Configuration. The Simple POS application provides several additional functions accessible through the following options: Previous Receipt: This option allows you to view the previous receipt and provides the choice to either email or print it for reference or record-keeping purposes. Full Screen: The Full Screen option allows you to toggle between full-screen mode and regular view. However, please note that this function may not be supported in Chrome due to specific browser settings. Choose Payment Provider: This functionality lists all the payment providers that you have configured in the administration settings. If you are conducting a demo or test and do not have an active payment provider, you can use the Virtual option. The Virtual payment method bypasses actual payment processing and assumes a full payment has been made. However, it should be noted that the Virtual option should not be used in a live environment. Refund Mode: By selecting the Refund Mode option, you can switch the application into refund mode. This mode allows you to process the entire transaction as a refund, accommodating situations where a customer needs to return a purchased item or seek a refund for a specific transaction. Logout: Choosing the Logout option clears the current basket, effectively emptying it, and returns you to the login screen, allowing for secure user logout and ensuring the privacy of customer information. By providing these additional functions, the Simple POS application enhances the user experience, offering convenient options for managing receipts, adjusting display settings, selecting payment providers, handling refunds, and securely logging out from the application.

title: Items / Bundles / Modifiers
text: When adding a Bundle or Modifiable item to your basket in the Simple POS application, you will be guided through the selection process to ensure the relevant choices are made before adding the item to your basket. If the Bundle main item has associated Modifiers linked to it, the application will automatically navigate you to the Modifiers tab, providing the opportunity to make any desired alterations or customization to the selected item. This ensures that you have the flexibility to modify the Bundle according to your preferences or specific requirements. By prompting you to make relevant selections and automatically directing you to the Modifiers tab when applicable, the Simple POS application streamlines the ordering process, enabling you to create a personalized bundle that suits your preferences and needs. For non-bundled items in the Simple POS application that have Modifiers associated with them, the interface will focus solely on displaying the Modifiers to streamline the selection process. Next to each Modifier title, you will find the minimum and maximum selection rules, indicating the allowable quantity or range of choices for that particular Modifier. Additionally, any associated additional prices for the selected Modifiers will be displayed, providing transparency on any cost adjustments. It's important to note that any modifications or selections you make during the ordering process will be recorded and included on the order confirmation slip. These modifications will also be transmitted to the Order Status Display, which is used in the order preparation area. This ensures that the preparation team is aware of the specific modifications and requirements associated with each order, facilitating efficient and accurate order fulfillment. By focusing on Modifiers for non-bundled items, providing clear rules and prices, and incorporating modifications into the order confirmation and preparation processes, the Simple POS application enables seamless customization and ensures accurate communication between clerks, customers, and the order preparation team.

title: Basket / Payment
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Basket Payment Refund Mode Discount Basket The Basket screen shows a concise list of your items, including any bundle choices and modifiers you've made. Similar items with the same selections and modifiers are grouped on a single line. Each line indicates the total price for that group, along with the quantity multiplied by the price of a single item. Edit Line - You can use the pencil icon for the basket line to make alterations to that line (change modifiers or bundle selections). Delete Line -Use the trash can icon to remove the line from the basket. Delete Basket - Use the black trash can next to the Pay button to clear the basket and return to the start screen. Payment At the bottom of the Basket screen, you will have your payment options. You can choose your payment method to use and you can split your payment types in use as well. For a Card payment, the system will establish communication with the configured Connector specifically designed for processing real EFT payments. Similarly, a Cash payment will also utilize the connector to trigger the opening of the cash drawer. On the other hand, a Manual Card payment does not require an integrated card terminal. It is intended for use with standalone chip and pin devices and only utilizes the connector for receipt printing. If a payment fails, you will receive a notification and after a 5-second delay, you will be directed back to the basket to try another card. To obtain detailed information about why the transaction was declined, please refer to the PED (Payment Entry Device) documentation, as each provider may have different reasons for displaying a failure. Please note that a failure message may also appear if the Simple POS is unable to establish communication with the Connector. Upon successful payment, the transaction will be sent to Imagine's back end for further processing. The system will: Submit the order to the Order Status Display. Provide you with an order number, which will be displayed on the screen and used in the OSD (Order Status Display) and ORB (Order Receipt Builder). Print an order confirmation slip that includes the order number, as well as any bundle selections and modifiers that have been applied. Show you the estimated waiting time, which is calculated based on the order throughput of the last 15 minutes. Finally, you will be returned to the start screen to proceed with other actions. Refund Mode The Supervisor Functions include a Refund mode, which is specifically designed for processing refunds. When you activate Refund mode, the entire transaction is treated as a refund, and the system does not allow for exchanges to be performed. The user interface indicates when you are in Refund mode to ensure that you are aware and prevent any potential mistakes. This clarity helps to maintain accuracy and avoid errors during the refund process. Discount After registering an item against the POS there are options available to discount them. These options will be detailed below. Clicking one of these will set the percentage discount against the item(s) in the basket. Clicking on ‘Custom Discount’ brings up a dialogue allowing the users to choose to discount by a percentage or a set amount. Once the discount has been entered press ‘Apply Discount’. This will then set the amount or percentage against the product in the basket.

title: Method 1 Imagine Excel Count Import File
text: The Imagine Excel Count file is a pre-prepared Excel spreadsheet which only requires the counts adding to. The Excel import file is limited to 5000 lines per import. Step 1: Export a Stocktake Count Import Template Exporting a spreadsheet template is done from the Import Counts from File tab on the Count page. Create a new stocktake or open an existing one. Click on the Count button. Click on Import Counts from File. Click on Export Count File to start downloading a Stocktake Count Import Template Downloads are saved to the default download location or your own specified download location if set. Find and open the Stocktake Count Import Template spreadsheet. Add stock counts to the Count column [D] ! Important Notes: The template only shows those items based on the stocktake filters. The spreadsheet is protected so you cannot amend barcode or description fields, or add, or remove items. You can change the file name to something more meaningful. Step 2: Import a Stocktake Count Import Template. Importing a spreadsheet template is done from the Import Counts from File tab on the Count page. Click on Import Count File to start downloading a Stocktake Count Import Template. Click Browse for File and browse to the template you wish to import. Check the correct file shows on the upload screen and click Submit Sheet. The template is added with a status of Validating Data. [May show briefly as Data Parsed] Use the Refresh List to check if the validation process has completed. If successful, Status changes to Data Validated. If unsuccessful, the status will change to validation failed. See the section Validation Failed on what to do next. Click the Tick in the Actions box to add the validated counts. Add to Existing Counts - Adds the quantities of this import file to any counts already against an item. Overwrite - Replaces any counts already against an item with this import file count. Cancel - Cancels the import. Add Items Not Currently in Stocktake - If you have used an Imagine Count template from another stocktake, Tick On to add items which are not in the original stocktake list, otherwise they will not be added. The status of an import will show as Importing to Stocktake whilst counts are being updated. Use the Refresh List to check if the import process has completed. Import is complete when Status changes to Imported to Stocktake. Repeat with another import file or continue adding items manually.

title: Method 2: External CSV Count Import File
text: This option is typically used to import a stock file which has come from a stock-taking device or 3rd party program. The file will be a CSV format with a file extension of .csv. Format Explanation - During the import process you will be prompted to confirm the format of the file. Delimiter Used in File: [The character used to separate each of the fields of data in the file]. , (Comma) ; (semi-colon) ‘ (single quote) | (pipe) [Tab] Are the Cells surrounded by single/double quotes? ‘ (single quote) “ (double quote) None Column Index that Contains the Barcode: Use the drop-down to select a column number. Column Index that Contains the Count: Use the drop-down to select a column number. Example of an External CSV Count Import File. Import an External Count CSV File. Create a new stocktake or open an existing one. Click on the Count button. Click on Import Counts from File. Click on Import Count File to start downloading a Stocktake Count Import Template. Click Browse for File and browse to the external file you wish to import. Check the correct file shown on the upload screen. Set the import format parameters which match the format of your import file. The example file above is: Delimiter = Comma Cells Usage = None Barcode Column = 1 Count Column = 5 Submit the Sheet to proceed. The template is added with a status of Validating Data. [May show briefly as Data Parsed]. Use the Refresh List to check if the validation process has been completed. If successful, the Status changes to Data Validated. If unsuccessful, the status will change to validation failed. See the section Validation Failed on what to do next. Click the Tick in the Actions box to add the validated counts. Add to Existing Counts - Adds the quantities of this import file to any counts already against an item. Overwrite - Replaces any counts already against an item with this import file count. Cancel - Cancels the import. Add Items Not Currently in Stocktake - Tick On to add items which are not in the original stocktake list, otherwise, they will not be added. The status of an import will show as Importing to Stocktake whilst counts are being updated. Use the Refresh List to check if the import process has been completed. Import is complete when the Status changes to Imported to Stocktake. Repeat with another import file or continue adding items manually.

title: Validation Failed
text: During the import process, Imagine will perform some validation on the contents of the file, particularly the external files. A failed status means that one or more of the values are incorrect or not recognised. Click the Edit Pencil in the Actions box to see what why it has failed. If no data is displayed, then check the delimiter/quotes/column index settings and within the import file itself. Example of No Data Displayed Example of Validation Failed with Data. State Advises the status of the imported line. OK Item imported successfully. Warning Item imported but advises additional information about the item. e.g., Item is not part of the original stocktake list. Error Item is not imported and advises why. e.g., the barcode does not exist. Message Count This is how many error or warning messages are against an item. Row Number Where the item is located within the import file. Useful when the file has lots of items. Barcode The barcode number from the file. It is possible to amend the barcode from here if required. Description Item description/ name if it's available (Imagine Excel file only). Vendor Item Number Vendor item number if it's available (Imagine Excel file only). Count The count quantity from the import file. It is possible to change the quantity if required. Quantity should be limited to a maximum value of 10 digits (i.e., 9999999999) and up to a maximum of 2 decimals (i.e., 99999999.99). The minimum value should be 0. Recycle Bin An item can be removed from the import list before trying to validate again. NOTE: An item is not deleted from the original file, only this import area allows you to continue with the import process. Validate Import After removing an item or making changes to the barcode field, use this button to try the import again. Validation Messages Click the arrow to the left of the State field to expand or collapse the Validation Message area. In the example below, there are 2 messages: 1 error and 1 warning. Use this information to check and make changes to the import file or this import list. Alternatively, delete the line item. Once ready, choose Validate Import to try the import again.

title: Receipt
text: NOTE: Any settings you make will take up to 1 minute to be applied to the connector. In each tab, you have the option to change or add multiple Headers, Footers, and Line information. When you have made your selections click Save and wait as changes can take up to 1 minute to apply to the connector.

title: Gift Certificate
text: NOTE: Any settings you make will take up to 1 minute to be applied to the connector. In each tab, you have the option to change or add multiple Headers, Footers, and Line information. When you have made your selections click Save and wait as changes can take up to 1 minute to apply to the connector.

title: Credit Note
text: NOTE: Any settings you make will take up to 1 minute to be applied to the connector. In each tab, you have the option to change or add multiple Headers and Footers. When you have made your selections click Save and wait as changes can take up to 1 minute to apply to the connector.

title: Web Order Dispatch Note
text: NOTE: Any settings you make will take up to 1 minute to be applied to the connector. In each tab, you have the option to change or add multiple Headers, Footers, and Line information. When you have made your selections click Save and wait as changes can take up to 1 minute to apply to the connector.

title: Windows
text: Chrome/ Firefox /Opera/New MS Edge and Chromium-based browsers. Open your browser and go to the following address: http://www.k3imagine.com/connector/certs/imagine-root.crt Choose to download the certificate to a known location i.e., the Downloads folder and open it when the certificate file has been downloaded. If prompted with a security warning about opening the file, choose to Open the file. You will be asked to edit trust settings choose "This certificate can identify websites" and click OK Click Install the Certificate. Click OK then select 'Place all certificates in the following store' and click Browse. Select 'Trusted Root Certification Authorities' and click OK. Click Next and then Finish. When prompted the import was successful, click OK. Firefox Open Firefox browser and follow this address: http://www.k3imagine.com/connector/certs/imagine-root.crt Choose to download the certificate to a known location i.e. Downloads folder. In Firefox, click the burger menu then Options. Search for 'Certificate' in Find in Options. Click the View Certificates button. On the Authorities tab click Import and browse to the known location where you saved the certificate. Choose the certificate (imagine-root. crt) and click Open. Click OK once the certificate is installed. Restart the Firefox browser once complete.

title: Mac OS
text: Open a browser on the device and go to: http://www.k3imagine.com/connector/certs/imagine-root.crt Once the certificate has downloaded, open the download location and open the certificate. If prompted, enter your Username and Password. Once the Keychain Access screen opens select the certificate and press the Get Info button. Open the Trust menu and under ‘When using this certificate’ chose the ‘Always Trust’ option. If prompted for your Username and Password enter these details and click Update Settings. Close the Keychain Access screen.

title: iPhone (iOS)
text: Open a browser on the iOS device and go to: http://www.k3imagine.com/connector/certs/imagine-root.crt You will see a message on the screen stating the website is trying to open Settings to show a configuration profile Click Allow. On the Install Profile screen click Install. Then click Install once more at the Warning screen. To complete go to Settings > General > About > Certificate Trust Settings and enable Full Trust for the k3imagine.com root certificate.

title: iPad (iOS)
text: Open a browser on the iOS device and go to: http://www.k3imagine.com/connector/certs/imagine-root.crt Go to Settings > General > Profile In the Downloaded Profile will be k3imagine.com, click this to get to the Install Profile. Follow the prompts to install, enter your passcode where asked. Once installed the certificate should show as Verified, click Done. In Settings go to General > About >Certificate Trust Settings then under ‘Enable full trust for root certificates’ enable the k3imagine.com certificate.

title: Movements Dashboard
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Movement Data Filters Key Performance Figures Movement Data Table The Dashboard has been broken down into 3 sections to explain what each area is used for. Movement Data Filters NOTE: If a field is left blank this will automatically choose all options available. NOTE: The search will only return up to the number of lines of data as configured in Analysis Configuration. If your search exceeds the limit a notification will display. FieldDescription From Date Pick a Start Date. To Date Pick an end Date. Shops Choose from your set list of shops. Shop Group Choose a group of selected shops. Company This can be used if a Tenant has multiple companies within Imagine. Vendor Select specific or all vendors available. Hierarchy This is to narrow down a category as required by only one level. NOTE: You can narrow down Hierarchy Levels further by using the Column Chooser. Master Item Number This is the number or code by which the master item is known or referenced. Master Item Name This is the Name given to the master Item at creation. Item Name This is the Name given to the Item at creation. Item Number This is the number or code by which the item is known or referenced. Dimensions Here you can input particular Dimensions of a product that were given at Item Creation. Item Description This can be used to narrow down descriptive information about a product such as Material type, weight, size, artist information, design notes etc. Type The type of movement that has occurred such as Receive Goods, Sale, Stocktake etc. Reference The number by which the movement type has been identified such as a PO Number, Receipt Barcode or Stocktake Description. NOTE: All other filters will be ignored when using the Reference filter Users and Clerks The User or Clerk that performed the Movement Group by Columns Used to group data into summary rows based on the number of columns you pick. For example if you pick 1,2 then, after you press Submit, the data will be grouped by the left most column and then by the second left column and you will see one row for each combination. This can be beneficial where you are planning on viewing large data sets and wish to see summary information initially. To see detailed grouping you should use the 'Drag column header' feature explained in Grouping Categories. NOTE: When pressing Submit you may receive a warning about invalid group column, you should adjust the left most columns to valid entries. Saves Reports, this will also save the format you have configured. Resets the filters to default values This will fetch the data if available. To review past saved reports. See My Analysis for more details. Key Performance Figures These are static boxes of overall information from the data shown in the Item Performance Table. FieldDescription Cost Overall costing of all movements in the report Qty Overall Quantity of items generated within the data. Movement Data Table The table shows the data of which information you have selected from the filters above, you can modify the way the information is displayed. Search Use the Search Bar to find data in the table below Export All Data This will export the data to a .xlxs file for use. There is no option to print directly from this page. Column Chooser This will bring up a list of options to add or remove columns. Reset Grid Filters Resets any filters applied to the Data table

title: Grouping Categories
text: To group detailed data in the Movement Data Table, follow these steps: Click and hold the header you want to group by (e.g., "Shop"), and drag it into place. If you want to remove a column header from the grouping, perform the reverse action by dragging it from its position and dropping it back into the table where you want the header to be placed. Notes The table will automatically update as you add, remove and alter positions of the headers. Headers placed furthest to the left will automatically be the major grouping, whilst headers further to the right will be subsequently more minor groupings. The example below explains this in more detail. Columns that display variable digital denominations, large blocks of text and other limitations cannot be grouped. You will not be able to drop these headers in the 'drag and drop' area. In Movements examples of the headers that cannot be grouped are: Cost (tenant) Cost (shop) Qty Item Description Master Item Description Example of grouping with a single column: Once you group the data, the Movement Data Table will display the information in a different format, showing the groups. In this case, it will be grouped by "Shops." You can use the arrow next to each shop's name to expand and view more detailed information. Example of grouping with multiple columns: If you choose multiple headers to group by, you will have a stack of groups. For example, you may have "Shops" as the major header, and within each shop, you can further group by "Date". To change the hierarchy of the data, arrange the groups in the desired order. The data will stack based on the order of the groups you arrange with major priority to the left, moving to minor priority as you move to the right.

title: Saving a Report
text: When saving a report, please keep the following points in mind: Saving a report does not save the data itself; it only saves the formatting and configuration of the report. To save your created report, click on the "Save Report" button. A pop-up window will appear. In the pop-up window, you can provide a name for your report. It is recommended to choose a descriptive name for easy future reference. There is an option for setting the report's visibility or permissions: "No One": Only you will be able to see this report. "My Role": Other members with the same role as you will have access to this report. "Everybody": Anyone with access to reporting will be able to see this report. Click the save button within the pop-up to save the report along with the chosen settings. After saving, you will receive an on-screen notification confirming that the report has been successfully saved. NOTE: You can save multiple versions of the same report with the same name. They will not replace or stack on top of each other. Each saved report will be distinct and separate.

title: Recalling a Saved Report
text: To view a previously saved report, follow these steps: 1. Click on the "Load Reports" button. 2. A pop-up window will appear on the page, presenting a list of saved reports. Select the report you want to open. 3. After selecting the report, click the "Submit" button to retrieve the associated data. 4. Saved reports are categorized based on the share option chosen when saving. The available categories are: "Saved Reports": This category displays reports saved under any of the three share options. "Shared Reports": This category shows reports saved with the "Everybody" or "My Role" share options. In the pop-up window, you will find the following information for each saved report: Description: The name given to the report at the time of saving. Share Type: The chosen share option when saving the report. Created: The date when the report was initially saved. Modified: The date when any changes were last made to the saved file. Type of Report: Indicates the type of report that was saved, such as Sales or Customer. Additionally, you have the following options for each saved report: Edit: Allows you to edit the report's name and share type. Delete Deletes the report. A confirmation message will appear asking you to confirm deletion with options to choose "Yes" or "No."

title: How to setup and use Clean Cash
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Clean Cash Usage Setup Clean Cash Clean Cash is a fiscalization system used in Sweden to ensure proper registration of all sales in stores with the Swedish tax authorities. It ensures that transactions are properly recorded and accounted for, minimizing the risk of cash manipulation or fraud. The process involves the following steps: 1. Sale Details: When a sale is made in a store, the transaction details are sent to the Clean Cash system. 2. Control Code Generation: Clean Cash generates a control code for the sale transaction. 3. Physical Receipt Printing: The control code is printed on the physical receipt, ensuring its presence as a legal requirement. 4. Back Office Storage: The control code is saved and associated with the corresponding sale transaction in the store's back office system. 5. Compliance Requirement: It is illegal to complete sales in Sweden without the control code on the receipt. Stores can face fines and penalties if this requirement is not met. By utilizing Clean Cash, stores in Sweden can adhere to fiscal regulations, ensuring accurate and transparent reporting of sales to the tax authorities. Usage POS Startup: When Clean Cash is enabled for a store (as per the setup process), the POS system performs a connection check during the Clerk's login. If the connection to Clean Cash cannot be established, an error message will be displayed, and the login attempt will be blocked. This means that it will not be possible to proceed with sales. In such cases, it is possible to temporarily disable Clean Cash in the Admin - Expansions section. Making a Sale: When a sale payment is completed, a request is sent to Clean Cash before the receipt is printed. The details of the sale, including transaction information, are sent to Clean Cash. In return, a QR code is generated and automatically printed on the receipt. Note: In case there are technical difficulties and a QR code is not returned within the specified timeout period, the sale will still be completed. This is because the customer's payment has already been processed at this stage, and an automatic reversal may not be possible. Setup Set up Clean Cash, there are several stages involved. Normally, the setup is handled by K3, but it can be disabled by an admin user if needed. Here are the steps for setting up Clean Cash: 1. Shop Feature Configuration (K3 only): Configure a Shop Feature called "CleanCash" under Platform Admin Tenants - Shop Features. This feature requires two specific values to be set: Name Type Value Comments Active Boolean True Indicates whether clean cash should be used in the shop. ConnectorOptions JSON [{“mac”:””, “retailId”:””}] A list of connector macs matched with retailIds from Clean Cash The MAC address should be separated with dashes (-) i.e. 12-34-56-78-90-AB, using other separators such as underscores ( _ ) will cause an issue when setting up the configuration. Any letters required can be in upper or lowercase. The retail id is supplied by the Swedish tax authorities when the POS is registered, this process is usually handled by the K3 Consultant. 2. Disable and Enable Clean Cash after setup: In the Admin - Expansions section, an admin user can enable or disable Clean Cash functionality. When Clean Cash is disabled, no checks will be performed on the POS, and no receipt codes will be requested. Disabling Clean Cash should only be done temporarily if there is an issue with the Clean Cash service itself, which prevents sales. It is important to note that trading without Clean Cash in Sweden is generally considered illegal, and it is at the retailer's discretion to disable it. K3 cannot be held accountable for any consequences arising from the decision to disable Clean Cash. It is essential to ensure proper setup and compliance with Clean Cash regulations when using it in a Swedish retail environment.

title: How to check the Clean Cash service if it is unavailable at the PoS
text: In case there's issues with the CLEANCASH from customers like the screenshot below: You can check the status https://statusgator.com/services/k3-imagine/clean-cash here if there is any problems. You could inform the customer or the customer can see this themselves. It coud look like this if there is a problem: Is the issue not known on the website? then refer to other Knowledge Base Articles or tickets.

title: Setting up limited receipt reprints
text: Reprinting of receipts is limited to one copy only under Swedish fiscal law. This ensures control and prevents misuse of receipts. K3 have provided the following Shop Feature that can be configured within Imagine's Support Platform. Please contact your local support team for more details. Shop Feature Name: SwedishFiscalisation Type: Fiscalisation Group: Fiscalisation Values: Active - Boolean - Indicating if the fiscalization feature is currently enabled for the given shop reprintsAllowed - Whole Number (int) - Indicating how many reprints (copies of the original receipt, not including the original receipt itself) are allowed of each receipt

title: Self-Checkouts receipt printing policy
text: To comply with Swedish law Self-Checkouts will prevent sales being completed if receipt printing is unavailable. This ensures compliance with Swedish fiscal regulations and prevents transactions without proper documentation. Please speak to your K3 representative to have this enabled on your system.

title: Imagine Infrasec Setup
text: Certificates for Imagine with Infrasec happen centrally, so the only setup that needs to be performed is against the shop. This is done via a Shop Feature which is set up in Platform Admin. Name: Infrasec Type: Fiscalisation Group: Fiscalisation There are two values to create Name: Active Type: bool Value: true ConnectorOptions Type: json Value: JSONS tring (See below) Example JSON [{ mac: "CONNECTOR_ID_MAC_ADDRESS", organizationNumber: "ORGANIZATIONNUMBER_FROM_INFRASEC", registerId: "REGISTERID_FROM_INFRASEC", storePayload: true }] With values... [{ mac: "00-60-ef-2d-f1-92", organizationNumber: "3838383838", registerId: "K3D3fc7j19000101", storePayload: true }] Note: With Infrasec, it is not possible/allowed to do an Exchange - a sale and a return must be in separate transactions and this is dictated to us by Infrasec.

title: Infrasec - Identifikationsnummer - Skatteverket
text: This is normally of questions for the Tax Agency, but what I know is that when an organization (a corporate registration number) registers the control unit with its ID (in our case ISCCUSE0000000011), they receive an identity code from SKV (Swedish Tax Agency) that represents the control unit on the corporate registration number. When they then register additional cash registers for the same control unit, they use the identity code and not the control unit's ID. In other words, you cannot register the same control unit ID ISCCUSE0000000011 multiple times under the same corporate registration number; it can only be registered once per corporate registration number. When registering the cash registers, you specify the number assigned by SKV to the registration of the control unit under the corporate registration number.

title: Receipt Setup
text: You have the option to configure various types of receipts here, and each type can be set up separately. To get started, please select the store for which you would like to make changes. Upon entering the main page, you will find your current receipts displayed. Please note that any settings you modify will take up to 1 minute to be applied to the connector. The core layout of the receipt is fixed, but you have the flexibility to adjust the header and footer sections. To edit a receipt, simply click on "Edit Receipt," which will redirect you to the following page. This is where you can enter or modify your information. It's worth mentioning that you can add as many header and footer lines as needed by clicking on the "ADD" button to create a new line. Once you have inputted your desired header and footer information, save your changes, and you will be directed back to the main page. On the main page, you will now see all the receipts you have created or modified. This process applies to gift certificates and credit notes as well.

title: Editing Line Items
text: Here, you can modify the specific details of item lines that are shown on both the Point of Sale (POS) system and the receipt. You have the option to customize the item's name, description, and more. To make changes, please select the relevant option from the drop-down menus provided. Show barcode: Checking this option will display the barcode on the receipt for returns. Show loyalty points: Checking this option will show the total number of loyalty points earned by the customer. Show employee: Checking this option will include the first and last name of the clerk on the receipt. Please refer to the "Clerks" section for more information. To remove a line, simply re-select the same option to uncheck it, leaving the field blank. Once you have made your desired modifications, click on "Save" to save your changes. Please note that it may take up to 1 minute for the above settings to be applied to the connector.

title: Admin - Edit Web Order Dispatch Note
text: The "Edit Weborder Dispatch Note" feature enables you to modify the footer details specifically for web order dispatch notes. Please note that there is a predetermined number of lines for web order dispatch notes. If you leave a line blank, it will be interpreted as a line break on the receipt. To make changes, fill in the desired content for each line and click on "Save." You will then be redirected to the main screen. Scroll down to the Order Dispatch Note section, and your selected lines should be displayed accordingly.

title: Companies
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Adding a New Company Editing an Existing Company Associating a Shop with an Alternative Company A self-contained legal business entity is referred to as a Company, which can be associated with one or more locations (Shops). Nevertheless, a single location can only be linked to a single company. To illustrate, if a business encompasses various shop types such as High Street, Concession, Franchise, and plans to have Outlet shops in the future, it would be logical to establish four separate companies and assign each shop to precisely one location. Adding a New Company Step 1: To begin adding a new company you can either use the "Add Company" or "+Add Company" buttons. Step 2: Provide a name for the Company and indicate the locations you need. Then, enter the Tax Number and choose the preferred currency. Name The name was given to the Company you are creating. Location Select from the drop-down which locations you wish to assign this company to. Tax Number This is the Tax Number assigned to this Company. Currency Select the relevant Currency using the drop-down. Step 3: Your added company will now be listed along with a drop-down of its locations (shops). Editing an Existing Company Delete: Deleting the Company will prompt a pop-up to appear, giving you the option to reassign the associated shops to another location. If there are no locations set up, a default company will be used. Once you confirm the selection, the Company will be deleted. Edit: You have the option to modify the Company's Name and Tax number. However, if a Shop is assigned to the Company, it is not possible to change the Currency. Associating a Shop with an Alternative Company Use the Drag and Drop icon to associate a Shop with an alternative Company. This is useful if you did not associate the Shop with the Company when creating the Company.

title: Prices
text: TABLE OF CONTENTS Adding a New Price List Search for an Existing Price List Column Chooser Edit Item Prices Edit Variable Item Prices Using the Search Item Fields Certain companies may maintain multiple price lists that are specific to different shops or locations. These price lists are established and utilized when transferring or relocating items or inventory between various locations or businesses. If you haven't set any price lists yet, you'll notice that the price list table appears empty and shows a message that says "No Data". Adding a New Price List Step 1: To begin creating a price list click the +Add Price List button. Step 2: Provide a new name for the Price List that can be easily referenced. Then, select the appropriate source and destination from the dropdown menu. Step 3: Click the +Create Price List. Step 4: To begin populating your Price List, you can use the Items/Vendor and Hierarchy dropdowns to filter for specific items See Using the "Search Item Fields" for more information. Alternatively, you can utilize the +Add Items button to add items directly. Step 5: To add items directly, click on the +Add Items button to open a new window where you can further filter your search. You can use the search box to find items by information such as Item Number, Vendor, and Name. You can also use the "Show Inactive" toggle to view inactive items. Step 6: After selecting the items, you can click on the "Add Items" button by marking the checkbox next to each item. Step 7: Your items will now be listed in the home page, from here you can set the prices or delete items if necessary. Step 8: To modify the price of an item, simply select the "Edit" icon and input the updated price. Remember to click on the "Save" icon to ensure the changes are saved. If you wish to remove an item, click on the "Bin Icon" and confirm the deletion. Search for an Existing Price List If you have an existing price list, you can utilize the search fields in combination with the dropdown menu to refine your search results. Search for Name This is the name given to the Price List at creation. Source This is the source that was selected during the creation of the price list. Destination This is the destination that was selected during the creation of the price list. Column Chooser When adding items from the items list you can use to column chooser to narrow down which columns you see. Click the column chooser icon and from here you can drag and drop columns depending on the information you wish to see. Edit Variable Item Prices A parent item may have variables that are set, such as items that come in various colors or sizes. If these variables are available, they will be displayed below using the dropdown icon. You have the option to set individual prices for each variable, if applicable. Using the Search Item Fields You can add specific items using the Item Search fields. Items All: This will search all items. Only Items with Prices: This will search all items with a price set. Only Items Without Prices: This will search all items without a price set. Vendor Select the Vendors available to your tenant. Hierarchy This is the Item level which was set when the item was created. Search This can be used to narrow down the search using a Item Number or Item Name.

title: Items
text: Items are basic items created in the Inventory module. Here, you can configure additional properties that only relate to self-serve apps. Your item can be used as a main item in a bundle or as a selectable item in a bundle group. You can also assign any modifier groups to the item in this section. Item List Use the item list to identify and click which item you would like to edit or view more details about. To create a new item you will need to use the Inventory module. Item Details Clicking on an item will display the Item Details screen where self-serve related properties can be edited. NOTE: As these items are linked to Inventory, some properties will be overwritten if you edit them via Inventory. These are highlighted below with an *asterisk Item No A unique identifier assigned to a specific product. Name This is the name that appears on the basket and receipt of your self-serve applications. It's assigned during basic item setup in Inventory. If needed, an alternative name can be assigned on the Composer tile. Image This is the image assigned to the item in Inventory. If needed, an alternative image can be assigned to the Composer tile. Active If the item is active or not. Inactive This option hides the item from view in certain screens. The POP application and barcode scanning will take this into consideration before presenting the item. Active State is ignored if a Composer tile is linked to the item. Display Catagory This determines if the item is sent to the Order Status Display when sold. You can select previously entered display categories from the dropdown or add a new one by typing into the same dropdown. Restricted Quantity This determines if the item, when sold in the Self Checkout, requires manager approval for selling due to age related restrictions. Tags Tags can provide a flattened hierarchy. You can link Composer Tiles to one or more tags to create a dynamic list of items in the front-end apps. For instance, a range of food items can be tagged as "gluten-free," "vegan," or "containing nuts." Note that tags are given at item creation, and you can refer to @Tags for more information.

title: Product Configurator
text: Product Configurator is where you configure your Items, Bundles, Bundle Groups and Modifier Groups these groups all play different roles across the SelfServe applications within Imagine. It is important to know them and how they are used. Items - These are basic items that will have been created in the Inventory module. Here, you configure additional properties that are only related to Self-Serve apps. Your item can be used as a Main item within a Bundle or as a selectable item in a Bundle Group. This is also where you assign any Modifier Groups to the item. Bundles - These are groups of items that you can sell together. A typical example would be a 'Meal Deal'. You select a main item and then make a selection from one or more Bundle Groups to build your meal. Taking the Meal Deal example, your main item would be a sandwich. Then, from one Bundle Group, you would pick a snack, and from another Bundle Group, you would choose a drink. Bundle Groups - These are groupings of similar items from which you would be expected to make a selection. For example, you might have a selection of snacks to choose from. Bundle Group selections have to be items and can only be linked to Bundles. Modifier Groups - These provide you with the opportunity to make certain prescribed modifications to an Item. You can only make modifications to an Item or a Bundle Main item, not a Bundle Group Item. An example of a modification would be choosing between white or brown bread for your sandwich. Below explains the relationships of supported types which can be added as a Composer Tile for your self-serve apps. Using the Meal Deal example to explain the relationships. Item = [Sandwich] Modifier Group = [white or brown bread] Bundle = [Meal Deal of sandwich with snack and drink] Item = [Sandwich] Modifier Group = [white or brown bread] Bundle Group = [Snack] Item A = [Crisps] Item B = [Popcorn] Item C = [Nuts] Bundle Group = [Drink] Item D = [Cola] Item E = [Lemonade] The Example below is of a Bundle which has Modifier Groups linked to the main item. You have a tab for your Selections and a tab for your Modifiers. If you were to just select the main item, you would only see the Modifiers.

title: Transfers Page
text: The transfers screen is used to manage create, receive and issue stock transfers at all shops. Transfers follow this workflow. Transfer Out Created at sending store --> Transfer Out is committed --> Draft Transfer in Automatically Created at receiving store --> Transfer In is received at receiving store. The initial transfer list view shows all recent transfers of all statuses. NOTE: When transferring items out or in, it will be stated that the store that is sending the items will be using the weighted average cost. Search - Using the search box transfers can be searched for a particular name reference. From Date and To Date - Filters the oldest and most recent transfer that will be displayed. Shop - Chooses the active shop context for the transfer list. Type - Selectable between Transfer out or Transfer In. Status- Selectable between transfer status All, Draft and Closed. Draft - Draft transfers have been saved but not yet committed, meaning the stock will not have been affected. Closed - Closed transfers have been committed meaning stock will have been removed from the sending store or added to the receiving store.

title: Create a New Transfer
text: Clicking Create New will create a blank transfer. Description - Enter a description to identify the transfer. Source - Choose the sending store from the drop-down selection. Destination - Choose the receiving store from the drop-down selection Transfer Number - This is auto-generated when you save. Adding Items Items can be added by directly entering or scanning a barcode or by clicking Find Items Manually. A screen will be displayed for searching and adding items. Search Text - Allows searching by item name. Vendors - Allows the list to be filtered to a specific vendor. Item Groups - Allows the list to be filtered to those belonging to a specific hierarchy. Add Items - Items can be added by adjusting the + / - controls next to the lines displayed and clicking "Add Items". Items which belong to a Matrix group will have an additional Matrix button allowing these related items to be edited together. Save, Save And Commit Clicking the Save button will save the transfer as a status Draft and close the edit screen. Draft transfers can be edited again by selecting from the transfer list. Clicking Save and Commit will finalise the outgoing transfer and change the status to closed. This transfer can no longer be edited. A draft transfer will be automatically created at the receiving store.

title: Receiving a Transfer In
text: Changing the required store and choosing the transfer type "Transfer In" will show all transfers for this store. Those with a Status of "Draft" are awaiting confirmation. Click on the Transfer In to be received. The Transfer will be displayed automatically populated with the items sent from the issuing store. The line quantities can be adjusted with the + / - buttons or all quantities can be set quickly using the receive all button. When all quantities have been set, click Save and Commit to add the quantities to the inventory and close the transfer. Unit Cost -Shown in the receiving shop's currency.
